TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Ambassador to Ireland and Holy See
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recall Australia's Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, (Mr Brian Burke) and suspend his appointment while matters of propriety relating to his actions as Premier and subsequently which have been referred to the Minister are investigated, and moreover during the term of the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mining of Kakadu
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toys: Violent or War Related
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
1. they are gravely concerned over the availability of war toys and other combat or violence related toys and games, including video games, in our country.
2. they believe there is sufficient scientific evidence to show that these kind of toys and games are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging to children, and socially undesirable.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate will take measures to end all trading in war and violence related toys, games, and video games, through either self-regulation by the traders in these products, or legislative action.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of tax- payers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Governor of Victoria has set aside 219 hectares of Reserved Forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest to be the West Barham Big Trees Flora Reserve.
We humbly pray that you consider protecting a larger area of the Otways from logging by listing it as National Estate forest so that botanical, water and tourist values may be preserved.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patenting
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.
The undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would:

*compromise animal welfare, *allow genetic engineering companies to appropriate the fruits of centuries of selective breeding, *reduce biodiversity, and *further concentrate ownership of breeding stock. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Therefore, please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more.
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We urge the members of the Australian Senate to act on this petition.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Tambling had moved by way of amendment:

At end of motion add ``, but, because of the urgent need to restore the confidence of wool producers and buyers in the long-term future of the industry and in order to end the confusion caused by the Government's vacillating wool pricing policies, the reserve price scheme be abolished immediately

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate adjourned last night I was speaking on the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991, which is to amend the Wool Marketing Act 1987 to provide for a wool industry supplementary payments scheme and to suspend the reserve price scheme. As I was saying before the adjournment, the world wool price has little effect on the demand for wool. It did not in the late 1960s or in the early 1970s before the reserve price scheme began when wool prices fluctuated wildly. Buyers never minded the price of wool as long as it was relative to the price of other fibres. The only conclusion one can draw from that is that the approach of the academic economists to the current wool industry battle is badly flawed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good talking all the time about a free market in a world where a free market does not exist and does not operate. We should be ever vigilant against allowing ideology on economic issues and crass politics to misplace the needs of people. This is what is happening in many industries today, and it is at the expense of many important sections of our community. Currently it is the economic survival of the Australian wool industry which is at stake. Today we have to take action to correct the bad decisions made by the Government when it started speculating about and then subsequently reducing the floor price of wool. In yesterday's edition of the Queensland Courier-Mail there appeared a very interesting letter from a wool producer from Winton. It said:
Last year the Federal Government forced the lowering of the wool reserve price from 870c to 700c.
Federal Primary Industries Minister John Kerin subsequently promised that price would be ``immutable'', and appealed to all to give his decision a chance to work.
But the Government did the very thing Mr Kerin asked people not to do. It set up the Vines inquiry, which by its very title and terms fuelled rather than reduced industry uncertainty and instability.
Buyers predictably held back for months with a wary return to the market towards the end of the year.
Gradually a higher percentage was being bought until the market hit rock bottom with sales suspended.
Ordinary growers had no idea of the reason.
Is this really the Government's idea of promoting a climate of stability to get the wool industry back on its feet?

Of course, the Government thought that it would be able to get those millions of bales of wool in Australia to the markets if it reduced the price. Where are those bales now? They are stored in sheds throughout Australia. It is to correct this problem that we are debating this Bill today.

Currently, the farm cash operating surplus of the woolgrowers has been estimated to fall to negative $5,700 in 1991-92, according to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) and will remain around these levels for at least two years. The increased debt that must be financed will require increased levies as a direct result of the limit placed on the Government's contribution to the supplementary payments scheme. As the ABARE figure indicates, this will be very difficult to achieve.

Woolgrowers are facing a future of enormous depressed financial circumstances and they want and need financial assistance now before they are irrevocably destroyed. What we have to remember is that the financial position of woolgrowers affects the rural communities in which they live throughout Australia. The Government has an obligation to help them. It has a particular obligation because the whole collapse of the reserve price scheme is the result of irresponsible speculation on the part of the Government and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. We have to remember in particular that it was Mr Kerin who originally said that he would consider lowering the floor price.

When the reserve price of 870c was originally set, it was during a period of high prices for wool. In fact, the price of 870c was conservative at the time, with wool fetching about 1200c. It was the Minister who then decided to start to speculate that the reserve price would drop. So, naturally, buyers stayed away from the markets in anticipation of that drop. Of course, if the Minister was forced by the economic blow-out of the Budget to drop the price once, can we blame any businessman for suspecting that if times got tough enough the Minister would, despite his many assurances throughout the world that he would not, again drop the reserve price?

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—I agree with Senator Boswell that it was. Mr Kerin went around the world promising that the wool price would stay at 700c. His word was immutable, he said that the floor price would be maintained until June 1992. The Japanese Government, the Italian Government and the British Government all took Mr Kerin at his word. In fact, I saw an article in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day stating that the Japanese are seeking wool payment from the Australian Government in compensation to cover losses arising from the wool industry chaos. This article went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Japanese importers, collectively the biggest customers for Australian wool, are furious over losses of up to $50 million that they will suffer as a result of misleading advice from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, last November.

What about the loss of $500m that Australian woolgrowers are going to suffer? I was interested to see that Mr Yasui, general manager of the wool division at Nippon Keori-one of the biggest Japanese importers-is reported as saying:
When we met Mr Kerin in Osaka, we believed his comment . . . We were wrong to accept Mr Kerin's statement.
I do not think that does Mr Kerin or the Government very much good at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Australia's needs?
—I do not know that we can believe that, actually. That is what this has proved.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Kerin further compounded the sabotage by giving his support to members of the Vines committee which travelled Europe supposedly seeking information on the wool industry, but asking buyers whether they would buy the wool if it dropped to 500c. All of this was done with the general authorisation of the Minister, who has even foolishly defended the action. Does the Government not have enough sense to realise that this was the green light for buyers to stay away in anticipation of that drop to 500c or lower?

One of my main concerns with this current legislation is that we act to maintain the mechanism for a floor price. This should be especially important until we see the results of the Vines report and its recommendations. It is for this reason that I will not be supporting the amendment moved yesterday by Senator Tambling to terminate permanently the reserve price scheme. I ask my coalition colleagues just what they will suggest we do when we have to consider this issue later this year if the Vines committee recommends that some sort of similar scheme be retained.

After all, prior to this round of destruction of the industry by the Minister, Mr Kerin, and the Government, a reserve price scheme had been the basis of a successful wool industry since 1972. I really cannot agree with the proposition that the wool reserve price should be abolished today. The Government says it should be suspended at the moment, and I certainly do not agree that it should be abolished.

Finally, I believe that the Government should also make good its compensation to the industry in light of the damage it has caused. After all, the Government is good at giving money to rescue other industries which have failed. It has given guarantees to the South Australian State Bank and it gave assistance to both Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd and the car industry. I believe that it should also do so for what was Australia's most productive industry. The Government also owes the industry more compensation than it is currently proposing to pay.

When the Government pushed the floor price down last autumn, the Australian Wool Corporation had to buy the stocks of wool at 870c and sell them at 700c. This cost the industry not $300m but $500m and, as such, the Government owes the industry and the growers this money. This is not a generous hand-out; rather, it is what it owes to the growers because of its irresponsible actions in destroying Australia's wool industry.

I certainly agree with amendment No. 1 to be moved by Senator Tambling on behalf of the Opposition in the Committee of the Whole to provide a limit or a cap of $200m on the borrowings of the Wool Corporation. If the borrowings continue to blow out, the woolgrowers could be up for a wool tax of 41 per cent and that, of course, is a very good way to go broke. At the moment, there seems to be much talk of loans that have to be paid back and increasing costs to the woolgrowers. The President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr John Allwright, said that the Government should reduce costs to farmers-and that of course includes woolgrowers-such as sales taxes and fuel charges. He also said that there is much the Government can do to reduce the uncompetitive level of domestic costs imposed on farmers and other exporters.

I remind the Senate that the Government does give $1 billion in overseas aid. I believe increased assistance should be available for our wool industry which is, and has been, our biggest earner of overseas trade balance and, as such, has contributed so much to the living standard of all who live in urban Australia. There is no doubt in my mind that the Government should increase assistance to what was once the most productive sector of the Australian economy. In conclusion, I want to remind honourable senators that there is a future for wool and the wool industry of Australia. It is a top quality product and, given a fair chance, it will compete successfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to speak to the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill. I have already listened to and read many excellent speeches that must be close to the heart of every Australian and certainly every honourable senator and honourable member who has spoken. What a disaster the wool growing industry has become.

SPEECH.PARA: The question before us all must be: how long will it take to re-establish the industry? I hope that in the weeks, months or years ahead the major effort will be given not to raking over the recrimination of the past and where to lay blame, but to looking at a new, vigorous, competitive and fully integrated wool industry for the future. Since January 1990, when I was first acquainted of the impending disaster, I have been amazed at the way the industry has lurched from post to post, making no progress whatsoever. I have been equally amazed that the growers have no idea of how the industry operates; even the Wool Council of Australia complains about its problems of getting information from the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC). One grower recently said to me that any grower under 45 years of age really does not remember what woolgrowing and marketing was like pre-Corporation. During their careers, they have been totally insulated from the realities of the market and the performance of the growers organisations.

The enormity of the situation is escaping many people and leading to all sorts of totally unrealistic comments, suggestions, requests and even demands. We are talking about an industry, initially involving 76,000 producers, which grows to about 400,000 with the various multipliers in the town and country areas. There is a grower investment in the stockpile of $1,800m. That in itself is a huge amount of money; but they also have a debt of $2,800m. This is a real debt and every one of those 76,000 growers has a liability in it, averaging $40,000, with interest growing daily. Interest is currently accruing at the rate of, say, $400m a year, or in excess of $1m a day. The assets of the Corporation comprise the stockpile, which is plus or minus five million bales, plus its buildings, plant and equipment valued at somewhere between $500m and $1,000m.

Recently, I have been told many times of all the virtues of the Corporation and all the good things it has done and how well it operates. But I find that I must question that. It may have made the woolgrower's life easier, but has it really assisted him in the long term? For instance, figures produced recently indicate that the price received is less, in comparative terms, than it would have been without a floor price.

A short time ago, wool enjoyed about 10 per cent of the world fibre market. If our promotion is so good and our plans so sound, why does wool now enjoy less than 4 per cent of the world fibre market-and falling? Recently, a delegation to China of which I was a member was told by the Chinese that wool was just another fibre, and that they do not like our floor price scheme or our auction system. We must take what they say very seriously because they are customers. That comes from a country which could, under a better arrangement, be our biggest customer for wools which we produce in abundance and which are very hard to sell, so it is very important.

In view of that comment, we must also compare wool with cotton. The cotton industry is not having this fuss. It is increasing its sales. It runs a very low cost system and it is increasing its prices. It has no stockpile and no huge bureaucracy. So we must also ask: is it out of step, or is wool? I just pose that question.

When I came to this Parliament, I found it the done thing to kick the processing sector of the industry-the industry being, I believe, a broad union of growers, processors and users alike. When I expressed my views in the Parliament, I received an invitation to attend the headquarters of the Corporation for lunch-which was lunch and a very stiff rebuke, based on the fact that processing and manufacturing in Australia was undesirable and that I would be better off by not supporting the industry but supporting the Corporation's point of view. I would have to add that, apart from the fact that it made me more determined than ever to pursue the value adding, broader industry view, the view that the Corporation expressed that day still seems to persist. As a result of this, I got to know Mr Kevin Perrott and his successor, Louise Jamson, of the Wool Textile Manufacturers of Australia very well, and I commend to the Parliament and to the producer section of the whole industry not only that the type of proposals that Kevin Perrott produced several years ago should be acted upon, but that that should be done properly and quickly.

So much concentration has been placed on the development of the exclusive image of wool, and the miracle fibre promotion, that the concept of wool being the popular and universal product has been lost. The concentration of the Corporation has been on all of the ways of buying wool in, not on getting wool sold and in use. Wool that is on customers' backs and wool in and out of shops around the world must take the place of wool in AWC wool stores.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has quoted $220 per bale per year as the cost of keeping a bale in store. With five million bales, the total cost runs to approximately $1 billion per year. How long can we even contemplate watching an asset disappear? Growers of wool must come to grips with that, particularly as I note that some commentators, such as David Barnett, are saying that the total value of the stockpile on realisation may be only about $2 billion, or there- abouts, in the first place. We are losing forever 60c per bale per day-$1 billion per year-and most growers would have no idea of how much money that is. That is a huge amount and it is their asset that is disappearing.

We are much better to be selling and loss cutting by getting wool popularised than we are to be pretending that 700c can be supported as a reasonable figure. If wool is so good at 700c, why do we have five million unsold bales eating their heads off? Certainly, price is not the only factor: promotion, quality and reliability also influence buyers. But all things being equal, the greatest single determining factor in any goods is price. We must get the sales going and we must recognise that, for whatever reason, there is no credibility left for the 700c price. Much as I and every woolgrower in Australia would like to feel that that can be attained, that is not the case. Prosperity, or the industry's return to it, can come only from a stimulation of sales. We must concentrate on the buyers. I have always said that I do not care what one grows, breeds, produces or makes-it is worthless unless there is a buyer prepared to buy. And currently buyers are unhappy and are not buying.

The funding is gone-it is all spent-and returning to the past is not an option. Large increases in the debt are simply not possible. I would like to quote the Chairman of the Corporation in the Australian Woolgrower letter of February 1991. On the front page he says that the realities of life must be faced. That is what the industry now has before it. He further states on the third page of that letter:
Every bale of wool bought from now on must certainly cost more than its eventual value in interest and storage costs. This is not commercially rational.

To continue to operate the 700 cent floor would almost inevitably lead to a stockpile of more than six million bales and a debt above $4 billion. Such a level of debt covered by Government guarantee is politically unacceptable. The burden of funding and servicing such a debt would be intolerable for the wool growing industry and too great to ask the taxpayer to subsidise for long.

It is just not possible. The floor price must cease. The sales must proceed urgently. The obligation to growers to the end of the 1990-91 season must be attended to. The existing stocks must be quarantined. The stockpile management and disposal program must be handled with greater care. The assets of the Corporation will need to be realised to whatever amount is necessary to meet to pay-out obligations on the suppliers and/or interest, and not by further increasing the debt.

Australia is the world leader in wool production and has 180 million sheep or thereabouts. New Zealand has 65 million sheep, South Africa 30 million and Uruguay 26 million, and Australia must give the lead that this involves. The industry has had some great leaders, but time seems to have separated them from the growers who, in the main, are totally ignorant of the overall situation. Right now, added debt of high magnitude will not help and the Australian Democrats who are canvassing a more money-debt situation cannot be taken seriously. I refer back to Mr Beggs again on that, and he does not believe that it will help either. That is why the Liberal-National Party decision was taken to limit the extra funding to $300m from the Government and a $200m balance of loan with any further needs to come from the sale of assets.

The other issue that must be raised is the effect of government policies generally on the market. We have the best and most efficient woolgrowing sector in the world. Its productivity is fantastic and the quality of its produce is the best in the world. So why are woolgrowers not wealthy? Well, production costs are high; interest rates are crippling; inflation exceeds that among our trading partners; shipping and transport costs are totally out of control; the trumped up value of our Australian dollar makes our produce unaffordable in many countries; and fuel costs and so on for broad acre farmers is an enormous proportion of the total cost. Why can we not attack these handicaps and get them right?

In summary, I quote the comments of three very well-known and respected Tasmanian woolgrowers reported in this week's Tasmanian Country. Bert Farquhar, a very well-known and substantial woolgrower in Tasmania, made the comment:
Now is the time to aggressively market wool and to establish new markets.
He is looking ahead. Then there is Andrew Cameron who said:
I am not at all shocked because I could see the industry was getting too far into debt. If we continued to buy our own wool we would not have been facing reality.
Then Robert Gatenby said:
You can never go back to a floor price scheme again because your credibility has all gone.

The state of affairs is a national disaster and the realities have to be faced. We could not pursue a slaughter program; we could not go along with an insupportable floor price. We must recognise that all those who are involved at any level of the industry must share the responsibility. The Government relaxed its control, the Corporation lost touch with its responsibilities and its growers, and the growers believed that they were insulated permanently from market reality. We must get together and plan for the future-a future involving ways to increase the growing and use of wool for the benefit of Australia as a whole.

I am greatly disturbed at the present state of the woolgrowing industry, but it is well within the wit of Parliament and the industry to finalise the 1990-91 underwriting, to arrange orderly disposal of the stockpile, to go out and promote wool as the universal and popular fibre, and to get the past behind us as quickly as we can. I support the Opposition amendments, but oppose the others. I hope that we can pass the legislation without delay so that we can get started.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are once again debating wool-the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991. Unfortunately, that has been the tone in the industry for the past three years-every bit of legislation has been very temporary. At the outset of my remarks let me declare my interest in the wool industry as a woolgrower.

SPEECH.PARA: I start where I finished in a previous debate in this chamber on this subject, namely on 15 November 1990. We were then dealing with a Bill to increase the maximum tax rate to 30 per cent and allow for an extra 20 per cent surcharge, if necessary. I concluded that speech by saying that at that time I was prepared to believe Mr Beggs for the third and final time. Unfortunately, he let me down for a third and final time. I had believed him, and did so reluctantly, twice before. The first time was when the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) lifted the floor price from 670c to 870c per kilo on 1 July 1988; it had made the decision six weeks before. That was done against the better, cooler heads of the growers around Australia, traders, merchants and processors.

The second time was when the maximum wool tax was increased to 20 per cent, with the Corporation assuring us that the reserve price would remain viable. That was in May-June 1990; the decision was made six months previously, but it was implemented at that time. The third time, as I have said, was in November 1990. There has been one calamity after another. We increased it to the 30 per cent and 20 per cent levy.

On or about 1 December 1990 Mr Beggs and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) left on their famous journey around the world, telling wool-buying nations that the ironclad figure of 700c per kilo would remain for at least two years. Some countries actually believed Mr Beggs and Mr Kerin and there was a short sharp jump in clearances. I know that during January and the latter part of December clearances were up to 64 per cent, but that did not last long. A lot of people tell us that it did not last because of the Gulf war, but I do not believe that was the case.

The Corporation knew, as buyers knew all along, including myself, that the reserve price scheme had failed. In other words, buyers bought to fill up the pipeline to supply wool to mills for a certain time. Buyers knew it was finished and that the money ran out. I believe that certain people would or should have known that the money was running out before we were told. I liken it to the position in the State Bank of South Australia in that we should have known a lot more a lot earlier.

I used to be a supporter of the scheme and I believed that it did a certain amount of good at that time, but step by step since 1973 or thereabouts when it came in it has been wrecked step by step. There are quite a few reasons why that has happened. First, the reserve price scheme has been too high and too inflexible. The reserve price did not allow for certain things to happen, such as production. Then there was a lack of market signals to growers, and the greed and arrogance of the industry. I am part of the industry, but I believe that there is too much greed and a certain arrogance in the industry. It believed that we were back in the 1950s when wool was a pound a pound. Australia in those days was the only one with the wool and buyers had to pay the price we wanted or go without it.

The incompetence of the Corporation has led to some of the downfall. Then there was the gullibility of the Minister in giving in to every whim of the industry. Every time the Corporation wanted to change something, whether to increase levies or whatever, the Minister gave in. The only time when he was strong was when he reduced the floor price from 870c to 700c, which he should have done a long time before. Then there was overproduction of wool that came about because of a high guaranteed price. If one wants overproduction, just guarantee a good high price and the product will flow through. I could give plenty of good examples, but I have not time to do so now. At present we have 5.6 million bales in store and a debt of $2.8 billion. That debt was on 1 January and does not allow for any buying by the Corporation in the January sales before they were cancelled. Unfortunately, now our only option is damage control.

The first step is that the Corporation and its Chairman, Mr Beggs, resign, as the only honourable thing they can do. I know they are not bound by the Westminster system but I think they should take note of it and resign. If they will not, I believe the Minister should make sure that they resign by invoking section 147 (1) (b) to remove them-just as Marcus Clark was removed in South Australia-and appointing an administrator under section 147 (2) (b).

Sections 147 (1) (b) and 147 (2) are very strong sections. In fact, the Wool Council of Australia-a representative body of the growers-has written to everyone in this chamber, asking us to eliminate that section. In other words, it wants to build self-preservation into the legislation so that it cannot be removed. That is a ridiculous situation. Even the Prime Minister and the Government of this country can be dismissed, as happened in 1975. Here is the letter, for everyone to see, asking us to eliminate this section so that directors cannot be removed by the Minister or anyone else.

I will carry on a little further about the Australian Wool Council. I do not know whether everyone in this place reads the West Australian, but I suppose Western Australians read it. I have a cutting here from yesterday's paper which is headed, `Wool revenge vow'. The article states:
The Wool Council has vowed to campaign against the Liberals and Nationals in the next Federal election after the coalition refused to block crucial wool legislation yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given their other competence, I wouldn't worry too much.
—Agreed, but I will read the rest of it. The Opposition will move amendments which we hope will be passed for the betterment of the industry. The article continues as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Wool Council president Chip Sawers said the council would spare no effort to see that woolgrowers and others who depended on the industry understood the Opposition's lack of support.

This will be the first time that the Wool Council of Australia has kept the industry informed. It represents only 64 per cent of Australian woolgrowers anyhow, because it is only that many who belong to grower organisations. This will be the first time that it has done anything about informing growers. I have compared it in this chamber before with the Australian Wheat Board. If I have a criticism of the Wheat Board it is that it overloads my table with information, but one gets nothing from this crowd except when it informs the woolgrowers of what we intend to do.
It carries on with another ridiculous argument in the articles as follows:

Though the Opposition wants to amend the legislation to scrap the floor price scheme, freeze the stockpile and put a $200 million limit on industry-financed supplementary payments, this would delay . . . sales until mid-March.

The only thing it did not tell us is why it would delay sales. If there is money there, the sales can start on Monday even if they are limited to $200m from the industry and $300m from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are keeping the Reps around in case you do anything.

—Good. It makes these ridiculous statements and does not back them up. So much for the AWC. If the Minister is not prepared to sack the Corporation, unless it goes voluntarily, I believe the Minister should resign himself.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go further I must tell the Senate what everyone knows, which is that the wool system has been wrecked by incompetence, as I have already said. It is no use suspending the reserve price, it should be eliminated, and eliminated now. I am surprised that the Government is not working that way in the first place, because otherwise there will be another postponement and another debate later in this chamber. We will get one in May, anyhow, as these measures are temporary. If we could put it to rest now we would not have to go through it again. There is probably some hope that the reserve price scheme will return after July. Worse still, wool buyers around the world might think the same thing. If they do, there will be more insecurity in buying-they have been hit a few times already-and that will prevent us from getting back to the final reality of how to sell goods in the market, with market forces. The commencement of the recovery of one of Australia's greatest industries will be slow-a recovery which is at least five years away.

Now I come to the biggest hurdle that will prevent the market from getting back to full strength and not distort market forces, and that is the stockpile that my colleague Senator Archer so ably mentioned. The stockpile stands at 5.6 million bales and could rise further because, as I said, January's wool has been passed in and has not been accounted for. The provision of this Bill applying to the disposal of the stockpile appears under section 146 which states:
. . . the Corporation must sell . . . or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool . . . in accordance with . . . guidelines

Where are the guidelines? I have not seen the final draft guidelines floating around but I think we are on the third interim edition already. The Opposition will be moving an amendment later on-and I will run through it now for the sake of this argument-to hold that stockpile in suspense, or isolate it, for 12 months.

Some people will say that that, once again, may distort the marketplace. I certainly do not believe in that theory because there is another 5.5 million bales in the pipeline for next year. We now have 40 per cent of the clip to sell this year, which means there is another 60 per cent of the clip still growing on the sheep's back, so there will be ample wool coming through to keep the wool markets supplied.

If we have at least 12 months isolation, countries such as those in Eastern Europe will be coming back into the market after throwing off communism. They will be buying wool, hopefully, within 18 months and they will be buying the supply that we have in the stockpile-23, 24 and 25 micron wool. That will be a good market. They will be followed by China which, hopefully, will be buying heavily; it needs this 23 to 25 micron wool for its climate and that will ease things for the stockpile.

There are measures in the Bill which propose supplementary payments for those growers who are not protected after 1 February when the reserve price scheme was suspended. The Government has decided, as set out in this Bill, that it will put in $300 million for equity for those growers. However, under section 142 the Government has an open-ended financial situation for the industry. If we go into the markets next week with an open-ended situation and the Corporation has to borrow with no limit to operate, there will be rorts in the market. Buyers can bid very low, the Corporation will have to make it up and, having borrowed that money, will have to add it on to the $2.8 billion already borrowed. The estimates are only about $600m, but I believe the figure could reach another $1 billion to add on, so there will be $4 billion debt in total. A $4 billion debt is exactly twice the value of the gold produced in Australia, and it will not be paid off overnight. I believe the coalition is going the right way by moving an amendment to put on a cap of $200m, giving a total amount of $500m.

The question then is: how are we going to make sure there is equity for those who sell between now and 30 June? As I told my party room yesterday, I think the only way to do that is to start off with what we can do without. That is, by selling the assets of the Corporation. Its Melbourne headquarters would do for a start. There is $1 billion there in fixed assets that could be used. Those growers who may not get as much from the original top up could have the first call on it. That is how it can be done.

How are we to pay for that stockpile. If a woolgrower sells a clip at an average price of 200c per kilo greasy-I think that would be a fairly conservative figure; I certainly hope it is not be lower-I believe that the Australian wool clip next year will be worth $2 billion. A wool tax of 20 per cent will be required to pay the interest on the current debt. If the cap is accepted at no more than $3 billion, the interest bill will be $400m per annum. So 20 per cent of $2 billion is the figure needed to meet that tax. Therefore, a grower would be left with 160c a kilo or $320 per bale.

I can assure honourable senators that all woolgrowers will not be profiting from selling wool at that price. They certainly will not be making money, even if they meet production costs. Returning to my previous argument, if we can isolate the stockpile for at least 12 months, or maybe longer, the production after next year will go down because farmers will cut down on sheep numbers through non-mating, selling off old sheep early, swinging over to cattle production or, if the wheat industry can be sorted out, growing wheat. In that way, hopefully the farmers will survive. I believe that the traditional growers will hold on.

The Government should be carrying the stockpile or certainly part of it. I suppose that we could ask why the Government should carry it. Mr Kerin gave an undertaking that the 700c per kilo was ironclad, so arrangements were made on that figure. Buyers purchased wool on that basis. If the Government is not prepared to isolate the stockpile and take over all of the assets, it should at least be providing assistance on part of it. I believe that every step taken by the Australian Wool Corporation was agreed to by Mr Kerin. The three steps that I mentioned before were each responsible for $1 billion of debt in that stockpile.

One section of the industry has been forgotten in this legislation: private buyers. In Australia, private buyers make up 20 per cent of the trade. In Western Australia they make up 30 per cent of the trade. There are 14 member companies of the private trading organisations in Australia but, unfortunately, this Government treats them as overseas companies. Private buyers deal directly with woolgrowers but foreign companies do not. There is no contact with them whatsoever. Private buyers were protected when their excess stock was put back onto the floor. When whole clips were bought to fill existing orders, any wool that might be left over would be returned to the floor and it would have protection. This protection has been taken from the buyers. Furthermore, when the wool sales were suspended on 1 February, private buyers had a substantial amount of wool already in the catalogue. Those stocks were to be protected; however, those sales were suspended and now there is no protection whatsoever in this legislation. I will be mentioning this in the committee stage-that the Government probably forgot about those private buyers.

As a result of changes in the legislation covering this industry during the past nine or 12 months, a small firm in Western Australia lost $200,000 in November and stands to lose $120,000 with the latest drop in the floor price. A larger firm, based in the eastern States, lost $2m when the floor price changed from 870c to 700c last November, and it stands to lose a swag on the present reduction. Those Australian companies have lost all protection. If those companies were protected up until then, they should also be protected until 30 June.

I believe that the wool industry will be in the wilderness for the next five years. The traditional growers-not necessarily the fringe growers who came into the industry, such as the speculators with 30 million sheep on the public stock-routes in New South Wales and those who changed over from cattle, who will leave the industry anyway-can survive. As I mentioned earlier, if the wheat industry can be improved, which can easily be achieved if we can convince the European Community and the United States to stop the stupid trade war, that will help this wool industry get through the difficult years to come. There are other ways by which the wool industry can be helped, including off-farm investment. But it will be a long, hard slog.

As a woolgrower, I am prepared to stay in the industry for five years without any return. I believe that some growers cannot remain in the industry and, unfortunately, they may go into liquidation. I feel for them. Unfortunately, that is the way things are going but it could have been prevented if the system had been managed a little better. I conclude by asking the Minister, Mr Kerin, to do something about the Corporation and its Chairman. It is no good leaving someone in that position to iron out a mess that that person and the Corporation made in the first place. This was done in the South Australia bank episode. The only credit that I give to the Premier of South Australia is for doing just that, if it was his action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a dreadful mess the Government has made of handling the wool marketing scheme. Mr Kerin has continued to blame the industry, the industry blames Mr Kerin and the Wool Council of Australia blames everyone. It is no use looking at who is blaming whom because we are all aware that the buck stops with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). I am not saying this lightly. I would like to go back over the history as to why the responsibility rests with the Minister. It starts in 1960 when the heads of a few growers' organisations were seeking a method of removing the very highs and lows in their income. The then Country Party sought to put forward an orderly marketing scheme for wool to overcome the problem. At that stage, Sir Robert Menzies, the then Prime Minister, insisted on a referendum for the growers as to whether there should be such a scheme. Of course, that was thoroughly defeated by the growers who were free marketeers.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion raised its head again in 1970 when the Australian Wool Board put forward a proposal for a flexible reserve price. Legislation was passed in 1972 establishing a Wool Industry Act. This was put forward by the right honourable member for New England, Mr Sinclair. We must look at this legislation. It stated:

The Corporation shall, so far as it is able to do so consistently . . . perform its function under the last preceding section for the advantage of Australian woolgrowers and the Australian economy by means directed to encouraging and facilitating the purchase of Australian wool, and at the same time in securing, in respect of the purchase of Australian wool, prices that are not subject to undue fluctuation or irregularity and are at levels appropriate-
I repeat, levels appropriate-
to the competitive position of wool in world markets.

The Corporation shall, at fortnightly intervals, make reports to the Minister and the Treasurer concerning the operation of its reserve price scheme, and shall include in the report such information as the Minister directs concerning:
(a) the reserve price determined by the Corporation;
(b) wool purchased and wool held by the Corporation; and
(c) sales of wool by the Corporation and proposed offerings of wool by the Corporation.

The Minister shall, from time to time, after consultation with the Treasurer, inform the Corporation in writing of the policies and principles that the Government of the Commonwealth considers should be followed and applied by the Corporation in the operation of its reserve price scheme.

(4) The Minister may, on behalf of the Government of the Commonwealth, if he thinks it necessary to do so, give a direction in writing to the Corporation with respect to the operation of the reserve price scheme . . . and the Corporation shall comply with that direction.

The legislation states that the Australian Wool Corporation shall provide a fortnightly report to the Minister. It went ahead very successfully, and should have been maintained. But what did this Government do when it got in? I stress that the rot started with what the Government did in 1987. It rescinded that legislation and substituted legislation which states:
. . . before the commencement of each financial year, the Corporation shall:
(a) determine the prices that, having regard to past wool prices and all other matters that it considers relevant, ought to be the prices for certain types of wool for that year; and
(b) publish a price, to be known as the minimum market indicator reserve price for that year, that is the weighted average of those prices.
(2) The Corporation shall not publish a price under paragraph (1) (b) unless the Wool Council has agreed . . .
All it had to do was make the Wool Council agree. If the Corporation or the Wool Council could not agree on a price, the Minister had the ability to intervene.

It was not a fortnightly report. It had its own power. It did not have to take regard of any competitive prices, world prices or anything else. It was indeed a full method of giving full control to the Corporation. The Minister now wonders why things have gone wrong. We have to make sure that the Australian people and the woolgrowers remember that the buck stops with the Government and the Minister, as he changed the legislation. The Government lost full control and the Corporation got out of control. It was no longer flexible and the levels were not appropriate to the competitive position of wool in the world markets. It was a yearly, rather than a fortnightly, decision as what the market could stand. The Minister bears considerable responsibility for this. I repeat that this is where the rot started.

I will bring us up to date. Until July this year the levy was 8 per cent on a floor price of 870c. It then rose to 18 per cent. Mr Kerin at last intervened in October and the levy went up to 25 per cent and the floor price was reduced to 700c. The Government guaranteed a $3 billion debt-loan, if you like-to be incurred by the Corporation. That did not work. In November we got new legislation. The Government then said not only that the levy would go from 25 per cent to 30 per cent but also that on top of that there would be a 20 per cent surcharge, that money would be paid to have 20 million sheep culled, and that the Corporation would introduce a 65 to 75 per cent quota scheme but it did not get round to stating the exact figures-with all the injustices of a quota system which I spoke about in my last speech. The Opposition absolutely opposed that 20 per cent surcharge. We said that the growers could not be charged 50 per cent of their cheque with a 700c floor price, which the Government proposed should be done.

Of course we also opposed the Corporation's quota scheme. At that time we sought a commercial slaughter. We said, `Pay the growers a reasonable amount and get rid of about 47 million sheep, otherwise this oversupply will go on year after year'. The Government would not accept that and instead it made a cast iron promise to retain the floor price at 700c. As we know, Mr Kerin went overseas promising that the floor price would be retained and that there would be no move at all in this regard. To begin with, the growers and the buyers believed him. I doubt whether the Corporation believed him because it knew it was broke. Nevertheless, the Minister went overseas perpetuating this myth that the floor price would not move.

The Corporation, whether it believed him or not, sent out a questionnaire to all growers to establish their right to a quota. The injustice of this was absolutely unbelievable. Growers spent week after week trying to establish their right to a quota. It was not easy. Some of them had withheld wool from the previous sales. They had to make out their right of appeal. I do not know the cost of that to the Corporation-it must have been fairly substantial-but the cost and time to the grower was immense. All this was done prior to any legislation on quotas being passed through this Senate.

As Mr Kerin travelled overseas he knew that his promise was now unsustainable. He now says that the 700c floor price was never going to work unless the Chinese and the Russians came into the market and unless farmers started cutting back on production. Mr Kerin said, `I knew it was a big risk'. This is what he now says and he knew this when he travelled overseas making his cast iron promise that the floor price would remain.

The truth has finally been told to the growers and the buyers that the floor price cannot be sustained. Suddenly-and it was sudden, Mr Kerin's excuse being, `The Treasurer does not say when the dollar will be devalued, so how could I say we were going to drop the floor price'-all sales were cancelled and the floor price is proposed to be dropped. And we are now debating this legislation.

Let us have a look at the result of that. Of course the Japanese are screaming for compensation. They say that our credibility has gone, that they will encourage people not to buy any of our agricultural produce and that we cannot be trusted. The European buyers have lost confidence in us and our growers have no idea what the Government is on about. They did not know how much in debt we were. They did not know their Corporation was bankrupt because the Minister and the Corporation did not tell them.

Let us look at the new legislation, which, as the Government says, is an attempt to allow the 35 per cent to 40 per cent of growers yet to sell their wool to receive 700c-as though the floor price were still in existence. First, the floor price is to be suspended until 30 June. It will then be reviewed in light of the Vines committee report.

Secondly, the Wool Corporation presently has a debt of $2.8 billion. The Government's present guarantee to the Corporation borrowing is $3 billion. It now proposes to extend that to $3.5 billion in this present legislation.

Thirdly, the Government will give a grant of $300m to assist the Corporation to make deficit payments to growers who receive less than the previous floor price of 700c. Next, the Minister could appoint an administrator. Also, guidelines will be set up on how the Corporation will handle the stockpile. Finally, very extensive powers are to be given to the Minister. Those are the six main points of the legislation that we are debating today.

All of this may sound fine. But let us have a look at the points one at a time. Firstly, the Government suspended the floor price rather than abolishing it, as we claim should be done. The Minister has said that dropping the floor price was by far the hardest decision that he had ever taken. He also has said that one of his biggest mistakes was reducing the floor price to 700c rather than dropping it altogether. If he says that that was his biggest mistake, why does this legislation continue to perpetrate the myth that the floor price could be reintroduced after 30 June?

For goodness sake, let us be honest with the growers, even at this late stage. We must allow the buyers and the growers to have confidence. They knew as soon as the sales were cancelled that the floor price had gone. Does the Government really think that the Japanese, Italian and German buyers will come back if we continue to say that there should be a floor price? What about China and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? Will they ever start up again if we say that the floor price should be restarted? We will lose all credibility if we continue to say this sort of thing. They know that the floor price will not be reintroduced. So, let us be honest.

The present debt incurred by the Corporation on behalf of the growers already is between $2.8 billion and $2.9 billion. We must now face the fact that this is the growers' debt-not the Government's debt. On the basis of that $2.8 billion to $2.9 billion debt, each woolgrower's debt is $55,000. Woolgrowers have been paying a 25 per cent levy just to meet the interest payments on that debt.

The Government says to the Corporation, `Between now and 30 June you can incur a further debt of $700m'. That will bring the debt up to $3.5 billion and this will mean that each woolgrower will be $69,000 in debt. I do not know how the woolgrowers who will be left in the industry after this debacle will ever keep up with the $400m interest payment on the present debt of $2.8 billion let alone the additional interest payment of $200m on a debt of $3.5 billion. Farmers will have to pay $600m in interest on this debt of $3.5 billion. As growers leave the industry there will be fewer producers to pay the debt and, therefore, those who are left will have to pay more.

What levy will have to be imposed after June, when the floor price ceases to exist, to service that debt? Will it be 12, 14, 20 or 22 per cent? I do not know. It all depends where the price levels out and on how many growers will be left in the industry. How can the Government continue to allow the Corporation to go on incurring more and more debt on behalf of the growers-at least, those growers who are left in the industry next season? Because we feel so strongly that this debt must be stopped, we will be moving an amendment that the Corporation cannot incur more than an additional $200m, not the $700m that the Government has encouraged and which is totally irresponsible.
The Opposition will also be moving an amendment which points out the need to freeze the stockpile for 12 months. The amendment, in part, states:

(b) in any period after that described in paragraph (a), the Corporation shall only sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products in a publicised, orderly and predictable manner, as prescribed in a subsequent enactment.'.''.

I will leave my comments on the draft guidelines that the Minister has proposed until the committee stage. Time does not permit me to do so now. I would like to take a few minutes to comment on the extraordinary situation that all of this has been allowed to develop and continue without any sincere attempt by the Government to encourage a world-class spinning industry in Australia.

Over the last eight years the Government has sat back and altered the wool marketing scheme legislation. Although our economy has been going down the drain, the Government has not made any sincere attempt to go out and seek the expertise that we need for downstream processing. The Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, which is a statutory body, offers assistance of $800,000 over two years to encourage downstream processing. So this is what the Government has done in regard to the textile, clothing and footwear industry.

The Government has also implemented a program under the heading `Incentives for international competitiveness-raw material processing program'. Under this program, the Australian Industry Development Corporation offers one-third equity in any wool or cotton project for downstream processing. That is a very generous offer. Two proposals have been looked at but, for various reasons, they have not been taken up. But the Government has not, in terms of immigration policy, sought to attract the skills that we need. We should be going out and seeking people with the skills that we need for fine wool processing. But the Government is not doing so. As a priority, the Government must go out and seek those skills and seek international investment.

Australia exports over 80 per cent of our clip. The remaining wool is processed at various levels, from the early stage of processing-that is, scouring of carbonised wool and tops-to the late stage processing of yarn and fabric. The need for our own downstream processing is unquestionable. Growers get just $28 out of a woollen suit which retails for $1,400-just 2 per cent.

Many say that we should stick to what we know best and what we have done historically. Japan would still be processing silk worm fibre if it were to follow such advice. Mr Thomas, the managing director of the largest processor of tops, throws cold water on any expansion into fabric manufacture because he claims that we are too far from overseas markets, that market countries apply tariffs on imported fabrics and that Australia's present economic environment is not conducive to competitive marketing. He says that we cannot extend our downstream processing because our economic situation is so dreadful. What an indictment of the Government!

In 1988 the Industry Development Commission commissioned a report from Werner International to examine the potential for adding more internal value to the Australian wool clip by increased domestic downstream processing and the subsequent export of these products.
The report was very enthusiastic in its recommendations. I would like to quote a few of them:
Our investigation has shown that a significant world-wide market exists for competitively priced good quality wool products, efficiently produced in Australia-

In intermediate wool products the available markets exceed 65,000 tonnes. A small further market of 3,000 tonnes in garments is possible. The annual revenue from achieving these targets would be of the order of A$1,000 million
Analysis shows that tops at 46,000 tonnes, fine wool yarn 11,000 tonnes and fabric 8,000 tonnes are the most appropriate volume products.
Worsted products would comprise 10,000 tonnes of the yarn total and 6,000 tonnes of the fabric.
The industry has a nucleus of good people but suffers from a shortage of skills at all levels.
The Government should have been bringing in those skills. The report continues:
Although faced with very real problems of restrictive work practices, R.S.I.-
and I add, `kangaroo paw' because no other country has it-
and the other labour difficulties facing the industry, management is not in despair of its ability to overcome them.

The international company which prepared the report for this Government says that we have real problems with restrictive work practices. What an indictment of this Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tells us that we must become the clever country. For his credibility's sake he has to allow industry to become clever; he has to go down the path of our industrial relations policy; he must fix our waterfronts; he must fix those restrictive trade practices; he has to fix up the unions and, if he does not, then all blame will be laid at his feet for the condition that competitiveness and our wool industry is presently in.

No wonder the Industry Commission has had only two expressions of interest and both fell through. This was, firstly, because of the present economic standards in this country. International investors are saying that they cannot cope with our present situation; they cannot cope with the union movement and its work practices; they cannot cope with the fact that they cannot get their goods sent internationally at competitive prices as occurs in other countries whose wharves work in an efficient and competitive manner. We note that the woolgrowers problems are not just because of the industry but because of this Government's handling of the economy.

Many people have come to me-I know that they have also gone to the Australian Labor Party-and said, `I had planned my expansion with ultimate conservativeness and detail but I could not cope and never foresaw the fact that the Government would deliberately, to cause a recession, double the rate of interest rates, and that is the thing that killed me. I could have coped with the doubling of interest rates for a couple of weeks, but I could not cope with it for years'. If Mr Hawke, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Mr Kerin cannot cope and fix this situation, then they should get out now and let someone cope who can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nothing short of a national tragedy that we are debating special legislation aimed at rescuing Australia's wool industry for the third time in less than nine months. Let there be no mistake, it is a tragedy for our farmers, a tragedy for the wool industry, and indeed a tragedy for the whole of Australia. Although technically this legislation only suspends the operations of the reserve price scheme for wool, in reality it represents the funeral service for a scheme which, until recently, has served the industry very well, but which is now buried under a mountain of wool having been killed by two groups of politicians: those in this Hawke Labor Government and those agri-politicians in positions of leadership in the Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: As a farmer's son who continues to have a proprietal interest in farming and as one who has strongly supported the reserve price scheme since its inception, I find great sadness in having to pronounce the scheme dead. But the sad reality is that the mismanagement of the scheme has been so bad in recent years that any hope of its resurrection is entirely forlorn. That is why the Liberal and National parties have moved an amendment to terminate rather than to suspend the scheme. Unlike the Government, the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation, we are prepared to tell growers the truth and to face reality. It is not in their interests to be left in false hope for the future, as the Government and industry leaders have left them in the past, which may cause them to make more wrong decisions.

Undoubtedly the downturn in the international textile industry reduced the demand for all fibres in recent years, including wool. Undoubtedly the political and economic changes in Russia, China, and eastern Europe had a significant and detrimental impact. But, equally undoubtedly, it was the decisions taken by this Government and the industry's leaders over the past three to four years which have, in large measure, prevented wool maintaining its market share among fibres; which have encouraged overproduction; and which have resulted in a mountainous stockpile of wool, now approaching some five million bales, leaving a massive burden of a $2.9 billion debt as a millstone around the collective necks of woolgrowers, in addition to any individual debt which they may have which is escalating in this rural recession.

It is not the fault of average woolgrowers that this crisis has emerged-except in the extent to which they trusted this Government and trusted industry leaders. Growers were treated like mushrooms by their leaders, as indeed were the Opposition, and kept completely in the dark as to the extent of the crisis developing in the industry. Relevant facts and figures were not given to growers to enable rational decisions to be made. Furthermore, the mismanagement of the reserve price scheme in recent years muted the market signals which growers should have been receiving about supply and demand. It is therefore understandable that they are now confused and angry.

Nor does this responsibility for the disaster lie with the Opposition, with the Liberal and National parties. Indeed, the Opposition has behaved with utmost responsibility in seeking solutions which are in the long term interests of the industry ever since its problems began to emerge.

Need I remind the Senate that as long ago as August 1989 I drew the attention of the Government to the developing problems in the wool market as evidenced by the massive increases in wool purchases by the Wool Corporation during the previous three months. Minister Button at the time ignored the warning, treating my question in cavalier fashion and confidently asserting that a sellers market would soon reemerge-some sellers market that we have seen re-emerge! So much for this Government's professions of concern now-some 18 months later-about the disastrous situation for woolgrowers.

In contrast, the Opposition has sought to make decisions on a rational and informed basis. As the problems emerged 12 months ago, we found this difficult because it was difficult to extract much information from either the Wool Council or the Wool Corporation. Information that was forthcoming sometimes changed. Figures forwarded to us by the Corporation during that period were unconvincing in many respects and raised many questions. Time and subsequent events have proved our scepticism to be well founded. Therefore, on the basis of its recent performance, it ill becomes the Wool Council to criticise the Opposition, as it has during the last 24 to 36 hours, for our responsible attitude to the legislation now being debated.

In the light of the Wool Council's inadequate performance in looking after the interests of woolgrowers in recent years, attempts to deflect criticism by striking out at the Opposition are perhaps understandable; but its attitude is irrational and unacceptable. The threat of the Council to campaign against the coalition will not deter us from our responsible approach and our determination to act in the interests of woolgrowers by, in particular, preventing the accumulation of a debt which could bankrupt them all. It is high time the Council did likewise instead of seeking to shore up its position in agro-politics in the light of its past mistakes. There can be no doubt that the Wool Council shares a major part of the responsibility for the demise of the reserve price scheme by advocating, several years ago, a major change in its function from a safety net provision to a price setting mechanism.

As I will detail in a few moments, the New South Wales Farmers Federation perhaps bears even more responsibility for the decisions of several years ago which have destroyed the scheme. The attitude it is now expressing towards the coalition is laughable when placed in that context.

Wool has long been a mainstay of Australia's export industries. There have always been ups and downs experienced in supply and demand and, consequently, in prices and profits in the industry. When the reserve price scheme for wool was first introduced in 1972, its purpose was to even out these ups and downs. Price stability and predictability were beneficial to both growers and users in an industry of cyclical production and fluctuating markets.

Most importantly, the reserve price was set at a conservative rate in relation to the market price for wool. The scheme was not introduced to encourage growers to produce wool excess to demand or to compensate them for their costs or for them to derive more income if that could not be justified by market demand. Its simple purpose was to even out the peaks and troughs. It should be pointed out that this was at a time of fixed and predictable exchange rates, stable markets and growing consumer demand. So the system worked well for almost 15 years.

But in 1987 the demand for wool began to outstrip supply and prices began to rise dramatically. By the end of June 1988 the market price had soared to more than 1100c per kilogram. New South Wales growers, in particular, and quite acceptably, massively increased wool production over the three year period from 1987 by more than 40 per cent to meet this demand. It was inevitable that when supply and demand became better balanced, prices would fall to a more moderate level. Indeed, if this was not to occur, then it was equally inevitable that demand would fall because synthetics would replace wool if the price ratio of wool to synthetics remained for long at an unsustainable 5 : 1 or 6 : 1 compared with the long term average of 3 : 1. Therefore, what was not acceptable was for New South Wales wool industry leaders, through the then New South Wales Farmers Association, now the New South Wales Farmers Federation, to vocally advocate substantial rises in the reserve price and, more importantly, to succeed in that advocacy against the warnings of wiser heads, including from my own State of South Australia.

Even more culpable, with its Australia-wide responsibility to growers, was the Wool Council for acquiescing in these demands. A reserve price as high as 900c per kilogram was demanded. In calling for such a high floor price, which was based on the sales results of a mere 35 per cent of a single year's wool clip-about 2 per cent of sales for the previous 15 years-the opportunists were, wittingly or unwittingly, changing the nature of the reserve price scheme from being a safety net for growers to being a price setter.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good analysis.

—I welcome the agreement of Senator Tate to those comments. These people also ignored the warnings expressed by some economists, agricultural journalists and even the then Chairman and Director of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr David Asimus, and Mr David Moore, respectively, of the detrimental long term consequences of such a move. Mr Moore and Mr Asimus both favoured a more conservative approach to the floor price. They feared that a sustained high price for wool would drive users away from wool and into other-cheaper-fibres. Compounding this was the problem of the floating exchange rate and the upward movement of the Australian dollar, which had the effect of increasing the real price for wool to overseas buyers, thus frightening them off even more.

SPEECH.PARA: Countries such as the Soviet Union and China, especially, would soon find such high prices unaffordable in the circumstances of major changes in their own economies. This is exactly what happened. The major problem foreseen was that with production already growing at 3 to 4 per cent a year by then it was likely to increase more with high guaranteed prices as distinct from high market prices, attracting other players into the game. This would eventually result in supply outstripping demand, making it impossible to maintain high market prices. One prominent rural writer, Julian Cribb, wrote the following in the Australian on 28 May 1988:
Six weeks ago the New South Wales Farmers' Association handed the wool industry a loaded gun. The next month will reveal whether the industry uses it to blow its own brains out.

That is exactly what happened. By acquiescing to the ill-informed New South Wales demands and setting the floor price for the 1988-89 selling season at 870c a kilogram, the Australian Wool Council and the Wool Corporation of Australia ensured, as Mr Cribb and others predicted, the destruction of the wool marketing scheme, a blow-out in the national debt and the ruination of thousands of woolgrowers. This decision represented a massive 70 per cent increase in the floor price in just two years and introduced a fundamental change to the nature of the scheme from a bad times insurance policy to an attempt to rig the market.

The wool industry not only blew its brains out-it nearly buried itself. Had a more moderate reserve been maintained, we would not be presiding over its demise now. Growers would still have received higher prices while demand exceeded supply. But in the absence of a continuing guarantee of high prices through an excessively high reserve, fewer new entrants would have been attracted to the industry and the situation would not have seesawed to supply exceeding demand so dramatically. It would have been much riskier for new entrants to rely on the continuation of high market prices. Hence a better balance would have been maintained between supply and demand with consequently better price stability.

Let me reinforce that it is not the wool industry leaders alone who bear the responsibility for the present chaos. That responsibility lies even more heavily with this Hawke-Labor Government which created the circumstances for the chaos to develop, including significant changes in 1987 to the legislation governing the scheme. Indeed, it is only since those amendments, introduced by Minister Kerin, have operated that the previously healthy scheme has gone awry. The Minister changed the requirement for consultation with Treasury, removed ministerial control over the setting of the floor price and, most importantly, removed the requirement that the comparability of wool price with that of other fibres be taken as a criterion in determining the floor price. It was these changes by Minister Kerin that paved the way for the floor price to be set at an unsustainably high level.

The Government's failure to reintroduce income equalisation deposits for a year after their reintroduction was announced encouraged some woolgrowers to initially hold their wool off the market, thereby reducing supplies in a period of high demand and contributing to the rapid rise in wool prices. When the income equalisation deposits came into operation, those growers put that wool on the market in addition to the subsequent clip, increasing supply at a time when some wool users had moved to other fibres as a result of the earlier shortage and high prices.

The Government's high interest rates have detrimentally affected the production costs of woolgrowers and also kept the Australian dollar at an unjustifiably high level; hence the price of our wool has been too high in foreign currency terms. High interest rates have also dramatically increased the cost to the Wool Corporation and therefore to growers of holding the wool stockpile. The statements of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) early last year encouraged speculation about the reserve price at a time when buyers were returning to the market and hence encouraged them to sit out and wait to see what happened. Let there be no doubt that this Government has contributed significantly to the current crisis. The Government also broke its promise, made in 1987, concerning wool promotion funding when it cut its funding from the promised 1.2 per cent of the gross value of production to a flat $25m per year.

Despite the litany of justifiable criticism which can be levelled at the Government, one searches in vain in the Minister's second reading speech on this legislation for any acknowledgment of his responsibility for the current situation. Yet the Minister further contributed to the climate of uncertainty by lowering the floor price to 700c, travelling the world declaring that inviolate and then suspending the reserve price until 30 June. This dithering by this incompetent Minister must cease. He should have the guts to acknowledge that the Opposition has shown true leadership by coming to grips with the problems of the industry and accept the amendments we are proposing to this legislation. The present uncertainty will continue until the end of June without any improvement in confidence if this legislation passes in its present form.

The Minister is responsible for the discrediting of the reserve price scheme. With a wool stockpile of some 4.8 million bales in the hands of the Wool Corporation and with an enormous debt of $2.9m, it simply cannot be resurrected, even in modified form. Growers will have a continuing interest burden of $400m a year from that debt alone. In the light of that and the extra borrowings that would be required to maintain the floor price, albeit at a lower level, a wool tax levy of 50 per cent would by no means be out of the question. There would also be the imposition of quotas, as previously foreshadowed, to manage supply. I am in no doubt that before too long, if not immediately on the resumption of sales, the net return to growers from market prices will be better than achievable from a quota-managed, levy-funded reserve price scheme.

A high levy and wool quotas would be especially unfair to South Australian woolgrowers, who have not contributed to the oversupply situation. The growth in the sheep flock and the subsequent growth in production, which has detrimentally affected the balance between supply and demand, occurred most noticeably in New South Wales and Queensland. In the 10 years from 1980-81 to 1989-90, the increase in wool production in the whole of Australia was 56.75 per cent. However, in Queensland the increase for the same period was a massive 88.82 per cent and in New South Wales it was 80.51 per cent. In Victoria it was 52 per cent; in Western Australia, 41.46 per cent; in Tasmania, 32.34 per cent; while at the bottom comes South Australia, with only a 26.07 per cent increase in production over that 10-year period.

Hence South Australian growers' levies have been used to fund the purchase of wool by the Wool Corporation at the reserve price of the excess in supply created by New South Wales and Queensland woolgrowers. They were the growers who, as I mentioned earlier, were the most vocal-particularly in the case of New South Wales-and therefore most responsible for the initiation of the unsustainably high reserve price.
