Furthermore, because South Australian growers have only marginally increased production compared with earlier years, determining quotas on the basis of 1989-90 production, as was intended had the reserve price scheme continued and quotas been introduced, would have been grossly unfair to South Australian producers. Compared with New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria, where production last year, as those percentages show, was well above earlier years, South Australians would have been treated unfairly. So long as the possibility of any attempt to revive the floor price scheme remains, the probability of continuing high levies and the associated unfairness to South Australia will remain.

That is another strong reason for supporting the Opposition amendment, which confirms the end rather than merely the suspension of the floor price scheme. The Opposition strongly supports the concept of a supplementary payments scheme as initiated by this legislation to provide some fairness to growers who have not yet sold their wool this season and so between now and the end of June will face the open market without the shield of a reserve price. However, an open-ended scheme funded mainly from the growers' levy is not on. Firstly, growers must have an incentive to put their own reserve on their wool, and buyers some incentive not to drive the market down, because both can act safe in the knowledge that deficiency payments will make up the difference to the former reserve price. Secondly, and as a consequence of this, growers cannot fund through their levies unlimited borrowings to meet the deficiency payments.

The additional interest on a further $500m to $700m in borrowings is not the only consideration. There is also the future requirement to fund that debt from the existing wool stockpile and other assets of the Corporation. That is, the additional borrowings which may be required to fund an open-ended supplementary payments scheme will not create additional assets which can later be liquidated to repay the debt in the way it is hoped the sale of the existing stockpile of wool and other assets will eventually allow repayment of the current $2.9m debt.

A possible call on growers to provide between them a further $500m to $700m in capital to repay this additional debt cannot be countenanced. Many growers simply do not have the financial resources to do this in the foreseeable future, if ever. The requirement to do so would bankrupt them. That is why we seek to amend this Bill to limit to $200m the amount for which growers will be liable to contribute to deficiency payments. We support the provision of $300m from Government funds to make these payments. After all, this Government has ripped at least that much from the pockets of the woolgrowing taxpayers by abandoning and then delaying the re-introduction of income equalisation deposits. However, beyond that funding, the Corporation must raise funds for deficiency payments by reducing its operating costs to free up funds or by selling some of its assets. Apart from protecting growers from debt, this will also put the Corporation's operations under some financial discipline.

Another important element to be considered in relation to restoring confidence in the industry is the management of the wool stockpile. With a huge stockpile of nearly five million bales of wool sitting in the warehouse, there is obviously nervousness and uncertainty among buyers about its effect on prices should it suddenly be released. The stockpile must be reduced to ease the woolgrowers' massive debt but it must be sold off in an orderly way so it does not adversely affect prices on the open market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Walters for her agreement. To ensure that there is an orderly sale of the wool stockpile, there should be a freeze on it for 12 months, with the exception of limited sales for certain contractual purposes and special categories, to give the industry time to settle down and restore confidence in the market. There should be further legislation after 12 months to ensure well-regulated and well-publicised releases of the stocks. Because correct management is so important, our amendment requires that it be controlled by legislation rather than by regulation for a period of 12 months commencing from the beginning of the sales next week. We believe that the guidelines for management of the stockpile should be set now, well before the sales start, rather than waiting for the Minister to issue them in his own time; nor should they be subject to change by the Minister whenever he feels like it.

SPEECH.PARA: Our final amendment seeks to amend the powers of the Minister in relation to this legislation. In this legislation-which the Minister himself has admitted was hastily drafted-the Minister already has regulatory power in proposed new section 148, which is standard for this type of legislation, but he seeks additional power to amend `any provisions of this Act other than this part'. This gives the Minister the power to overrule any part of the legislation, and indeed makes a mockery of the whole Bill. If the Minister wants the power to impose penalties on those who abuse the scheme, as he has claimed, the legislation should spell that out quite clearly.

Our amendments will vastly improve what is, in its present form, grossly inadequate legislation for offering solutions to the wool industry's present difficulties. However, more is required to restore the balance between supply and demand. As long as the national sheep flock remains at its present high level, supply will exceed demand for the foreseeable future and this will continue to depress prices. Average market demand for our wool through the 1980s was of the order of 700 kilotonnes, and that was with Russia and China in the market as significant buyers. But current production exceeds 1,000 kilo- tonnes. Abolition of the reserve price alone will not sufficiently quickly get rid of this imbalance. That is why I have been, and continue to be, a strong advocate for a commercially based flock reduction scheme.

Despite all the factors contributing to the demise of the reserve price scheme, if an effective flock reduction scheme had been established when I first urged it last year, the scheme may have survived. We needed to get rid of 30 to 40 million sheep at that time. The Government and the Wool Corporation both ignored this requirement. But, belatedly, the Corporation introduced a very limited scheme offering $1.80 for old sheep, and $6-and then later $5-for young sheep. As inadequate as that scheme was, it has already resulted in the slaughter of some 8 1/2 million sheep and it is expected that about 10 million will eventually disappear at an average cost of $3.70 per head.

If that half-baked scheme has achieved such success, I am confident that a commercially realistic scheme offering growers $8 to $10 a head would succeed in reducing the flock by another 20 to 30 million sheep. But instead of urging this necessity on the Wool Corporation, this ill-informed Government is initiating a scaling down of the existing scheme, according to the Minister's second reading speech. The Government should be seriously considering the provision of additional funds to the industry for a commercial slaughter scheme rather than initiating a scaling down of the current scheme funded by woolgrowers themselves.

The advantage of funding a slaughter scheme is that, to the extent it works, it will have a major impact on reducing supply. To the extent that it does not attract sheep for slaughter, it does not cost anything anyway. The Government must take this initiative if it is fair dinkum about assisting the industry to solve its problems.

Initiatives are also required to increase the demand for wool. It is not enough to sit and wait for the market to improve simply as a result of a price which is market determined. More active marketing and promotion are required. It is the Liberal and National parties which again have taken the lead in this regard. Both coalition parties sent separate delegations to China last year and I was part of the Liberal delegation there in November. That delegation covered a range of issues but, in particular, we concentrated upon ways of encouraging the Chinese back into the wool market.

We were ridiculed by the Government for going to China but when we got there we had the opportunity to speak with Ministers, officials, Chinese technicians, representatives of Chinese woollen mills and the like. These were initiatives which we took well in advance of the Government but they were ridiculed by the Government. However, ultimately the Government realised that it would have to follow suit. The Opposition did a great deal to try to encourage the Chinese and the Soviets to return to the market.

In May of last year, the Opposition called for changes to the insurance scheme for wool exporters to the Soviet Union and again, at that time, the Government ridiculed that call. Later, the Opposition proposed a range of credit arrangements and counter-trade arrangements, which we believed would help redevelop demand for Australian wool in the Soviet Union. The Government finally adopted policies similar to those which the Opposition had previously been advocating. If only the Government had acted earlier and in time, it would have done something to stimulate the demand for wool in the Soviet Union and again perhaps prevented the demise of this scheme. The Government stands condemned for sitting on its hands and doing so little when the Opposition has been calling for so much to be done.

Finally, to assist growers through these extremely difficult times, there must be increased funding for rural adjustment and rural counselling. The Government must also get on, as Senator Walters said earlier, with all the reforms to our economic structure in which it has thus far failed so dismally. Need I again mention the labour market, the waterfront, transport, tariffs and fiscal policy. We will await with interest the Government's much heralded industry statement in a couple of weeks time. There can be no doubt about the coalition's commitment. We have taken the lead on these general issues, as we have indeed on the wool industry's specific problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Bill 1991. In June last year when legislation to alter the wool tax was before the Senate, I stated that what the industry needed was certainty. With the disastrous collapse of the reserve price that this Bill, in effect, has to bury, the need for certainty and confidence is more vital than ever.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition is firmly of the view that change is inevitable and that this Parliament has a responsibility to play its role in assisting a vital and efficient rural industry to survive the difficult transition to the free market sale of wool. More and more growers, whatever their past support for the reserve price, now realise that the scheme ceased to have a future when this year wool sales were suspended for three weeks. I strongly support them in the view that the sooner we start selling wool in the free market and discover just what price Australian wool commands, the sooner we will start back on the road to success.

It is essential, therefore, that we remove any degree of ambiguity about the longer term fate of the reserve price by supporting the coalition's amendment to actually terminate it. Confidence in the reserve price has been shattered and the last thing that growers now need is any uncertainty or false hope that it can be revived. It is a shame that there have been a few growers who simply do not seem to be able to agree among themselves about the best option. These growers have not been able to agree with the Wool Council of Australia; the Wool Council has not been able to agree with them; and the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) has not been able to agree with either. In general, many of those things have interfered with achieving a more timely solution.

While I support a free market solution on the grounds of both necessity and long term viability, this Government cannot expect growers to make this transition unaided. A $300m contribution to deficiency payments until July does not begin to solve the problem of the wool stockpile. It is the view of a great many woolgrowers in my State of Western Australia that the stockpile must be quarantined for 12 months and then sold in an orderly manner. Again, this is the policy of the coalition and we do agree with the position of the growers.

It must be emphasised that while this Government has taken the only possible course of action in abandoning the reserve price and getting sales under way, it has not gone anywhere near solving the debt problem that continues to burden growers and threaten recovery. It is a great shame that Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) did not take a greater initiative much earlier and has allowed the woolgrowers to live a life of uncertainty for far too long.

We have a situation where the debt per bale reached $500 and where the wool tax will remain at 25 per cent for the remainder of the season. We cannot expect growers to remain viable when they are receiving a far lower, if accurate, price and paying a high level of wool tax. At the very least, if the Government is not prepared to take over the debt and the stockpile, there needs to be an assurance that the debt will not grow even larger. This, however, is exactly the prospect that faces growers when the cost of the deficiency payments for the remainder of the 1990-91 season is estimated at $800m, of which only $300m will be supplied by the Government. That means, of course, a further debt of $500m. The end result will be to drive growers out of business and it will rebound on general taxpayers in meeting the consequences of a collapsing wool industry.

The coalition aims to arrest this prospect of as much as a further $1 billion in Australian Wool Corporation debt by limiting additional borrowings to $200 billion. This discipline, I believe, is essential to alleviate the threat of continuing, uncontrolled levels of the wool tax. There is no value today in indulging in long recriminations against the AWC. However, it must be stated that growers tell me that they do not wish to continue with this present management in its current form. Growers, in the long term, will support an organisation with responsibility for research and promotion, but see no future for the AWC as a marketing organisation.

As my colleagues Senator Walters and Senator Chapman have already stated quite clearly here today, if there is one thing that the industry needs, it is greater marketing and promotion. The number of people who are buying wool and buying woollen products is declining constantly and we have to turn that around. The AWC has done absolutely nothing about doing so. If, by attacking the coalition, the AWC thinks that it has had in the past and will get in the future a better deal out of the Labor Government, I suggest that it should look at history and think again, because this Government has sought the demise of the whole rural sector. Not just woolgrowers, but the whole farming sector has been on a downward slide for years now, and this is but part of that slide. If the AWC is going to run campaigns against us because we are not going to acquiesce in what it wants-and we are doing what the growers want-I suggest that it think again.

The coalition makes absolutely no apology for a consistent opposition to quotas since they were first put forward in November. This proposal has been crucial in damaging the credibility of the AWC, of the reserve price scheme and of the Minister in entertaining the idea until reality imposed its own solution. Our only consideration in the coalition is: what is going to be best for the woolgrowers and what is going to be best for the marketplace? That is the bottom line-the be-all and end-all. The sooner the AWC understands that, the better off we will all be. Quotas posed an administrative nightmare and considerable problems of equity, particularly since Western Australian growers were not generally responsible for massive production increases that would have formed the basis for quota allocation.

The combination of a 60 per cent quota and a 40 per cent wool tax necessary to sustain the reserve price was a simple recipe for disaster. We would have done everything possible to prevent the passing of quota legislation, and I am glad to think that this intention has assisted in preventing its introduction.

Throughout the course of debate on the future of the wool industry it is too easily forgotten that wool has only 5 per cent of the world fibre market. Australia must make the world want to buy and use our wool before we can demand the price we might like. It is all very well to have pipedreams and to think that this price would be wonderful or that price would be even better but, if we cannot achieve either, there is no point in crystal ball gazing and having those pipedreams. We have to achieve what is possible. The art of the impossible is just not a consideration. There is no law of necessity that will compel buyers to return if we withhold supply.

The most important signal that we can give the outside world is that we want to sell wool. It was not the least of the faults of the quota scheme that it would have deprived us of the signals of the marketplace, apart from creating on-farm secondary stockpiles. Australia survived a free market in wool for many decades before the reserve price was introduced. We cannot blame growers for overproduction when we insulate them from the ultimate knowledge of the world market price. As has already been stated today, the whole situation seems to have been kept under wraps for too long. There was not enough discussion about it early enough in the piece. There were no decisions made that could have turned this situation around before it got out of hand, and the blanket-pardon the pun-that has been thrown over a lot of the detail is something that the AWC, again, has much to answer for.

Neither is it the fault of woolgrowers that the AWC fatally compromised the reserve price by raising it to levels that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics warned were unsustainable based on demand patterns. I strongly endorse the comments made in November by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, that the AWC chose to ignore the accurate information that was available to it. That is all the more reason why today the least impediment should be placed on market signals. Now that the reserve price scheme has failed, we need to look forward to an era in which there is no central wool stockholder, for that not only encouraged overproduction against market signals, but has, through earlier stockpiles, dampened returning demand, preventing growers from getting the appropriate signals that production can be increased.

Therefore, in order for an honest market to operate in the best interests of growers and the national economy, there is a need for a far greater commitment to action than this Government has yet shown. The existing stockpile must be quarantined and then sold as soon as possible in an orderly manner-never to return. I repeat: the stockpile cannot be dismissed as a problem for the AWC or for the wool industry. This Parliament put in place the legislation that made it possible and, quite frankly, we cannot ignore the consequences. Ultimately, the only levies that woolgrowers should pay must involve wool promotion and not its withdrawal from the market at subsidised prices. Woolgrowers cannot afford to be paying out money and getting nothing in return. It is the task of the Government to move towards this situation as soon as possible.

While we must avoid creating dependency cycles in rural industries that have proved their efficiency in the international marketplace, government must be prepared to play a necessary role in assisting the wool industry in its transition. We cannot afford to downplay the extent of the crisis that threatens our entire rural economy at the moment. This is very much an integral part of it.

Our world economy depends on a viable wool market, and let us not forget it. I state this with particular feeling, since by last November farm product prices in Western Australia had fallen by 18 per cent in 12 months, above the national average drop of 13 per cent. Prices for sheep led the fall with a 60 per cent drop. The only figures that we have to date are still the September quarter figures. They show a 7.5 per cent fall in the value of farm production and an 80 per cent fall in income from unincorporated farm enterprises-in other words, the family farm. The rise in the wool tax from 18 per cent to 25 per cent did not occur until October and does not register in the September quarter figures. One can only guess what the December quarter figures will be like. They will be absolutely horrendous.

We are looking at a decline in average woolgrower farm cash operating surpluses from $52,300 in 1989-90 to $9,500 in 1990-91, and a projected negative income of $3,700 in 1991-92. Sharp cycles have occurred before in rural industries, and it is inevitable that some producers will leave the industry. In the broader perspective, this country simply cannot afford those types of reductions. We have a country in a recession-if not a depression-at the moment and here we have yet another industry going to the wall. Unfortunately, in this industry it takes not only a person but the entire family history with it. We must be mindful that it affects not just the people on the land, sad as that is; it affects so many other people in a broader context. The figures that I have quoted and other indications point to something far worse than a shake-out.

Australians expect sensible action by this Parliament to ensure that we continue to have a wool industry, and not another huge addition to the social security bill. They expect a solution that will lead to reliance on the basic laws of supply and demand. This is what the coalition advocates in the necessary passage of this Bill and in the amendments and further action that we propose. We have not taken the decisions lightly with our amendments and we consider that they are in the best interest of the industry generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few weeks we have seen suspension of the wool sales and of the reserve price scheme. These have been major shocks and areas of concern to the woolgrowers across Australia. In listening to contributions made by members of all parties, I find that there is much with which I can agree. However, I cannot agree with the Liberal Party's amendments and part of the National Party's amendments and final conclusions. They are offering a panacea, immediate abolition of the reserve price, but they have not followed that through to tell us what it means in real terms. Senator Knowles just alluded to it when she said that it would remove the marketing powers of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC). But the big question that has to be answered is: who will be responsible for the stockpile and for future wool that will be sold when sales resume shortly? The Opposition has not answered that question and it is consequential upon the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: If Opposition members wish to remove the marketing powers, they are not saying who will be responsible for marketing, or what will happen to the staff in the AWC who are responsible for marketing. They presume that the Government will take over the debt. That is something that even Opposition members with their hard-nosed, dry market policies would not agree to take over. They want total government management of the stockpile. They allege that this Government has not outlined what will happen with the stockpile, and on that point I vehemently disagree with them.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has outlined what will be happening with the stockpile. The AWC has announced, with the concurrence of the Minister, that stockpile management rules will apply for the rest of the year. All sales from the stockpile in Australia will cease on 25 February. Sales from the stockpile in Europe can continue until 25 March in small quantities for inventory adjustment purposes, but at no less than 700c floor price. The only exception for contracts entered into by the AWC before 25 February is for wool to meet the technical requirements of International Wool Secretariat developmental projects. Opposition members have failed to say what they would do if the stockpile is frozen. What will they do if there is market need for a very specialist line of fleece or tops and it happens to be in the stockpile? Opposition members are saying that they would not allow that to be disposed of.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand what freezing the stockpile means, obviously.

—The Opposition would abolish the reserve floor price immediately. Most farmers to whom I speak are opposed to abolition of the floor price, but they recognise that the supply and demand position is such that something has to be done. Traditional wool farmers I have spoken to have been critical of many people, and in particular of the Australian Wool Council. Last night I spoke with a farmer who retired about six years ago, and he said that when he left his property the price to the wool producer was about 400c a kilo. My understanding of the wool reserve price was that it was a safety net. That safety net has been removed and it became a price setter, as Senator Chapman outlined earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition amendments are designed to end the reserve price. It is interesting to note that there is some disagreement amongst the members of the National Party. The `old-style' members of the National Party, as I would call them, are the people who were supportive of the National Party's efforts in 1969 and 1970 when it fought the Liberal Party to try to get some stability into the wool industry. Honourable senators come in here and talk about how wonderful things were prior to the introduction of the wool reserve price. That is a load of rubbish.

In 1969, 1970 and 1971, the farmers of this country were going through problems of having absolutely no market, or no price, through a variety of causes. In 1971, we saw headlines threatening that, if the wool reserve price was not 40c a kilo, the Country Party, as it was then called, would break the coalition. What do those people have to say today? Even after the Liberals in the coalition agreed to the reserve price in 1971, a significant number of Ministers were still opposed to the reserve price and still wanted market forces to remain. In those days, I might add, the Liberal Party thought it was fine for woolgrowers to receive 36c a kilo for their wool. Fortunately, it is slightly higher than that now.

In 1970, the disagreements between the Liberal and National parties were referred to as `the fighting season'. It strikes me that the disagreements are still out there. Those who would support the National Party are still disagreeing most vehemently with what the Liberal Party is foisting upon the National Party. The Liberals criticised the wool selling plan; there is nothing new in that. They deferred it for two to three years. It is not a new issue for the coalition to discuss the wool reserve price and support for that market.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a real issue for you to be debating it, because you do not know anything about it.

—Senator Knowles knows little of my family background in wool; nor, I suspect, does she care. I lived on the family farm and in 1969 and 1970 my brother had to go and drive a truck because the income level was so low that families could not exist. So the honourable senator should not tell me that I do not understand the problems of the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: With the termination of the reserve price in this Bill, we are not looking at abolishing future reserve price schemes; we are providing guidelines for where to go in the future. We are saying that a reserve price would have to be self-funding and the floor would have to be conservatively set. I do not know any farmers who would disagree with that.

I have dealt with the consequences of the Opposition amendments and I have mentioned the guidelines in relation to the stockpile. We have also had restrictions on the supplementary payment scheme to $200m. What that, in effect, means is that farmers would be receiving $65 a bale less under some of the Opposition's proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —It means mortgaging our children. That's what it means.

—It means $65 a bale less for those people who have to sell their wool before 30 June. The Opposition has also come up with some costings, but it has not looked at the full implications of those costings. It has not been prepared to be honest about its alternatives. It has told us that it will suspend and freeze things, but it has not told us what its proposals would in fact do. To those who have been criticised by the Australian Wool Council and the New South Wales Farmers Federation, I say: welcome to the club. That is nothing new to the Australian Labor Party: we have argued with and tried to talk economic sense to them. It is now obvious that some people in the Liberal Party are beginning to realise that they have some problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I cite Mr Lloyd's comment that the advice of the Wool Council to both the coalition and the industry in the past has been poor and there is no reason to suppose that the demand to hold up this legislation was any better. I add that the Wool Council should not presume to speak for all farmers. The farmers I meet and deal with often say that they are not members of the New South Wales Farmers Federation. They do not feel that they have been ably represented by members of the Wool Council and wool industry leaders.

That is something which farmers will have to address. They will have to look at involving themselves in the representation on those organisations. With all unions-and I class the Federation as a union-the membership, the representation and the leadership are only as good as the input from their members or those who should be members. That goes for all unions, be they trade unions or industry unions such as the Wool Council and the New South Wales Farmers Federation. The membership of those organisations does not comprise every producer of wool in this country. Therefore, it has to be recognised that they do not represent everybody and should not presume to speak for everybody in the country who produces wool.

The other thing that farmers have said to me-and again it is being critical of the Wool Council and its pressure to have the price of wool increased to 870c a kilo-is that a false market signal was sent to those in farming who move around from industry to industry looking at where they will gain the maximum income. People were encouraged to go into the industry who had not traditionally been in it. The traditional wool farmers are very critical of that. They are very upset by it, and justifiably so, I would suggest. They would like to see whether there is some way of penalising those people more than others, but that would not be very fair.

I also hear comments that not enough is being done in research and development and that not enough is being done in the marketing of Australian wool, even though our merino wool is the best. I hasten to emphasise `our merino wool', because our other wool has to compete with and, I would suggest, is really no better than wool from other countries, but our merino wool is excellent. People are critical that it is very hard to buy in shops in this country. They are critical that the price one has to pay to purchase the finished garment in this country is exorbitant and is in no way commensurate with the costs that they, in fact, have had to outlay or with the price that they have received.

I urge support of the Government's legislation and proposals. This is the way forward. It gives the industry time to think; it gives the industry some guidelines; and it is important that we wait for the Vines committee report. We cannot have an inquiry going on and then, halfway through that inquiry, take the rug out from underneath it and say that it is no longer necessary. This inquiry is important. The results of the inquiry must be used and looked at in developing future plans for the wool industry. By abolishing the reserve price the Opposition would remove one of the possible planks and one of the possible recommendations of the Vines committee. Therefore, it is important that we take some breathing time and do not act hastily. That is what this Government is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rushed into the chamber to deliver what I believe will be a reasonably brief address on this occasion. Perhaps I could take the time of the Senate to give an analogy. What I see is happening to the wool industry is something that happened to me. As it is my personal experience, I hope honourable senators do not find it boring.

SPEECH.PARA: When I left school I commenced my working life as an orchardist in Tasmania. As many people will know, the orcharding industry in Tasmania in the late 1950s was quite a substantial industry. In fact, southern Tasmania was renowned for exporting top quality fruit all over the world and, in particular, to the United Kingdom. This is where I now draw the analogy. For various reasons the industry declined. One reason was marketing problems in the European Economic Community (EEC). When the EEC formed it started flooding the United Kingdom with fruit.

Another reason was the problems in Tasmania on the waterfront. We could guarantee every year when we were picking and packing fruit that there would be a strike in the first week we started to deliver fruit to the wharf. There would not be a strike all year but we could guarantee every time the fruit season started that we would have at least one strike. In addition, the agents were always there to hive off what they thought was a fair percentage of whatever growers got for their fruit. Finally, there were always the shipping lines there to up their prices every year. Eventually it got to the stage where all of a sudden we had surpluses of fruit. We had nowhere to sell it and, of course, we started dumping it. Later on came what was known as the tree pull scheme.

What happened in Tasmania is almost the same as what has happened to the wool industry. The marketing situation fell apart. There was an oversupply because of external reasons. There were the cost problems at home with greedy agents. There were all those other things that were associated with the industry. I always remember my father telling me that the late Sir Henry Jones, who founded that great company H. Jones and Co., which had a very large operation in Hobart, was quoted as saying, `The industry will wake up one morning and find it will be ruined by a parcel of humbugs'. How true that was. That was when the industry was in full flight, when we were canning not only apples and pears but also apricots and nectarines and everything else that one could grow.

I think that particular expression could almost be used to describe what has happened to the wool industry. We have woken up in a very short time and found to some extent that the wool industry has been ruined by a parcel of humbugs. I do not think it is fair to try to pick out one person or one group or one particular reason, because everybody has had a hand in it.

There is no doubt that the Australian Wool Corporation has had a big hand in what has gone on. Its forecasting has been certainly below the mark. I remember very well being briefed by the Wool Corporation people at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference the year before last. I asked them then how many bales they had in stock and they said something like 2.1 million or 2.2 million. I said, `I have it on good authority that you have over three million bales in store'. They denied that, but it turned out a couple of weeks later to be true.

I do not believe the growers themselves-I think other speakers have said this, too-have been kept up to the mark about what has been going on. There, too, I think the growers themselves are a little bit to blame because they have been willing to let this go on and be pushed, not by greed but by profit. They have not queried what has happened with the floor price scheme over the years. It has been explained in far greater detail by better people than me just how that floor price got up to 800c or further and how it all fell apart.

I happened to be watching Graeme Campbell, the member for Kalgoorlie, speaking in quite a lively fashion the other night. I must say that, instead of spreading the load, he was sheeting all the blame home to the Australian Wool Corporation. I do not think he was fair at all about that. He mentioned Minister Kerin once. I thought it was quite unfair to single out the Wool Corporation.

I heard Senator West speak about the price of wool here in Australia. I must say that I personally feel that a few years back perhaps-Senator Button may agree or disagree-a decision should have been made and encouragement should have been given for more processing of our wool here in Australia. I know it can be said that overseas mills are geared up--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, who was the biggest opponent of that in Australia? You know, don't you?

—Yes, that is what I am saying. More people are to blame for this mess we are in than just the Government or the Wool Corporation or the growers. Everybody has to share the blame. But I think the biggest problem we have now, and the major cause of what has happened, is the uncertainty that has been created. I remember very well last year-in September, I think-when Ian Sinclair and I had breakfast in Japan with the Asian manager of the Wool Secretariat. He made a quite telling point. He said, `We in Japan want your wool. In fact, we are looking at increasing our buying this year by some 20 per cent and Korea looks like increasing its buying by about 10 per cent'. But he also said, `I wish you would tell your Prime Minister, your Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and representatives of the woolgrowers in Australia to stop saying that nothing is going to happen, that the price is not going to move, because every time they open their mouths we get suspicious and people do not buy'. I think the uncertainty relating to the floor price scheme and just how much was in the stockpile has had a snowballing effect on the whole industry.

SPEECH.PARA: And what a time in the life of Australia for this to happen. It is not just the wool industry that is in crisis. We have huge problems with our wheat. The surpluses are down 68 per cent this year with an additional 37 per cent next year. On top of that, as I said, the wool industry operating surplus is down 8.2 per cent this year, and a further 139 per cent next year. We do not need to be reminded of the position of the citrus fruit growers. They have been here demonstrating outside Parliament House and complaining about what is going to happen to them. I think the real gross value of the citrus crop will be down 20 per cent this year. The beef industry looks like being down 14 per cent, and the sugar industry is looking at a 15 per cent decline. The tale of woe for the farmers-it is predicted that net farm cash income will fall by about 40 per cent-is something that I think is of great concern to us all, whatever political party we are in.

I think the most telling factor in the rural sector at the moment, unfortunately, is that people have lost faith in the Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). On 31 May, Mr Kerin said, `My clear message to the market is that 700c is immutable. The next time the floor price is changed it will be upward'. Unfortunately, those words will probably haunt him for the rest of his life, just as the words `No child will live in poverty after 1990' will sit with Mr Hawke and `This is the recession we had to have' will sit with Mr Keating.

Mr Kerin followed those words with `The Government's commitment to the 700c per kilo is rock solid'. That is when I think uncertainty started being created. That is when the Japanese became suspicious and stopped buying. And, of course, once they stopped buying, just about everybody else around the world did.

The problem we have now has been well outlined by just about every speaker. The wool industry faces the bleak consequence of a minimum of $2.8 billion of internal debt and the potential exists for that to rise to about $3.5 billion. It will require half a billion dollars a year to service that debt. Currently we have 4.8 million bales of wool in the sheds and what looks like 1.5 to two million bales of annual oversupply. So we have these three problems: too much debt, too much supply and, quite frankly, too much wool.

I must at this stage declare an interest. I am a woolgrower myself, though not a very big one, and I know exactly what the feeling is around my area. It is important to stop uncertainty as much as we can and the main way we can do that is not by messing around talking about the reserve price scheme being suspended but by biting the bullet and completely abolishing it. That is why the coalition is supporting the legislation. The reserve price scheme must go permanently if we are going to have confidence return to the industry. As I said earlier, we are only creating more uncertainty when we say that we are going to suspend the reserve price scheme.

The next issue is the industry debt. We have indicated that we will support the Government's proposal to pay the $300m in supplementary payments. That will make up the shortfall between what the farmers actually get-it is a good question what they will get-and the 700c that they should have got until the end of June. It is a bit of a worry that people are speculating already about what price wool is going to sell for. Some people are saying 375c, but I really do not know how they arrive at that figure. They have never been able to forecast anything before and that is why we are in the mess we are in. This continued speculation about what the price of wool is going to be when the wool sales start is unfortunate.

I do not believe that it is in the interest of woolgrowers that we support a proposal which allows the Wool Corporation open-ended borrowing to augment those supplementary payments. Growers are so far down the tube that we will be saddling our children and our children's children with a debt that is going to take many years to get rid of. The coalition's suggestion of applying a $200m cap on extra borrowing will limit the wool industry's debt to $3 billion. We know what the annual interest rate is going to be, so capping that debt will discipline the market, encourage farmers to exercise restraint and prevent the industry from being forced into extra debt.

As part of the arrangement, again to take that uncertainty out of the market, it is essential that the stockpile be frozen for 12 months. I wish that when all this business started someone had taken a million bales and put them down a mine shaft somewhere and forgotten about them. With the huge debt we have got now, it is an asset we have to retain but, while people have the threat hanging over their heads that that huge stockpile is going to be released, that too creates a lot of uncertainty. So I think it is most important that we spell out to the buyers in the industry that that stockpile has to be frozen.

On the other side of the coin, it is very important in this critical time when farmers are facing ruin that the Government give attention to the provision of additional finance through the rural adjustment and rural counselling schemes. It is not just the wool farmers who are going to suffer; the wheat farmers are too. Even the peanut farmers want to talk to the Government about the problems they have in their industry.

So it seems that, right across the board, Australia in the bush is suffering and suffering very badly. We in the coalition have said for quite some time now that one of the ways to try to improve the market is to reduce the supply. We have been very strong. Whilst it is most unfortunate that we have to reduce our flocks at this point in time-only 10 million, I believe, have been slaughtered-it is pretty evident that a reduction of 40 million sheep is what the industry requires. It is very sad. The electronic media have shown very sad pictures of farmers actually crying as they have to eliminate their sheep. It is something that people who live in the bush become accustomed to.

There is nothing more traumatic than to have to go around shooting sheep after they have been burnt in a bushfire, as I and many other farmers in Tasmania did in 1967. There is nothing more traumatic than to build up a breed of sheep by your own efforts and your own breeding and, at the end of the day, have to go around and shoot 10,000 or 20,000 of them. It takes the heart right out of you when you look at your overdraft as well.

I really feel for what is happening in the bush. It is not going to change very quickly. We as a nation have to come to terms with what is happening. Dr Hewson has said many times that if our agreeing with the Government on actions would make it easier for people we would give the Government bipartisan support. But today we are putting forward amendments that we believe, in this very difficult time, are in the best interests of the woolgrowers. I just hope that the Australian Democrats and the Government take notice of those amendments.

At the other end of the scale, whilst we have that huge supply problem, we also have a lot of market deficiencies. I have been involved for many years-through my association with the Royal Agricultural Society of Tasmania and its shows-with wool fashion parades. I have seen how well they have been presented. In our Bicentenary, we had that wonderful fashion show at the Opera House in Sydney. It cost quite a deal of money. But really we are only trying to convince our own people here in Australia to buy wool. Whilst that is very important, the market share of wool in Australia, the amount of wool we use, is pretty small compared to what goes on around the world.

I have to question the amount of money that the Government and the growers have been pumping into New York, into the International Wool Secretariat. Just how good has it been? Have we got value for money over the years in which it has been trying to promote our wool overseas? I do not think it has done a very good job at all. But whilst the price has been high and farmers have been selling their wool and getting reasonably good incomes, no-one has questioned what has been going on outside of Australia. I just hope that as a result of this crisis we look at not only the Wool Corporation but also the benefits we are getting from the quite huge amounts of money we have been spending overseas on our promotion campaigns.

I know that one of the reasons that the Japanese put forward for an increase in sales this year was the fact that they were following the cotton market. The cotton manufacturers in Japan were promoting a product called `new generation cotton'. They were doing huge promotions on this, almost as big as the promotions the Japanese Government was doing on `import now month' in October. The wool people in Japan were going to follow up with this new generation wool. They believed that by doing that they could increase their sales of 22- and 23-micron wool, which they had not worried about before. That just shows what can happen with a bit of innovation. But that innovation did not come from the International Wool Secretariat, nor did it come from the amount of money that we, as growers, and the Government have been putting into trying to increase our markets overseas. That came from the Japanese industry itself. So I do not believe we have been getting the sort of value for our dollar overseas that we should have.

As it is approaching lunchtime, I will just finish by saying that I think it would be most irresponsible of anybody to try to block the legislation. We certainly will not be doing that. We urge the Senate to support the amendments that have been put forward in good faith by the Opposition.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time being 12.45 p.m., we will proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched the consensus revolution in 1983 we all knew we were in for a series of special relationships with favoured interest groups. But no-one could have guessed the extent to which the Government would forge a political deal with the hierarchy of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to the detriment of not only the rank and file membership but ordinary non-unionised workers who have, over the last decade, voted with their feet and deserted the union movement in droves.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Kemp has performed a valuable service in setting out the extent to which this Government has been prepared to fund the ACTU by a series of round robins which in any corporate sector would have called for universal political condemnation but, having raised it to the art form that it has, the Government has been able to get through largely unscathed to date. As Senator Kemp pointed out in his excellent adjournment speech of 13 February last, in the current financial year--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are getting some intellectual content from him at last, are you?
—I have got some very useful figures here. I would have thought you would benefit from looking at them.
—For you, I mean.

—No. I have got my own contribution to make in this but Senator Button will find that if he puts the two together it is a damning indictment of the way his Government has been prepared to favour its friends. For the current financial year the ACTU has received just under $4m, which in contrast to the latest figures available, those for 1987, shows that the ACTU affiliation fees were a mere $2.5m. In all, since this Government came to office, it has contributed $11.6m to ACTU coffers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let there be no doubt: the ACTU not only has a permanent seat at the Cabinet table; it has a power of veto over the major parts of the reform process which the Government itself knows is so vital if we are to get Australia off the canvas. I am sure that Senator Button read with great anguish this morning the comments of Dr Deeley to the Sydney Institute. ICI, having been held up by this Government as a great example of award restructuring and the productivity progress that this Government has made, ought to be horrified to hear what one of Australia's leading industrialists has had to say because he, in his cry of anguish, made it clear that micro-economic reform has been mere rhetoric. The reason for that, of course, is that it has been nobbled at every opportunity by the ACTU. I do not think that any of us in the real world have any real doubt about that. I suspect Senator Button in his heart of hearts knows that full well but the political will is simply not there to do anything about it.

That is why, under this culture that operates, we have been able to see what I regard as the high-water mark of political chicanery as evidenced by a recent 16-page glossy insert in Cleo magazine. I think it deserves some careful attention because let there be no doubt that this is nothing short of a government subsidy to the ACTU to promote the virtues of union membership, whatever they may be. It is done under the guise of promoting the jobs, education and training (JET) program, which was designed to facilitate the re-entry of unemployed sole parents, mainly women, into the work force. Unfortunately, even this scheme has been very unsuccessful to date with only about 5 per cent of some 250,000 sole parents actually being interested in undertaking this program and, of those, only about 50 per cent have been in what the Government itself would regard as the high priority category. So JET has a big question mark over it.

Senator Richardson has been good enough to tell us, in his recent defences of this outrageous exercise, that indeed the money has not come out of the JET program; it has come out of the Department of Social Security (DSS) advertising budget, which also enables it to promote such things as the JET program. I regard that as mere sophistry, because the fact of the matter is that, whatever pocket it comes out of, the money is purported to be appropriated to appeal to sole parents. However, if we look at where this advertisement has been placed, we see that some $45,000 has gone to pay for a 16-page insert in Cleo magazine. The only sensible reference that one could identify as relating to the JET scheme is a one-page black-and-white advertisement which, according to Cleo magazine itself, retails for just under $6,000 and yet the Department has contributed $45,000 towards the cost of this insert.

My information, and I have not had it contradicted by Senator Richardson in his furious efforts to justify this scheme, is that the total cost of the exercise is $270,000 and of that approximately one-half, or $135,000, has been contributed from the public sector-in other words, from the Department of Community Services and Health, DSS and the Commonwealth Bank. When we look at why the Commonwealth Bank, with all its problems, finds itself contributing to this worthy cause, we find Anna Booth proudly proclaiming that she was instrumental in getting the bank to kick in for this outrageous exercise.

As we know, Anna Booth is simply another Government token appointment to that bank. I say to Senator Reynolds that I do not mean `token' in the sense of `women'; I mean `token' in the sense of `expertise'. She happens to be a board member of the Commonwealth Bank. I would have thought Anna Booth had enough integrity to understand that there must be a million and one better ways of promoting the JET program than by contributing towards an ACTU membership drive-and that is what this is all about.

That money will also go towards the ACTU's sending out of the insert to some 500,000 female workers. So again the JET scheme is to be advertised to the wrong people, and the $45,000 simply represents a reallocation of resources from unemployed sole parents to the ACTU and middle-class employed women. Cleo magazine, as I am sure no-one doubts, caters for young, upwardly mobile working women, not disadvantaged, unemployed sole parents, almost two-thirds of whom are over the age of 30. So one could not imagine a less appropriate vehicle for meeting the proclaimed objectives. I regard it as an absolute disgrace, and I am sure the Australian community will, too.

I would be fascinated to hear from Senator Reynolds or anyone else just what else the Government has done by way of promoting the JET program. If this is the start of a new approach-to somehow get the message out via magazines that are unlikely to be read by unemployed sole parents-then we would like to hear about it, because I would have thought that most of them would not be able to afford the $3.50 cover charge. So, under the guise of catering for a disadvantaged group, what we really have when we strip it away is yet another sordid, grubby political deal which involves a transfer payment from the Government to the union movement so that it can somehow try to pull itself up by its bootstraps rather than addressing the real reasons people are no longer interested in unionism.

Of course, those who are particularly not interested in joining the union movement are working women. They know that the union movement has been ferocious in defending its own privileges, in actively discouraging part time workers, the vast majority of whom are women, and indeed in ensuring that all sorts of barriers to entry and hurdles are put in the way of those who would like to engage in casual or part time activity. So women have absolutely no reason to be grateful to the ACTU, and I suspect the last thing on the mind of any sole parent wanting to enter the work force is to rush off and join the union. What these people want is a decent job, unhassled by the unions, yet they find that the ACTU is putting almost every hurdle it can in their way.

Senator Richardson, showing acute and exquisite sensitivity, had the temerity to write to the Age newspaper purporting to defend this little rort and in the process I thought simply made matters a lot worse. He really did not explain where the funds came from and I suggest that if he has any integrity in this area he ought to come clean, he ought to table the documents and we ought to know whether there was any written request from Martin Ferguson or whether it was just the usual telephone deal. We ought to know whether indeed there was any costing provided to the Department of Social Security before it had its arm twisted to agree to this, whether it was simply an initiative from the Minister, and what the true costs of the exercise are.

I suspect that we may well find that the ACTU, having got its hands on $135,000, got a nice discount deal from Cleo and that the end result is that the public sector is funding the vast proportion of this membership drive. Now if that is the case it is indeed a scandal of even greater proportions than we know to date. So for Senator Richardson to rail in the way that he has, and fulminate about how he has been the victim of low standards of journalism on the part of the Age, is simply a smokescreen designed to disguise the fact that he knows full well that he has been party to a deal that simply cannot see the light of day.

It certainly lends support to all those who might have doubted the words of the ACTU President in his new year's address when he said that the ACTU is part and parcel of the Government of Australia. We know that is a fact in terms of decision making but I do not think many of us thought that that really meant that it got carte blanche whenever it wanted to launch membership drives or any other financial activities. If this is what we are going to see, then the sooner it sees the light of day and the public can make its judgment the better. So I hope, Mr Deputy President, that we are going to have a lot more factual information put on the record, and that we are not simply going to be subjected to Senator Richardson throwing tantrums and trying to discourage journalists from pursuing the matter. I hope what we will see is a proper examination of the cost-benefits analysis of this exercise and I suspect that they are absolutely minimal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will resist the temptation to take up the issue Senator Alston has raised in this place today, but I can assure him that on another occasion I would like to answer some of the things he has said about the Government's commitment to women in the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak this afternoon about an issue affecting Queensland Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. I would like to take the opportunity to commend the announcement by the Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss, that the State Government will legislate for Aboriginal land rights before the end of the year. I think it is appropriate, especially for someone like myself who has been waiting for this announcement for over 25 years, that I should take a short time this afternoon to comment on a few issues related to this announcement.
Many senators will welcome this decision, which highlights the Goss Government's commitment to giving recognition to Aboriginal land claims. In his announcement yesterday Mr Goss emphasised:
They-
that is, Aborigines and Islanders-
don't want the whole box and dice but they want a share. Ultimately that's our best chance as a community to heal this problem and to allow the communities to become self sufficient.

I certainly welcome Mr Goss's statement and I think the emphasis should certainly be on that quote of Aborigines and Islanders wanting a share. They are not making a land grab as is consistently claimed by certain sections of the media and indeed by certain sections of the political and general community. It is predictable, unfortunately, that both the National Party and Liberal Party leaders in Queensland have reacted against this proposal which fails to replicate the new spirit of bipartisanship that has been fostered here in the Federal Parliament by the Minister, Robert Tickner, and indeed the Opposition spokesperson, Michael Wooldridge.

I take this opportunity to commend both of those key spokespersons on trying to get away from the rancour and the level of debate about Aboriginal affairs that were so prevalent when Minister Hand had responsibility, and from that attempt to always blame the victim by blaming Aborigines and Islanders when anything at all went wrong in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It is so good to see that that rancour seems to have gone from the debate here in Federal Parliament. It is a pity that now-on the first occasion that at State level we have the opportunity to see whether that bipartisanship has extended generally throughout the country-it appears that it has not reached Queensland.

Let me examine particularly the arguments of both Russell Cooper and Denver Beanland, the respective leaders of the National and Liberal parties in that State. Russell Cooper said that the legislation would result in a `land grab' and indicated that `no minority group has a right to make massive claims with the majority of Queenslanders disadvantaged'. I would just like to bring to the Senate's attention the fact that Mr Cooper does not seem to have the same conviction about his own National Party leader, Don McDonald, who has extensive land ownership that extends over huge tracts of the State of Queensland. In fact, the Australian Magazine of 26 January lists the McDonald family as No. 7 of Australia's top 10 land holders, owning 29,000 square kilometres, valued at an estimated $55m and including Rutland Plains and Dunbar on Cape York.

I am not arguing against the members of the McDonald family owning that amount of land-that is entirely their business. They have built it up over a period of time. But I find it a little extraordinary that when the McDonald family owns 29,000 square kilometres, or 1.7 per cent of Queensland, Mr Cooper can worry about Aborigines and Islanders, who after all constitute 2 per cent of the population. He will not even keep an open mind about Aboriginal and Islander land rights. We do not know yet what the claims will be. But he will not even keep an open mind about what it might be reasonable for 2 per cent of Queenslanders-that is, Aboriginal and Islander Queenslanders-to have entitlement to after all these years.

It is easy for him to accept the land holdings of McDonald, but it is not so easy for him to apply the same fundamental principle to Aborigines and Islanders. It seems to me to be a clear case of double standards that it is okay for the National Party President to own 1.7 per cent of Queensland when he-apart from his representation of the National Party-represents just one family, yet Mr Cooper rejects a just share of entitlement for Aborigines and Islanders constituting not one family but 2 per cent of the population.

It is not just Mr Cooper; it is also Mr Beanland. He has reacted aggressively, accusing Mr Goss of `selling out the State'. I am sure Michael Wooldridge will be most disappointed that his colleague in Queensland has reacted with the typically hysterical attitude that it is a `land grab' and Aborigines and Islanders want your backyard and mine. That is the level of the debate of the past. We thought that we had got through that very simplistic level of argument. We thought that political leaders could be a little bit mature about debating this issue, but apparently they cannot when it comes to Mr Cooper and Mr Beanland.

I suggest that both Mr Cooper and Mr Beanland show a little consistency by studying the amount of rural land owned by single families or companies, and start giving more temperate leadership by accepting rational debate and negotiation on the proposed land rights legislation. We do not yet know what the claims will be. We do not know what is reasonable and what is realistic, or what impact the legislation will have on Queenslanders. It is a question of restoring some justice to the State's Aborigines and Islanders, and that has to be negotiated in a realistic and rational manner.

Sections of the media also could moderate their response and try to contribute some factual analysis to the debate. For example, this morning's Courier-Mail headline screamed, `Cape Claims of 60m Hectares by Aborigines'. I have checked with both the Minister, Anne Warner, and the Queensland Premier's Department. There are no claims; this is completely inaccurate. Aborigines have not claimed 60 million hectares. What they have done is talk about their concern to have included in negotiations-and I emphasise `negotiations'-areas around Temple Bay and Port Stewart on Cape York. The only thing I could find that gave a very clear indication of the amount of land we might be talking about was a quote in the Cairns Post of 6 December last year:
The State Government may hand over about 2160 hectares of land inside the controversial Cape York property, Silver Plains, to Aboriginals.

That is rather different, I am sure all honourable senators would agree, from this morning's headline which mentions claims on 60 million hectares. No specific claims have been made in writing. Clearly, it is important that land claims be sensitively negotiated. This process will not be assisted by exaggeration and hysteria and I would certainly hope that in the coming months Michael Wooldridge can prevail upon his counterpart in Queensland to return to some form of bipartisanship and some rational debate on this subject.

It is certainly timely that Mr Goss has made this announcement because the tradition of native title faces its final test some time this year, according to an article by David Solomon in the Australian of 23 November last year:
The way has been cleared for the High Court to make fundamental decisions next year-
that is this year-
about the force and effect of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander claims to land under the common law.
The court will determine whether and to what extent traditional native title was extinguished by British colonisation and subsequent legislation.
The question has already been described by three members of the High Court as ``of the greatest importance''.
The issue has to be determined to settle a claim by Mr Eddie Mabo and other leaders of the Murray Island peoples to land on several islands in the Torres Strait.

We do not know what the outcome of that particular case will be, but I think it is rather interesting, and I said so at the time, that in 1985 the Queensland Government attempted to solve the dispute by passing legislation declaring, in effect, that any rights Mr Mabo and other islanders might have enjoyed were abolished with effect from the time the islands were annexed to Queensland in the late nineteenth century. So it would seem that as recently as 1985 there were very clear doubts in terms of the legal issues and I look forward to those legal issues being clarified by the High Court later this year.

Again, I commend the initiative of Mr Goss and I urge all political leaders and sections of the media to demonstrate some leadership and to show a little bipartisanship, a little preparedness to debate and consider these issues rather than rushing in to make accusations of land grabs.
Sitting suspended from 1.10 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform honourable senators that the Prime Minister has appointed the Hon. Robert Tickner as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Mr Tickner will assist the Prime Minister with policy and operational issues of the Aboriginal Reconciliation Council and the reconciliation process. The Minister will also be responsible for administrative matters involving the Aboriginal Reconciliation Unit located in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister confirm that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has approved the use of the displaced timber workers job scheme, established after the introduction of World Heritage listing for the far north's wet tropic rainforests, to employ waterside workers made redundant in the port of Cairns? Will the Minister advise the chamber whether he endorses this appalling rip-off by wharfies who are already being paid, from the taxpayer and industry, up to $200,000 each?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not know whether that has been done.
—It has.

—I am not suggesting it has not, but I do not know whether it has been done because the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories never consulted me on the matter, nor would I expect her to.

ANSWER.PARA: I would imagine that the same sorts of sensible rules would apply to redundancy on the waterfront-not that it has been specifically written into any agreement-as would apply in the Public Service or, indeed, in many other employment areas; that is, after a reasonable period of time elapses, and it is two years, I know, in some places, people, if they are able to go back to work, can do so. The wet tropics would not have any particular relationship to the waterfront. If this is true, there would be nothing to stop people displaced from the waterfront going to seek employment, if they wanted to, in other jobs. I do not see what is wrong with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister-and I remind him that a similar question was asked of Senator Bolkus on redundancy-what is the purpose of paying out taxpayers' money for redundancy, and re-employing those same people using taxpayers' money in another part of the Public Service?

—I will inquire and find out whether this is correct. Could I just say that one of the principal differences may well be that people are required to staff what is going on in the wet tropics, and the distinction I would certainly draw is that they are now no longer required to work on the wharf in Cairns.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of media reports that thousands of Tamil youths have disappeared in the civil war-torn north-east district of Sri Lanka recently after being taken into custody by government security forces? Can the Minister verify the media reports? Does the Minister have any information on the whereabouts of the missing youths? What options are open to the Tamils to seek reparation for the disappearance of the youths? Does the Minister know whether the matter has been reported to the United Nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is seriously concerned about allegations of human rights abuses occurring in the course of the armed conflict between the Sri Lankan Government forces and the Tamil Tigers, including in particular reports of the disappearances which have been referred to by Senator Jones. I cannot verify in any detail the specific reports to which the question refers but there are a considerable number of allegations which follow the common theme of abductions of Tamil youths and young men. Nor do I have detailed reports on where these young men, if surviving, are held.

ANSWER.PARA: While it is certainly true that the LTTE, the Tamil Tigers organisation, itself has been responsible for major outrages and systematic human rights abuses, there is little doubt that the Sri Lankan Government forces have also committed serious violations. The Australian Government has urged the Sri Lankan Government in the past, and it does so again now, to take more effective steps to restrain the excesses of its own forces and to curb abusive practices. I can assure Senator Jones that the Government has conveyed its concerns on the human rights situation in the country to the Government in Colombo on a number of occasions, most recently during the current session of the Commission of Human Rights (CHR) in Geneva. Australian statements to the CHR forty-seventh general session will also underline our continued concerns in this respect.

There is growing concern among the people in Sri Lanka at these disappearances. An organisation called Mother's Front is emerging as a major grassroots organisation with the objective of tracing the disappeared of all communities and seeking financial relief for their families. The High Commission attended in an observer status the inaugural national convention of this organisation in Sri Lanka a couple of days ago.

The Government welcomes measures which have recently been taken by the Sri Lankan Government to improve respect for internationally accepted human rights standards, including the recent establishment of a high level task force on human rights which is assisting in providing responses to individual cases raised by foreign missions, including ourselves, in Colombo and by continuing to cooperate with the United Nations Commission on Human Rights and the Red Cross.

The Australian Government does believe, and has always believed, that the only viable solution to this conflict is a peaceful one. Regrettably, it is not possible at the moment to say what shape that peaceful solution might take and whether it will include provisions for reparations. We are doing our best to continue promoting the idea of some mediated solution along the lines that have been the subject of discussion in this chamber in times past. We simply hope that sooner rather than later some sanity will prevail and a peaceful reconciliation will be possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to protocol I of the Geneva Conventions, which has been ratified by the Parliament this week. In particular, I mention article 82-Legal advisers in the armed forces-which provides that the parties, of which Australia is now one, shall:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . ensure that legal advisers are available when necessary to advise military commanders at the appropriate level on the application of the Conventions and this Protocol . . .

I ask the Minister: what steps has the Minister taken to ensure that legal advisers are present on the Australian ships in the Gulf? Who on the Australian vessels will undertake the role of legal advisers? How far have these people been briefed on the contents of the protocol?

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue came to my notice yesterday. I have asked for some inquiries to be made as to exactly what steps the Australian defence forces have to take. As yet I have had no response, so at this stage no formal steps have been taken in that regard. I hope to have a result of those inquiries in the next few days.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that it has been clear for some time that the ships may be engaged in armed conflict, why has the matter not been addressed before and how soon will it now be resolved?
—My understanding is that the legislation was passed yesterday. I was not going to be too presumptuous.
—You have known.
—With no help from you.

—There was no help from anyone on that side in the passing of the legislation, as Senator Evans says. I thought I answered the second part of Senator Durack's question earlier. I have made inquiries. I expect to get a response soon to see what our obligations will be and how they will be fulfilled.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister familiar with the latest Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) figures on wage movements? Is the Minister able to form a view which suggests that wage rises in Australia are comparable with the increases in other OECD countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to those two questions is yes and yes. The information that supports those answers is found in the latest Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development Economic Outlook publication for the December quarter 1990. That lists, in a table form, OECD estimates, which show that Australian unit labour costs in the business sector are estimated by the OECD as being below the average of other OECD countries for 1991. The Australian estimate is for an increase in money terms-I must make the distinction; this is different from the real terms change because our unit labour costs are falling-of 4.4 per cent for Australia compared with an OECD average for the year 1991 of 4.6 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: To look at some of the countries that we do better than, according to this OECD tabulation, is instructive. For example, we do better than the United States of America, which is listed at 4.9 per cent. We do better than the United Kingdom, which-and the Thatcher-now-Major model is often cited by senators opposite as the ideal from their point of view-is estimated at 8.3 per cent. As I said, we are at 4.4 per cent. We do better than Italy at 6.3 per cent, Austria at 5 per cent, Finland at 6.9 per cent, Greece at 14.6 per cent, Portugal at 9.4 per cent, Spain at 5.7 per cent and Switzerland at 4.9 per cent.

That tabulation shows a very heartening improvement for Australia. As well, in the face of what we have seen this week as a fairly irrelevant call, but nonetheless a call, made by the shadow spokesman for industrial relations, Mr Howard, on the 40-hour week, it puts to flight some of his fantasies about what unit labour cost performance in Australia is. The burden of his remarks is that it is not a good performance. Australia's performance, compared to other countries in the OECD, is reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to report to the Senate the Government's present position with regard to resource security legislation. Has that situation been altered at all by Mr Griffiths's document issue or has the situation been changed by Premier Field's representations to the Prime Minister? Will the Minister give the Senate a categorical assurance that no reference to resource security legislation will be included in the Government's impending industry statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not give assurances or promises about anything which will be in the statement of 12 March. I have said that before and I repeat it in respect of this question. Last week the Prime Minister said-in a somewhat misinterpreted statement by journalists-that this Government could sanction an agreement reached between a State government and proponents.
