He queried the view that we needed Federal legislation in place for a process to be followed whereby a State government comes to an arrangement with a proponent for a resource development and comes to the Commonwealth Government for some backing. There are several ways in which that backing could be provided. Any proposal which is brought forward will be given prompt attention.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday I had a discussion with Premier Field during his visit. The Prime Minister has had what has been described to me as a good discussion with Premier Field. It was agreed that options to achieve resource security would continue to be explored.
As I said at the start of my remarks, the timing is still being considered. Of course, the Commonwealth Government is awaiting proposals from States about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Prime Minister's statement in Launceston is to be interpreted as the Government's position, it should be interpreted as having no firm national position or national consistency with regard to whatever submissions will be received from State governments case by case. If that interpretation is correct, will that consideration have a common criterion of evaluation or will it be an ad hoc attitude to each case?
—I have nothing to add to what I said in answer to the honourable senator's first question. I am not going to follow the honourable senator down the path of rambling speculation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has agreement on a new classification structure been reached between employers and employees in the metals industry? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether or not the new structure will assist efficiency and provide greater scope for workplace reform in the metals industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Industrial Relations Commission, in a hearing on 12 February, ratified a new classification structure for the metal industry award. The operative date for that structure was Tuesday of this week, 21 February, when the orders were formally agreed. It is, I think, an historic agreement. I congratulate the metal industry unions and the metal industry employers for significantly improving the flexibilities of the work forces in the metal industry and the 450,000 Australian metal industry workers who are affected by the changes.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulties that the parties, in reaching this agreement, have overcome cannot in any sense be underestimated. The agreement marks the culmination of some three years of negotiations to develop an award framework for fundamental changes in the industry and, of course, at enterprise level. The 350 task-based classifications in the award will now be replaced by 14 levels of classification structures, with wage rates based on the skills exercised by the worker. This means that the demarcation disputes between different tasks, which characterised a lot of activity in the industry in the past, will now be done away with. I think that will add a significant efficiency and a significant improvement in industrial relations.

Workers will also now be able to undertake all of the tasks at their skill level which are necessary to do the job. For example, a welder, who in the past might have done only welding, will now be able to do all the work associated with that occupation, including the rigging work that is necessary, the driving of forklifts that is necessary and so on. Workers in the future will have the opportunity to progress up through a career path by gaining relevant skills and experience. They will also have access to better and more interesting jobs, with higher rates of pay.

I think the changes for employers are also significant. They will have access to a better trained work force, with far more flexibility in the deployment of their labour. Individual enterprises will be able to put in place work arrangements which better suit their needs and assist them to achieve higher productivity. A procedure has been agreed for the orderly transfer of the work force, as it now is, to the new structures. The award framework is supported by revised training arrangements, skills standards and competencies. Skill structures are to be finalised in March by the parties.

These changes in the workplace are complemented and enhanced by the ability for workers and employers, in accordance with the enterprise flexibility clauses of the award, to agree on changes in their workplace which will enable them to work more flexibly and more efficiently.

I again congratulate the parties. I say that it is a triumph for them. But it is also a triumph for this Government in the sense that it could occur only in the cooperative and consensual climate that we have engendered in industrial relations in this country. If we were to try to achieve these changes by consent in a confrontationist climate, which is the philosophy of the Opposition, these vast improvements would not have been able to be achieved at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that, following an overhead value analysis conducted by P &A Consultants, Australian Airlines is to withdraw safety engineers at a number of airports throughout the country? Is the Government also aware that the net result of these plans is that from June airports such as Hobart, Launceston, Mackay, Townsville and Rockhampton will be left without the services of Australian Airlines aircraft maintenance safety engineers? Given the Government's previous commitment to ensure that airline deregulation would not lead to a deterioration in air safety standards, does the Government consider the actions of Australian Airlines acceptable on the basis of saving a mere $2 per seat? Will the Government give a commitment to intervene with a view to ensuring that aircraft passenger safety throughout the country is not compromised in the pursuit of the almighty dollar?

—I have given that assurance a dozen times in the Parliament. I do so again. The internal staff arrangements of Australian Airlines is a matter for Australian Airlines. The oversight of the safety regulation is a matter for the Civil Aviation Authority which exercises that regulation in a stringent fashion. Indeed, we often get many complaints from Senator MacGibbon in this House in too stringent a fashion. I absolutely assure Senator Calvert and the Senate that no changes will be made in the engineering staffing arrangements in Australian Airlines that in any way compromise safety.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and relates to the wrecking of the ship Sanko Harvest off Esperance in Western Australia last week. Was that area of the ocean marked as dangerous on any maps produced by the Department? Can anything be done that will ensure that a similar tragedy never recurs in the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is of interest to senators from Western Australia. I must acknowledge that Senator Knowles has been pursuing this same matter, so she may be interested in this response.

ANSWER.PARA: The Sanko Harvest did ground off Esperance recently, and unfortunately broke up and sank. The matter is being investigated and the results of that investigation are not yet known. But what is known is that the grounding and sinking occurred outside the pilotage area for the port, so there was no requirement for a pilot.

I have looked at the charts and, as big a mug as I may be, according to the Opposition, even I could see that this is a dangerous area. It is clearly marked on all the international navigational charts.

At this point no-one knows why the master of the ship chose to take a direct line into the port of Esperance when the chart clearly indicated that he should not. The matter is being investigated and I will advise both Senator McKiernan and Senator Knowles of the results of that investigation when I have them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the much touted industry statement to be made to the Parliament on 12 March and to the very public internal argument as to who will get the credit for it-the Prime Minister, Treasurer Keating or his good self. In light of this morning's report in the Australian Financial Review that his junior Minister, Mr Simon Crean, has now entered the fray and is lobbying Mr Keating's faction for the statement to include protectionist measures, will the Minister inform the Senate whether his own contribution to the industry statement will be to support the Treasurer and his bid to further level the playing field or whether he will support his junior Minister, Mr Crean, who is presumably promoting the line of the Australian Council of Trade Unions of using taxpayers' money to kick-start areas where the private sector has been unwilling to move?
—I have read some of that stuff in the newspapers. I would not be too upset about it. We will get it right.

—Senator Bishop's question is the same question that I have been asked on a number of occasions: what will be the contents of the statement on 12 March? Senator Bishop should just wait a while, it is not long now, and she will be able to see. I think she will probably have some relevant questions to ask after the statement has been brought down. She should not get too excited about all that; I am not.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I wonder, in the light of that example of a non-answer, otherwise known as ducking and weaving, whether or not the Minister will at least have the decency to include in that statement an apology to the Australian people for his part and that of his junior Minister in their planning of the recession which, in the words of the Government, is the one `we had to have'?
—That is not a supplementary question. A number of Government Ministers have made comments about this. I have nothing to add to what has been said.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister to explain what consideration he gave to the recent Soviet proposal for a settlement of the Gulf war which would forestall a land war to get Iraq out of Kuwait. I further ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Secretary-General of the United Nations (UN), Perez de Cueller, that this is not a United Nations war. Does he agree with Mr Ali Alatas of Indonesia that `the door to peace opened by Mr Saddam's offer should not be slammed shut', given that this was the first time Iraq had been prepared to discuss withdrawal? Finally, I ask the Minister what consideration he has given to the future of the United Nations organisation with regard to a genuine United Nations role in conflict resolution and peacekeeping operations so that in future conflict situations the world does not face a scenario whereby the United States or any other major power takes military action and then gets a rubber stamp from the United Nations Security Council for its chosen intervention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the Soviet peace proposal, I answered a question on that very fully in this place yesterday in Senator Vallentine's absence, as I recall. I have nothing to add to that. It is simply a matter of waiting now to see what the Iraqi's response is to that proposal and then seeing how things pan out thereafter. As I made clear yesterday, the United States is not to be taken as having rejected the proposal, only to have identified a number of shortcomings in it. Those shortcomings are, in our judgment, capable of modification and remedy. We all hope that one way or another it will be possible to avoid, in a principled way, and consistently with the achievement of the UN resolutions and nothing else, the avoidance of further bloodshed. So I have nothing to add in that respect to what Mr Alatas or anybody else might have said about that particular proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the recurring suggestions that the UN Secretary-General, Mr Perez de Cueller, somehow is seeking to claim that this is not a United Nations war, what he has said on a number of occasions when asked is that it is a war taking place under the authority of the United Nations Security Council within the United Nations framework, but is not being actually conducted by the United Nations or its Military Staff Committee-or any of the other particular pieces of specific machinery potentially available under article 7 of the UN Charter-which has never, of course, been strictly implemented. But Mr Perez de Cueller has made it abundantly clear on innumerable occasions that he is not seeking to argue that this is taking place in any way at odds with the principles or procedures of the United Nations. As I have just said, it is unquestionably taking place within a UN framework. In that sense it can properly be described as pursuing UN objectives.

It is of course a matter for continuing debate and discussion, in which Australia will be very much involved, as to what the UN's role institutionally should be in conflict avoidance and conflict resolution in the future. One of the things that will have to be addressed is whether or not it is possible to develop some standing military arrangements within the terms of the UN Charter to make possible an institutional UN response to these situations in the future.

There are competing views as to the practicality of that and it may be, given the complexity and scale of military conflict in this technological age, that there are problems in going down that particular track, but it is an open question and one that very much deserves to be followed up in the kind of new international order that we all hope will exist and be consolidated as a result of this particular conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I wonder whether the Minister could elaborate on why the full text of the Secretary-General's meeting on 13 January with Saddam Hussein was not given more prominence by the coalition forces, given that there was a chink of opportunity in that meeting. Secondly, why is it not now the Secretary-General of the United Nations who is looking at the Soviet proposal and deciding whether it is acceptable or not rather than President Bush of the United States of America?

—I have nothing to add to the previous answer in that respect. The United Nations Secretary-General has made it perfectly clear that he supports a peaceful resolution to this conflict if that is at all possible. He made it clear in his own representations prior to 15 January, both directly to the Iraqis and publicly, what he understood the requirements of a peaceful resolution to be. They had to be built upon the unconditional and immediate acceptance by Iraq of its obligation to withdraw from Kuwait. The Secretary-General has constantly made it clear ever since that that has to be the basis on which a cease-fire or a peaceful resolution is achieved; that there is no other basis upon which it can be achieved. I do not believe it is likely that any role that he perceives himself capable of playing at the moment is not being equally capably played under the authority of the UN and the Security Council by the great powers most immediately currently involved.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs. Given the present appalling economic climate when bankruptcies in the last quarter alone rose in Western Australia by 89.4 per cent, Victoria by 69.4 per cent, New South Wales by 60.5 per cent, Queensland by over 50 per cent and Australia as a whole by some 56.8 per cent and where small business is struggling to survive, does the Government intend to continue with its original timetable for phasing in the system of an earlier collection of company tax? Is the Government also aware that, if it continues with this timetable, additional financial strain will be placed on the small business sector at a time when it is already reeling under the effects of this Government's engineered recession? Can the Minister give an assurance that it will not proceed with the original timetable and give small business a break?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are all aware of the statistics which Senator Boswell prefaces his question with. I do not know whether they are precisely accurate but for the purpose of answering the question I assume that they are. In so far as the economic recession bears on small business, I am very mindful of the fact that it is probably small business that has suffered most in the current downturn in the Australian economy. As far as the question of the revised timetable for collection of taxes announced last year is concerned, Senator Boswell will be aware, I hope, that the Treasurer announced some alleviation of that timetable in the latter part of last year. As I understand it, that was generally welcomed by small business organisations and by business generally.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Boswell's question relates to the small business sector as a whole. When he talks about bankruptcies he is not talking about incorporated business, so it is rather odd that he prefaced his question with figures about bankruptcies and then went on to ask a question about company tax, which relates to a relatively small part of small business because a very significant proportion of them are not incorporated businesses.

I will certainly listen to any request from Senator Boswell which would provide for a more sensible alleviation of corporate tax arrangements, but it seems to me that his question is in part misconceived.

I should conclude by saying that I am not sure that this is the worst problem which small businesses are facing at present by any manner of means. I have no doubt that a favourable response to Senator Boswell's question might help a very small proportion of small businesses, but I am not convinced that it would help the vast majority with whom we have to be concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask Senator Button, who is the Minister responsible for small business, whether he will come into this chamber when we next debate a matter of public importance and debate the issue instead of hiding behind Senator McMullan, his boy?

—Just as I am not going to make commitments about what is going to be in the March statement, I am not going to make commitments about every afternoon in the Senate, because I have a number of other things to do.
—You don't care about small business.

—It is precisely because I do care about small business that I would like to do some work on these issues rather than engaging in a silly debate with Senator Boswell, which would do absolutely nothing for small business. All he is hoping is that this debate will do something for himself.
—You are running away. You are scared. You are squibbing.

—I am very concerned about small business, but I am not concerned about Senator Boswell's capacity to send a pompous and largely inaccurate speech, as it will undoubtedly be, to a few constituents in north Queensland.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to the newly released national health strategy background paper by John Deeble and I ask: could the Minister tell the Senate whether any factors in this report indicate the need to fine tune Medicare when the Australian Government has kept the cost of health care down to a considerably lower proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) than most other western countries since its introduction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley, who was a distinguished medical practitioner before entering this chamber, for her question concerning Dr Deeble's paper. Whilst it very clearly sets out the fundamental strengths of Medicare-the medical service which is approved of by seven out of 10 Australians-there are certain problems in relation to supply and demand for medical services which the paper quite clearly identifies and which will need attention and consideration by the national health strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: It may be of interest for honourable senators to know that the medical service use per person increased by 23 per cent in the five years to 1989-90, but the largest increases were in the areas of pathology and other diagnostic services. In other words, the paper documents an underlying growth in the use of medical services but mainly in those areas where the use of those services is dictated by referrals-in other words by doctors-rather than by patients themselves presenting for a particular service. The doctors numbers problem is the result of training decisions made in the 1970s and there is a continuing underlying growth in the numbers of doctors and the use of medical services. It is a real problem which needs to be addressed.

Senator Crowley pointed out that the cost of private medical services has remained a stable proportion of GDP over the last six years and that is a notable achievement within the Medicare framework. But when one looks at the question of alternatives, it is quite clear that the voucher system, which has been touted and flirted with by the Opposition, is something which ought to be rejected by all Australians and, of course, by the Opposition very early in the piece.

I understand that the shadow Minister for health (Dr Bob Woods) has been retreating on this issue over the last several days. As I understand it, the proposal is that the Government would provide vouchers towards the cost of private insurance to Australians; I do not know whether to all Australians, but to a considerable number of Australians. The voucher would be used to purchase private health insurance.

The only comparable country with a great dependence on private health insurance is, of course, the United States. There the higher costs, both in service delivery and administration, are quite horrific. The amount spent on health in the United States is 11.2 per cent of gross domestic product, while in Australia it is 8.1 per cent. To put it another way, in the United States $2,769 was spent on health costs per person compared to $1,294 per person in Australia-in other words, the United States spent more than double the amount on providing health care to each person compared to Australia. I think that is why Australians will reject the idea that Medicare should be displaced and a system of vouchers for the purchase of private insurance should be substituted.

I am quite sure that my colleague Senator Graham Richardson would be most concerned that it would be a terribly troubling thing for elderly and frail Social Security client beneficiaries to have to make choices between private health insurance, whereas at the moment they have the certainty of the universal Medicare scheme, which I am sure is one of the reasons that has led to its receiving such ringing endorsement election after election over the last several years.

As Senator Crowley pointed out, there is some need for fine-tuning of Medicare. I am quite sure that Miss Jenny Macklin, who is conducting the national health strategy review, will give these issues her close attention. I believe the Minister, Mr Brian Howe, is looking forward to the receipt of her review of these matters in order to ensure that Medicare is strengthened in order to continue to well serve the Australian people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. As a preface to my question, I quote the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Bernie Fraser, who, when referring to the economy, was recently quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it is a matter of sitting tight for a while giving these changes a chance to work and see what happens.

I therefore ask the Minister: now that what the Australian people have thought for some time has been confirmed by the Governor himself, how long will the Government sit tight and `wait and see what happens' before doing something to overcome this recession that, we are told by the Treasurer, the country had to have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read Mr Fraser's speech given earlier in the week and I thought it was a very lucid speech. I hope people like Senator Archer have read it and not just taken a quote from a newspaper out of that speech. It is not quite fair of the honourable senator to take a quotation from Mr Fraser's speech out of the context in which it was put and put it in another context. Mr Fraser was saying that a variety of factors have to be taken into account in any consideration of loosening monetary policy.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two points he was making and would continue to make: that monetary policy has already been relaxed by some 6 per cent in the last 10 months or so and that it takes time for that sort of relaxation of monetary policy to work through the system, and that any additional relaxation of monetary policy at the present time would have no impact on the present circumstances of the Australian economy for some months to come. As I recall the speech, that was his first point.

The second point Mr Fraser was trying to make in that speech on this issue was that, in the light of world economic conditions, particularly conditions in the Anglo-Saxon countries-if I can so describe them-where recessions are taking place, it might be foolish to hastily reduce monetary policy because governments have to be very careful to look not just to the next few months, but to the longer term and try to determine policies which will influence the way this country comes out of the recession and which will influence, very much, the shape of the Australian economy in the years to come.

I think that is what Mr Fraser was saying about sitting tight. It is not at all palatable for governments to have to sit tight, but we do not want to get ourselves in the same situation as the Fraser Government did which, when confronted with recession, panicked, took all sorts of silly steps to try to get itself out of that difficult situation, and failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of recent Radio National reports which claim that Constancio Pinto, a high school teacher in East Timor, who has in the past acted as an interpreter for the East Timorese resistance, was recently arrested and allegedly tortured by Indonesian authorities? Can the Minister confirm whether these reports are accurate? What action has the Minister taken or will he take in relation to this apparent increase in the repression of East Timorese people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of media reports on Radio National that Mr Pinto, an East Timorese teacher, has allegedly been mistreated while under arrest for assisting an Australian journalist, Robert Domm, to gain an interview with the Fretelin leader, Xanana, last year. I can confirm that Mr Pinto was arrested in mid-January and has since been released. As for the allegations of torture, the Australian Embassy in Jakarta is currently making inquiries, including independent sources, to find out whether this is true. If the Embassy's inquiries confirm that Mr Pinto was seriously mistreated, I will certainly instruct the Embassy to raise the matter with the Indonesian authorities. Such action would be consistent with the Government's very firm policy of raising these human rights cases where we have reasonably specific details of what occurred and where these allegations are backed up by reliable sources.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not agree, however, that the arrest of Mr Pinto is indicative of what Senator Bourne describes as an increase in repression of the East Timor people. The human rights situation in East Timor in the past year did improve over that of 1989, although it is clear that there was an increase in security problems and a resultant deterioration in that situation in East Timor over the particular period of September to November last year-a deterioration which resulted in the Australian Government registering its concern at very senior levels with the Indonesian Government.

The situation appears very much to have calmed down again over the past two or three months. Independent sources indicate to us that release of people detained as a result of that unrest late last year has been under way since early December. All I can say generally is that the Government will continue to monitor very closely the human rights situation in East Timor and continue to make representations to the authorities as appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is it a fact that around December last year the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation called for expressions of interest from the aviation industry to operate and maintain its F27 aircraft? Is it a fact that that contract has been awarded to the Civil Aviation Authority? If so, why are the regulators of the aviation industry competing in a commercial area?
—I do not carry that kind of detail around with me in my head. I am happy to pursue the matter and will advise the Senate as soon as I have received an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the recent statement about the United Nations (UN) by Senator Powell in which she suggested that because the way in which that body operates it should be reformed, may I ask the Minister for his response to this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a rather extraordinary statement attributed to Senator Powell in the past couple of days suggesting that because the United Nations has not handled the Gulf war in accordance with the prescriptions of the Australian Democrats, it should be reformed, and in particular democratised. Senator Powell claims that the United Nations abrogated its responsibilities by leaving the decision to join the war to each individual nation and ceding control of the military action to the United States of America. She said that the Security Council should immediately take back control and that when that is done the whole organisation must be turned upside down and thoroughly democratised to ensure that this sort of thing does not happen again.

ANSWER.PARA: I think we ought to return to some basics and an understanding of what the UN's role is in all of this. The Security Council's 12 resolutions on the war clearly establish what must happen if there is to be a resolution of the conflict. It was the Security Council of the United Nations which ordered an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, and it was the Security Council of the United Nations which adopted resolution 678 to enforce that order and requested all individual States to provide appropriate support to that end. Of course, that is precisely what the coalition is doing in the Gulf at this time-operating within resolution 678 to secure Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.

The crucial point that Senator Powell fails either to comprehend or accept is that it is Iraq's failure to comply with the Security Council's resolutions which has brought about this war, and until there is irrefutable evidence that Iraq is complying with those resolutions there can be no question of the withdrawal of coalition forces. As for what she says about the democratisation of the United Nations, the Security Council has not acted alone in the Gulf crisis. I remind her that 144 nations joined in the United Nations General Assembly condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

I am not sure how quickly the UN will respond to Senator Powell's blandishments as far as the reform of its own house is in order. We will be respectfully suggesting that it does not act too quickly in this respect. We believe that a very dangerous principle would be set if it did. No institution-international or domestic-would henceforth be safe if it did not operate in accordance with those principles of naive, breathless muddle which the Australian Democrats have made peculiarly their own.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the Burkegate cover-up. I refer the Minister to his answer to my question on 26 November 1990 when he said that he would look into the matter of Australia's diplomatic representation in Ireland and the Holy See during that period of time when Ambassador Burke is required to appear before the Royal Commission into WA Inc. Could the Minister inform the Senate today whether he has looked into these matters? Furthermore, could the Minister explain whether he has been advised as to when, for how long and on how many occasions the Ambassador will be required to appear? Finally, has the Minister discussed with the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, talks that he held in Dublin with Ambassador Burke during the recent parliamentary recess?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering where Senator Campbell had got to. It has been eight Question Times, now, that we have been back this year and this is the first time he has raised this question again.

ANSWER.PARA: I have continued to note the various allegations about Mr Burke's conduct and performance-those made by Senator Campbell in the Senate, and those made elsewhere by others. I have said before, and I say again now, that Mr Burke retains my confidence and I see no basis at this time for his recall from his post in Dublin. If and when some hard evidence emerges through the courts or a Royal Commission of something which would make it inappropriate for his ambassadorial position to be maintained I will act, but not sooner. I have said that before, and I say it again.

The allegations that have been made in relation to Mr Burke and to all manner of other actions and activities in Western Australia over the past decade, as I understand it, will be properly and fully examined by the Royal Commission now established. I have no intention whatsoever of prejudging the conclusions of that Royal Commission or, of course, in any way interfering with its deliberations. As the Prime Minister and I have previously indicated, if or when Mr Burke needs to return to Australia to appear before that Royal Commission, arrangements will be made to facilitate his return.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for carefully reading that prepared speech-which I would ask him to table -but he totally ignored the question. It was not a question about whether Ambassador Burke was to be recalled; it was asking whether or not the Minister had considered the matter of what representation we will have in Ireland during the time that Ambassador Burke will be required to appear before the Royal Commission, which the Prime Minister has made clear in the other place his Government will facilitate. All I have asked is: has the Minister had any advice as to when, for how long and on what occasions Ambassador Burke will be required to appear? I think that is a reasonable question and I ask the Minister to turn his attention to the real question.
—I have had no such advice to this point. Apart from that, I have nothing further to add to my answer and I do not propose to table any piece of paper in front of me.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of statements by the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations that a coalition government would trigger a double dissolution of Parliament within months of the next election if it failed to get its industrial relations changes through the Senate? Is the Minister also aware that Mr Howard is of the opinion that it is not worth a government being in power if it does not reform the industrial relations system? I seek the Minister's views on this sentiment and how it compares with the Government's approach to industrial relations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a transcript of an interview by Mr Howard in which he expressed the views that are embodied in Senator Beahan's question. I might say that it is extraordinary, since the Opposition's proposals on industrial relations `reform' are not quite clear, that the Senate should be stood over under the threat that, if it does not pass these unspecified measures, it will be taken to a double dissolution. We would all be grateful to receive an Opposition paper which clearly specified its proposals so that the electorate could judge and the Senate might form a view. Nonetheless, I am also not sure what electors in Australia would think of a threat that they may have to face two elections within the space of three months.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I think that Mr Howard's comment that if a government does not reform the industrial relations system there is not much point in its being in power is a very revealing statement, and I wholeheartedly support it. Such a statement is a damning indictment of the former Liberal Government, of which Mr Howard was Treasurer. During its term of office, that Government made no effort to reform the industrial relations system. It was content to accept the status quo without any attempt to fundamentally overhaul the system. If the coalition were to introduce legislation or to take charge of the system, one can ask these questions. What does it mean? Does it mean that wage growth will revert from the 6.8 per cent per annum that it now runs at to the 11.4 per cent per annum that it ran at under the Howard Government? Does it mean that industrial disputes will increase from the low level at which they are now by about 61 per cent to bring them back to the level reached in the period of the Fraser Government? Does it mean that the increase in average--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I respectfully suggest that putting all these hypothetical questions is clearly indicative of a debate and not of an answer to a question.
—Yes, Senator Cook, I think Senator Hill has a point. I would ask you to conclude the answer as soon as possible.

—I will do that, Mr President. A Liberal-National Party government, on what we know on the record, would end the whole progress towards award restructuring which so underpins the important industry changes. Since there is no clear idea of what wages policy would be, how could an incoming government deliver an aggregate wage outcome on target or under target as we have consistently throughout our term in office? It is interesting that Mr Howard should hold those views, but it is certainly frightening for the Australian community that a return to the Fraser era is contemplated.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I want to congratulate Senator Button in this instance on his press release of 19 February on the Cape York space base and the work that he seems to be doing to move that matter ahead. I ask the Minister: what stage has been reached in the investigations into the Aboriginal and environmental concerns about the Cape York space base proposal? Is there a deadline in place for completion of the environmental investigations and negotiations with the Aborigines? If not, will the Minister use his best endeavours to establish an early cut-off date for the resolution of these issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been made clear in whatever I have said about the spaceport during the past nine months or so that whatever proponent wishes to proceed with the proposal will have to satisfy both some environmental requirements and some appropriate requirements of negotiation and, hopefully, agreement with the Aboriginal communities.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty in the whole process has been that some of the proponents of the space base have, for a variety of reasons, fallen by the wayside. At present, the most important issue is to find an appropriate consortium to take the proposal forward, it having been determined both here and by national experts to be a viable commercial endeavour. That issue has to be resolved first. To my knowledge there have been a number of discussions with Aboriginal communities about the proposed spaceport. At present I cannot give a precise timetable as to where those discussions are. I will find out and give Senator Macdonald an answer as quickly as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister accept and understand that commercial entities cannot possibly plan and proceed with their proposals and submissions on the space base if they do not know the cut-off time or when there is some limit on the extent of these environmental and Aboriginal negotiations and that for those commercial entities to proceed with a realistic estimation of what they should do, it is important that there be some cut-off date?
—I understand that and so does any consortium that has any nous.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. I refer to the Minister's most recent statement on child-care payments, which speaks of child-care benefits being available for working families and working parents. I ask: are we to assume that the Government considers that the 890,000 mothers not in the paid work force and who are caring for their children do not in fact work? Is this the basis for the Government's discriminatory policy against them?

—I refute any notion that the Commonwealth Government in its provision of access to child-care is constructing that access on a basis which discriminates in the way suggested by Senator Harradine. In fact, I think there is now a general community recognition of the worth of the contribution of women, or indeed whichever spouse or parent is in charge of a particular household, to the servicing of that household. The fact that the person is not in the paid work force does not mean that that person should not have the benefit, in relation to children of the household, of the child-care centres and, indeed, the extension of fee relief to commercial centres, which was ratified by this Senate just before Christmas and came into operation on 1 January. It is an example of the further increase of the provision of child-care into the community by this Government. We are very committed to that. The fact that those in the paid work force or those performing home duties are able to take advantage of these child-care places is a matter of great pride for this Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to a question that Senator Watson asked on 19 February. I have made a copy of the answer available to Senator Watson. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: DECLARATIONS IN RELATION TO PROTOCOL I

It is Australia's understanding that in relation to Article 5, with regard to the issue whether, and in what measure, Protecting Powers may have to exercise any functions within the combat zone (such as may be implied by provisions in-Parts III and IV of the Protocol), the role of the Protecting Power will be of a like character to that specified in the First and Second Conventions and Part II of the Fourth Convention, which apply mainly to the battlefield and its immediate surroundings.

It is the understanding of the Government of Australia that in relation to Article 44 of Protocol I, the situation described in the second sentence of paragraph 3 can exist only in occupied territory or in armed conflicts covered by paragraph 4 of Article 1. The Government of Australia will interpret the word ``deployment'' in paragraph 3(b) of the Article as meaning any movement towards a place from which an attack is to be launched. It will interpret the words ``visible to the adversary'' in the same paragraph as including visible with the aid of binoculars, or by infra-red or image intensification devices.

In relation to Articles 51 to 58 inclusive it is the understanding of Australia that military commanders and others responsible for planning, deciding upon, or executing attacks, necessarily have to reach their decisions on the basis of their assessment of the information from all sources, which is available to them at the relevant time.

In relation to paragraph 5 (b) of Article 51 and to paragraph 2 (a) (iii) of Article 57, it is the understanding of Australia that references to the ``military advantage'' are intended to mean the advantage anticipated from the military attack considered as a whole and not only from isolated or particular parts of that attack and that the term ``military advantage'' involves a variety of considerations including the security of attacking forces. It is further the understanding of Australia that the term ``concrete and direct military advantage anticipated'', used in Articles 51 and 57, means a bona fide expectation that the attack will make a relevant and proportional contribution to the objective of the military attack involved.

It is the understanding of Australia that the first sentence of Article 52 is not intended to, nor does it deal with, the question of incidental or collateral damage resulting from an attack directed against a military objective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today Senator Parer asked me whether waterside workers who are about to be made redundant from the Port of Cairns on the twenty-eighth of this month are going to be employed under the structural adjustment program for the wet tropics through the actions of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I have sought a response from the Minister. I have also asked for a response from the Department in case there has been some suggestion of it made there.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand why Senator Parer asked that question. It was provoked by a recent newspaper article in the Cairns Post, which had not been brought to my attention. The response that I have received from the Minister is this: the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has given no in principle support of any kind to employing displaced waterfront workers under the wet tropics structural adjustment program, as mentioned in an article in the Cairns Post. Neither Mrs Kelly's Department nor the Minister's Office has received any submissions on the matter-I just do not know where these stories come from, frankly-and no waterside workers are employed on any wet tropics structural adjustment projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a further answer for Senator Bjelke-Petersen who asked me in the Senate whether I would seek to have the results of television aggregation in Queensland monitored and whether I would take action to ensure that rural viewers are not further disadvantaged. In light of the time, Mr President, I wonder whether I could seek leave to have the answer, which is quite long, incorporated in Hansard?

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Will the Minister seek to have the results of television aggregation in Queensland monitored?

(2) Will the Minister urge the Department of Transport and Communications to take action to ensure that rural viewers are not further disadvantaged by the continual decline in their television services?

The Government is committed to the provision of three commercial television services to majority of regional Australia. I believe there is some confusion about recent changes to commercial television services in Queensland, and the role of the Commonwealth Government in those changes. I regret this is so, and I hope this answer will assist you to understand the situation.

Unfortunately, there was a last minute change to the program supply arrangements to two of the three services, and this is what has caused much of the public confusion. The purchase of programs by television stations, and the affiliation agreements they make with national networks, are entirely commercial matters between the parties concerned. I am sure you would agree that it would be entirely improper for the Minister for Transport and Communications or the Government to interfere in such contractual negotiations.

(2) The second issue you have raised is that of the programs available on the remote commercial television service (RCTS) in the outback areas of Queensland. As it happens, the licensee of this service, Queensland Television (QTV), is also one of the three regional licensees. As you point out, it no longer takes the majority of its programs from the NINE network, but from TEN. Although QTV's 1991 programming schedule has not been fully decided, I am informed that it is likely that it will take programs from the TEN network as well as special programs from other networks.
Any complaints about commercial television programming may be registered with the licensee and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement regarding ministerial practice during Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Senator Button interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that this is regarded with mirth by the Leader. But Ministers have adopted the practice of walking out of Question Time before the Leader has asked that further questions--
—Some Ministers.

—Some Ministers have adopted this practice each sitting day of walking out of Question Time before the Leader has asked that further questions be put on notice. Mr President, I suppose that this is not a subject on which you can direct Ministers. But, as they presumably have more respect for you than they appear to have for the institution, can I suggest to you, Mr President, that you might, through the Leader, suggest that Ministers could at least demonstrate that small degree of courtesy by remaining until the end of Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the matter I want to raise relates directly to the remarks that were made by Senator Hill. I should say by way of preface that each of the Ministers concerned has been notified of my intention to move, in the form that I will be moving, a motion at the end of Question Time.
—On a point of order, he didn't seek leave.
—Order! Senator Alston did not seek leave. Is leave granted?
—Mr President, I do not believe that I need leave. Standing Orders entitle me to move this motion at the end of Question Time.

—Senator Alston should have sought leave to make a statement, even though there is a procedure under which he could have automatically moved a motion. I think, in the circumstances, the honourable senator ought to be given leave.
—I am indebted to the Senate. I was simply saying what perhaps should have been said by way of leave preparatory to moving the motion which I believe I am entitled to move without leave. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pursuant to Order of the Senate of 28 September 1988, I ask the following Ministers to explain why answers have not yet been provided to certain questions on notice:

1. Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Senator Bolkus-question No. 261, of which notice was given on 17 October 1990, relating to CES offices and which answer is 97 days overdue;

2. Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Senator Bolkus-question No. 389, of which notice was given on 13 December 1990, regarding the training of staff in the Department and which answer was put on notice 70 days ago and is now 40 days overdue;
3. Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson-question No. 369, of which notice was given on 6 December 1990, relating to research performed within the Department, which is 47 days overdue;
4. Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson-question No. 408, of which notice was given on 18 December 1990, relating to overseas pensions, which is 35 days overdue;
5. Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook-question No. 388, concerning training of staff within the Department, which is a mere 40 days overdue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a letter relating to the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration--
—Order! Senator Cook, you were asked pursuant to an order of the Senate to answer that question.
—To answer that question? I will investigate the reasons for the delay and reply further in due course.

—Order! In relation to the point raised by Senator Hill and also referred to by Senator Alston, I do think the present situation is unsatisfactory. I have asked Ministers before to stay in the chamber until Question Time is completed. I ask members of the Opposition to inform the Ministers that they are going to ask these questions after Question Time; it might help solve the problem.
—In at least one instance we have advised a Minister on two occasions that the matter is proposed to be raised. Each of the Ministers concerned has been notified via his office. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 5 March 1991, answers to questions on notice Nos 261, 369, 388, 389 and 408, together with an explanation for the delay in responding.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I table a letter relating to the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the development of the Senior Executive Service, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Coates) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement and ask a question relating to a matter of privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, yesterday I asked a number of questions relating to matters of privilege on the tabling of documents by Senator McLean and I asked for your ruling on that. Last night, at the beginning of the adjournment debate, the Acting Deputy President, Senator Calvert, responded to those questions. I refer, in particular, to the last part of Senator Calvert's response to my question, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The second question related to the use of the documents by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its inquiry into the cost of justice in Australia. The Committee could seek to have the documents laid before it and could seek to hear evidence in relation to the documents, but that is a matter for the Committee to determine.

Mr President, I put this question to you to which I seek a response at a later stage. Does this mean that if the President of the Senate rules that a document is not eligible to be tabled or incorporated in Hansard because of the rule of sub judice yet is circulated privately by a senator, and another senator on a standing committee, such as the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, believes it is germane to its present inquiry, and if a majority of that Committee believes that the document ought to be tabled in the Committee and used as evidence in its inquiry and therefore attracts the privilege of Parliament by being incorporated in the evidence and published accordingly, therefore we get a decision between the President of the Senate and a majority of a standing committee which may choose to vote accordingly?

I believe it would be unsatisfactory to have such a circumstance apply whereby a President's ruling could be overturned, in effect, by a simple majority of the Standing Committee, which is no more than four or five senators. I particularly draw your attention to that possible unintended consequence. I seek clarification from you on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht has not raised this issue with me before. I will examine the issues that he raised and make a statement to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Today there has been discussion of the fact that the Deeble report has identified a link between overuse of medical services and the national capacity to pay, and that it has indicated that under Medicare there has been a substantial increase in utilisation. This flies in the face of continued claims by the Government that Medicare had not led to any over-utilisation of health services.

I think it is significant in the light of this that the Medicare levy does not go anywhere near paying for overall health expenditure. I believe that it is important for the Australian people to know the reason for the inability of the Medicare levy to pay for the spiralling health growth in service volume and, in fact, to know whether the underfunding by the Medicare levy has contributed to this spiralling growth, because there is clearly no relationship between the cost of Medicare and the levy itself. The reason that those matters are of such significance is that the Australian Institute of Health, among its activities, has to:

. . . contribute to the improvement of the health of Australians and to the efficient use of resources in the provision of health services . . . to . . . undertake studies into the provision and effectiveness of health services and technologies . . .

I note that there has been a major analysis, drawing on national health insurance data, comparing the use and costs of private medical services in 1976 to those in 1986 undertaken by the Australian Institute of Health. I further note that the report states:
In the Institute's work, emphasis shifting from the development of health statistics to management and use of data bases that have been put in place.
It goes on:
As the various data bases are put in place, there will be a shift in emphasis towards undertaking value-added analysis of statistics that have become available . . .

This is particularly relevant at the moment because of this Deeble report. I would be interested to know the extent to which the Institute of Health has been involved in providing information which would not otherwise have been available to the Deeble report. It is important for us to find that out because this is an expensive Institute. The activities, we argued at the time, could well have been conducted in other specialist areas, for example, the Bureau of Statistics. I think it is important for us to find out whether the Institute of Health is contributing to such major findings as the Deeble one about over-utilisation of health services under Medicare. The reason I ask is that the Health Economics and Expenditure Unit of the Institute, which is responsible for collating information on expenditure on health services by governments, through private insurance and by individuals, published an information booklet some time ago. It says that the unit also provides advice on health economic analysis and evaluation. It says that major tasks carried out during the year include provision of economic consultancy to the screening evaluation coordination unit and so on, and estimating the economic and health aspects of increasing taxes on tobacco and modelling the effects of Commonwealth Grants Commission recommendations on health financing arrangements.

What I want to know is: does it have its eyes on the big game? I suppose the 1976-86 report shows a readiness to do so but I believe that this Institute which, as I said, is costly and has taken some time to report for the year to 30 June-in February 1991-has to establish that it really does have a place in the sun.

I wish to speak to the corrigenda to the annual report of the Australian Institute of Marine Science. It is interesting to note just how extensive that corrigenda is, indicating considerable changes in terms of both the structure and the report into the research program. Having said that, it is worthwhile looking at the report of which this now forms a part. The report itself has a number of interesting photographs on the cover, one of which is a photograph of `benthick sampling during experimental testing into the habitat choice of juvenile banana prawns'. It is clearly a photograph of a rich mangrove area. The report itself also expresses the following hope:

. . . to generate a constant flow of new knowledge; to stimulate the development of high value new uses, services, processes and technologies; and to contribute to the knowledge base required for the sustainable use of existing and new marine biological resources and for conservation issues.

It says that concern about the impact of terrestrial practices on the quality of coastal waters has attained high political priority in the last two or three years. Then it goes on and talks about the extreme importance of mangrove areas. The reason I raise this is that at this very time we have around Port Adelaide an area which is recognised by the Department of Fisheries of South Australia-a mangrove area which is responsible for most of the commercial fishing, worth about $5m a year, and most of the recreational fishing involving some 300,000 residents of Adelaide who spend some $130m per year on their fishing activities. Half of the mangrove areas of Port Adelaide have already disappeared and the other half are now under serious threat from the multifunction polis (MFP) proposal, which has been pushed very vigorously by Senator Button in this chamber and also by Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia.

It is of concern to me that at a time when we are spending a great deal of money on research to identify the important environmental attributes of our coastal areas-and we have identified mangroves as one of the richest and most productive areas-we have both the Federal Government and State government in South Australia moving to damage those various areas. There is little point in identifying these areas if, in fact, the governments takes no notice of the scientific results.

Specifically in the case of Port Adelaide we have an area of mangroves currently in an aquatic reserve. These mangroves are prevented from migrating inland as a consequence of sea-level rise, and the sea will rise there both as a consequence of slow subsidence of the surrounding land and also as a consequence of greenhouse. Those mangroves can go nowhere because they are currently backed by saltpans. There is no plan within the MFP proposals for those saltpans to be removed and turned back to swamp into which the mangroves could migrate. There has already been extensive clearing of mangrove areas to the south of the aquatic reserve and that area could also be returned to mangroves with a great deal of benefit.

Indeed, only a couple of weeks ago, the South Australian Government launched what it called its status report on the development of the MFP proposal. At that launch, which was in the form of a press conference, Mr Rod Keller who now heads the Government committee was asked about the mangroves. Clearly he had not been properly briefed on the subject because he said, `We will get rid of those rubbish areas. You don't have to worry about that'. This indicates what little concern the South Australian Government and, by implication, this Government represented in this chamber by Senator Button have for these very important areas. It is absolutely vital that we recognise the importance of mangrove areas and do everything we possibly can to protect them and certainly, if possible, extend them where that can also be done. The MFP proposal is simply inconsistent with that protection.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

This National Museum of Australia annual report is a catalogue of disaster as a direct result of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) being opposed to it. The Treasurer has made no bones about the fact that he does not like museums and considers that we have too many of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has got one at home.
—He has a museum of clocks but, apparently, no-one else can get into the act because he says, `I do not really agree with the National Museum of Australia'. A report in the Bulletin last month said:

SPEECH.PARA: Reminded of the four repositories filled with 200,000 pieces of Australian heritage and history destined for the Museum, he says: `I know but the world's full of fabulous stuff.'
It is not very full of fabulous Treasurers out here. The article continued:
`I think Australia is getting museumed-out.'

The Federal Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, David Simmons, is saying that he is pushing ahead to try to have a construction timetable agreed to by Cabinet this year. But there seems no doubt that Mr Keating's opposition will kill off this National Museum project. That would be a tragedy. No matter what one thinks about the terrible state of the Australian economy at the moment, one hopes it will not always be in such a state, and this is a project which should not be killed off, particularly as it involves using the old Parliament House. I would think that Mr Keating's objection to the National Museum extends, no doubt, to preserving the old Parliament House, which for some incredible reason he would like to see bulldozed. We have little enough history in this place--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not said anything of the kind. You are making it up.

—I am quite happy for the Minister to have a copy. In fact, I will table the copy of the Bulletin magazine of 8 January relating to the Treasurer's total opposition to the National Museum of Australia, which includes the restoration of the old Parliament House to be ready for the centenary of government in 2001.
—Order! Senator Baume, you will need leave to table material.
—I seek leave to table the article.
—Is leave granted?
—Without accepting the distortion that might be in the article, we accept it.
—I thank the Minister for that sanctimonious nonsense. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Council drew to the Minister's attention problems arising from the continuing absence of approved criteria and guidelines for the national historical collection. As a consequence much of the collection lacks statutory protection and the Council is unable to de-accession material not considered appropriate for inclusion in the collection.
Council also asked the Government to update the monetary limits on contract approvals which have remained unchanged since 1980.
The Government is setting out to kill this project. There is no doubt. The report goes on:
While much has been achieved through community consultation, restoration of acquisition funds and augmentation of curatorial staff are essential for balanced development of the collection.

It reveals what I believe is a scandalous situation: the number of researchers and students who have been able to get access to material in the collection has been reduced from 140 in 1988-89 to only 11. The report says:
The number of researchers/students given direct access to the collection was reduced due to competing accommodation needs of consultant cataloguers.
In other words, the lack of resources given to this Museum is destroying its capacity to service researchers and students. The report goes on:

Of greatest concern is the recent discovery of the loss of four items from the collection . . . en-route to the Stockman's Hall of Fame, Longreach. Following exhaustive searches the Minister was formally advised of their loss.
It goes on:

. . . inadequate supervision of routine conservation following use of Australia II for bicentennial celebrations may have resulted in increased conservation costs in preparing the vessel for display at the Australian National Maritime Museum.
As I said, this is a sorry story. It goes on:

Despite these efficiencies the acute shortage of collection accommodation and adjacent working space was apparent during the year. The Museum at present has only 1000 square metres of controlled environment space which falls far short of its requirement. An additional 1300 square metres of warehouse space was leased adjoining premises occupied by the Museum at Wollongong Street, Fyshwick. This is at best a temporary solution and will be used immediately for the storage of the large Aboriginal Arts Board collection.
And so it goes on. The failure of this Government to provide any serious backing to this is a disgrace.
