SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

When it was introduced in 1947, the Social Security Act 1947 (the Act) brought together separate legislation dealing with age, invalid and widows' pensions, maternity allowances, child endowment and unemployment and sickness benefits. Commonwealth legislation in the area of social security dates back to 1908 with the enactment of the Invalid and Old-Age Pensions Act.

Since 1947 the Act has been subject to over 100 amending Acts. At the outset, the Act depicted a passive payment mechanism, providing benefits in the form of direct cash payments to clients. It has now become more attuned, because of the many recent amendments, to the changing social and economic environment through its development into a more active piece of legislation that targets individuals and families in genuine need while positively encouraging them toward independence of the welfare system.

These developments have involved increasing complexity and diversification within one of the most important pieces of Commonwealth legislation. A large proportion of the Australian population is affected by the Act. The volume of recent amendments, the increased complexity of certain areas of the Act and changes in drafting styles since 1947 are some of the factors that have contributed to reduced comprehensibility of the Act as well as a hodgepodge of styles and presentation.

A legislation review was instituted by the then Minister for Social Security and carried out by the Department of Social Security with the cooperation of representatives of the welfare sector. This Bill is the result of that process. In February this year copies of an exposure draft of the Bill were released for public comment. Public seminars were held in each capital city to explain the background to the review of the legislation and to examine the structure, format and style of the draft legislation. Those attending were invited to suggest changes or improvements to the exposure draft. The response to these consultations was both constructive and positive.

The object of this Bill is to overcome the problem of readability by using a clear English drafting style and format. That style and format should make it a more accessible piece of legislation that ordinary Australians can reasonably be expected to understand. In many instances, traditionally used legislative words such as ``notwithstanding'' have been dropped or replaced by non-technical words such as ``despite'' or ``even if''. In some places ``cease'' has been replaced by ``stop'' and ``request'' by ``ask''. These are just a few examples of one aspect of clear English drafting.

Two main aims have been pursued in redrafting the Social Security Act. The first has been the aim of making each individual provision as simple and easy to read as possible. The second has been the aim of making the arrangement of the provisions in the Act logical and easy to follow. As a result, this Bill contains many new features at both the individual provision level and at the overall organisational level.

Chapter 1 of the Bill is of fundamental importance because it provides the basic interpretative tool for the reader. It sets out in one place the definitions of principal terms used in the Bill. Definitions may:
settle the meaning of a word or phrase that might otherwise be of doubtful meaning;
extend the ordinary meaning of a word to achieve a broader effect;
narrow the ordinary meaning of a word to achieve a restrictive effect; or
allow a shortened reference to a complicated concept or a long name.
Two innovations of note in the definitional part of Chapter 1 are:
an index of defined words and phrases; and
groups of definitions according to subject matter.
The main advantage of grouping is that it reduces the ambit of the search area for a reader. The index will improve accessibility.

Chapter 1 includes a part concerned with determinations having an interpretative effect. Some definitions in the current Act confer powers. For example, an organisation cannot be a ``benevolent home'' for the purposes of receiving a portion of a social security payment under the Act unless the organisation has been approved as such by the Secretary. The use of definitions in this way is inconsistent with the purpose of definitions and puts the reader to unnecessary trouble. Hence, such provisions, where they remain essential, have been reworked and grouped together in a separate part of the interpretational Chapter.

Chapter 2 sets out the modules for each of the 20 types of social security payment. Each payment module is almost totally self-contained so that a reader will find out everything he or she needs to know about a particular pension, benefit or allowance without referring to a multitude of provisions outside that module. Special or less frequently used provisions that affect qualification or payability, such as the effect of compensation payments, are located outside the payment modules for cost and space-efficiency reasons but they are signposted at appropriate points in payment modules. Rate calculators are also located outside the payment modules for similar reasons. The provisions of each payment module deal with matters in a procedural order covering in turn qualification criteria, how to claim, determination of claim, how to assess rate, how payment is made, recipient obligations, continuation, variation and termination of benefit, bereavement payments and fringe benefits provisions. Equivalent provisions to these are currently found scattered throughout the Act.

Chapter 3 of the Bill contains general provisions which relate to rates of benefit and to means testing. This Chapter contains the rate calculators for the social security payments covered in Chapter 2. The generic rate calculators are probably the most effective innovation of the rewrite exercise. This is because they have transformed an incomprehensible set of rules into more useful tools that, while still complex, are set out in steps to assist social security clients and their advisers to check rate calculations.
Chapter 3 also includes general provisions relating to the ordinary income test, the maintenance income test, the assets test, the effect of the receipt of compensation payments and indexation.

Chapter 4 provides for payment of certain pensions outside Australia and sets down the rules regulating the rate payable to people who can take their pensions overseas. The Chapter also covers bilateral social security agreements between Australia and other countries.

Chapter 5 consolidates provisions dealing with the identification of debts arising under the Bill and with the recovery, waiver or write-off of those debts. Currently, these provisions are found in different parts of the legislation.
Chapter 6 mirrors Part XIX of the present Act that deals with the review of decisions by:
officers of the Department of Social Security;
the Social Security Appeals Tribunal; and
the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Part XIX was an early piece of clear English legislation to emerge from the legislation review and was introduced into the Social Security Act 1947 by the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Act 1988. Hence, it is one of the few areas of the Bill that did not need substantial revision.

Chapter 7 of the Bill sets out the Secretary's responsibilities regarding general administration and information gathering. There is a separate division dealing with confidentiality and the protection and use of personal information. Chapter 7 also provides for the establishment, membership and organisation of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
Chapter 8 contains a number of miscellaneous provisions.

The Bill contains notes following some provisions. These are designed to assist readers in locating definitions and other relevant provisions. Examples showing the operation of provisions have been incorporated in the text to explain how some provisions work-especially those involving complex calculations. At the front of the Bill is a ``Reader's Guide'' which explains how the Bill is structured and how it can be used.

The rewrite of the Act does not involve any major policy initiatives and it does not have any financial impact. The new legislation is intended to reflect existing policy which is, in turn, reflected by the existing legislation. The primary purpose of the rewrite is to overcome readability problems that had developed mainly as a result of the volume of changes made to the current Act since 1947. Another important object of the rewrite is to make the Act easier to change in the future as the need arises. Those purposes would be fulfilled by this Bill. Furthermore, it is expected that this will pave the way for other large pieces of federal legislation to be written or rewritten in a similar clear English style and format. The Department of Veterans' Affairs has already begun working on the clear English rewrite of Part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

This Bill does not include any amendments to the Act introduced during these Sittings. These changes will be introduced as amendments in Autumn Sittings next year. A Bill covering the transitional arrangements and consequential amendments will follow this Bill.

The legislation working party of the Social Security Advisory Council played a major part in the preparation and discussion of research papers and other less tangible ways in the development of this Bill. The members of the working party, especially its chairman, Professor Terry Carney, deserve special thanks for their enthusiastic and important contributions. That working party did an extraordinary amount of work for very limited compensation-well beyond the call of duty.

In terms of this legislation, we owe a great debt to Monash University and the law school, headed up by Terry Carney and Peter Hanks, who co-authored one of the important texts on social security legislation in Australia. I would like to say also that in the Department of Social Security Michael Sassella and other members of his team in the legislation division of the Department worked very closely with the Parliamentary Counsel and his staff. Again, a great deal of forbearance and patience was necessary on the part of our external advisers. In the Department itself, people can imagine that some of the battles were, if not quite bitter, at times very heated. Those in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel were working with a very different approach. I place on record a tribute to all those people. I think this legislation will, hopefully, be a precedent for rewriting much more Commonwealth legislation in a way that is accessible.

I say in conclusion that, if there is one Act of a Federal Parliament that ought to belong to the people of Australia, it is the Social Security Act. In this case, this Act is much more the people's Act as a result of these clarifying amendments, albeit on the basis of existing policy.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee annual report, I congratulate the Committee on its report and the work it does in promoting soil conservation activities across Australia. In recent years we have often heard of several pressing issues in environmental matters which have been competing for the public's attention, including energy, pollution and the greenhouse effect, but soil degradation would be our most basic issue. Often in the media it is forgotten and there do not seem to be many votes in this issue when politicians parade before the public their concerns about the environment. Yet, as I have said, soil degradation would be Australia's number one environmental issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing is more important to a nation's environment than its soil and the preservation of the quality of its land. The loss of our thin and fragile soil, the progressive degradation of our land and the expansion of the desert and arid areas of the Australian continent are our number one environmental challenges. Left unmet, the result will be a disaster on a massive scale for Australia. By 1983 about 66 per cent of all our lands were in need of some conservation measures. Significant long term problems have also arisen as a result of the progressive breaking down of the structure of Australian soils.

Soil conservation is of particular importance not only to the greenies to whom this Government and the media are often pandering, but it is of vital importance to those Australians who often have much more to do with the environment, and that is the man and woman on the land.

Only in the past few years has soil degradation come a little into focus. This is partly because, during the past few years, Australia has experienced a series of storms, droughts and floods which were directly or indirectly related to the problem. I was very interested to read in our Queensland newspaper, the Courier-Mail, this morning a letter by Mrs Patsy Bell from Boonah telling about how Boonah had recently had eight inches of rain in five hours and, regrettably, much of its topsoil had been washed away. Also, the nation's stocktaking during the Bicentenary brought a reawakening of concern for what has been happening to Australia's land. It is estimated that about half of Australia's rural land requires treatment for land degradation. Human activity has been responsible for about half of that degradation.

The report is certainly quite lengthy. There is just one thing that I want to talk about in relation to the Landcare program. The report says the objectives of the community Landcare support sub-program are as follows:

- - to increase the development and adoption of sustainable land use practices at a local or district level by assisting with extension, planning, research and training projects by landholder-based community groups, with support from State and local government agencies.

In the South Burnett district where I live, one person who has been active in this field is Kingaroy Anglican priest, Reverend Stuart James. Last year he was named the Landcare individual of the year at an awards ceremony in Brisbane. The Reverend James said, `We pray for our daily bread, but if we don't look after the land our prayers won't be answered. There is no such thing as a free cut lunch'. In other words, he has gone from saving soil to saving souls as far as being a priest is concerned because he was involved in soil conservation in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy at Kingaroy before he retired and became a priest at Wondai. I would like to congratulate Reverend James on achieving this award and on his activities which are recognised throughout my own State of Queensland.

There was also the group from Pittsworth on the Darling Downs which took out the community award at the ceremony. This group, which was formed only about 19 months ago, has 90 members and is actively encouraging land restoration through seminars, field days and farm walks, while Winton graziers Charlie and Ann Phillott are Queensland nominees for the national Landcare producer award. I want to say congratulations to these people who have really done so well in looking after the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on one particular aspect of the annual report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee and, that is, the allocation of funding to the Northern Territory. It is interesting to note also that the national soil conservation program received an allocation of $23.184m in 1989-90 which, the report says, brings the total level of funding since the program's introduction in 1983 to $54.97m. It is quite obvious to me, using a little quick arithmetic, that from 1983 to 1989, $31.786m was spent on national soil conservation, but for the year 1989-90 almost $23.2m was spent. So there was quite a significant increase in that program's funding last year which, I think, shows that the Government is, at last, realising the importance of this national problem and, as my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, how serious it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out a concern I have. The Select Committee on Animal Welfare held hearings in the Northern Territory and I know that money has been set aside for the programs up there; in particular, a total of $38,000 for land conservation at the Victoria River Downs range. I believe most of that problem would have been caused by feral donkeys of which there are some 66,000 roaming that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a couple on the other side, too.

—I thank Senator Baume. One has to see for oneself the degradation, not only of native pastures but also of the waterways and the magnificent conservation area in Kakadu Park, that has been caused by feral buffaloes.
—I did not think there were any buffaloes left.

—I can assure Senator Panizza that there are buffaloes there. We actually saw what had happened in the past, and to see the way that nature has rehabilitated that area in the short time since those buffaloes were removed is something to behold.

SPEECH.PARA: Soil conservation is a national problem. In that particular part of Australia-the Northern Territory-one of the things that is putting great pressure on the fragile soil is the vast number of feral animals which are ranging the Top End. They are many and varied from buffaloes to pigs, goats, horses, one-humped camels and Bali cattle. As I said, feral pigs and cats between them are causing severe problems not just to the soil, I might add, but to the native animals that already exist there.

It was quite a shock to us to note that in the Top End there were something like 283,000 buffalo prior to 1985. The mess they made was something else. There was a total of 83,000 donkeys; 200,000 wild horses; something like 20 million rabbits-one can imagine the soil conservation problems they were causing; 25,000 camels; and 1.7 million cattle.

The fragile environment in northern Australia is certainly under pressure from the soil conservation point of view particularly, as I said earlier, from feral animals. Those feral animals, at the same time, have caused some 50 species of native animals to become extinct and I think that in itself is a tragedy. Animals and mammals like the lesser bilby, the central hare-wallaby, the short-tailed hopping mouse and the crescent nailtail wallaby have all become extinct in the period of time that these feral animals have been roaming the Top End. I fully support the Government's feral animal control in the Top End and I congratulate it, although it has acted a bit too late, on increasing the funding for soil conservation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee to the Senate, but there are just a couple of points that I would like to take up in it. The establishment of the national soil conservation program fund is referred to in the report as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Act establishes a trust fund from which payments for projects, other than State and Commonwealth projects, are made. Provision is also made for bequests or gifts to the National Soil Conservation Program to be paid into this trust fund.

I just hope that money is forthcoming for the national soil conservation program and for soil conservation generally around Australia. I believe that soil is a very easily erodable and degradable resource and, whilst maintaining and achieving the maximum return for it in our lifetime, we must improve and protect it for future generations. That was a saying of George Knowles, who was the soil conservation commissioner in New South Wales many years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very decent fellow too, I might add.
—Was he a South Australian or a Western Australian?
—He's just a relative.

—I know he was a great New South Wales soil conservationist and we appreciated what he did in New South Wales. I notice, also, the aims and objectives of the national soil conservation program. The program has five major goals. One of those is that all lands in Australia be used within their capability. I make the point to the Senate that the pressure that is being put on land resources in Australia at the moment because of the policies of this Government, because of the high interest rates, because of the fact that the land-holder is really having to work his land to the nth degree to try to get just a living out of it, will cause big problems for soil conservation and for the degradation of land in the future. It is something that the Government has to take in hand, and realise that more money will have to be forthcoming to allow people not to mine their country. That will have to happen soon because of the downturn in prices and the input costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point in the report that I would like to take up relates to the general principles of the structure of the national soil conservation program which are to encourage self-help by locally-based community landcare groups. There are a few problems associated with the money getting through to the soil conservation programs in the States. The money is not flowing as quickly as it should. There is a problem in that sometimes plans are put in for landcare group programs and there is a delay between the State reviewing the program and approval by the Federal Government. I hope that Senator Bolkus, the Minister at the table, takes that back to the Minister responsible and tells him that there is a big problem at the moment. What happens if the money does not get through? If enthusiasm for the program is not kept going, there will be a loss of eagerness and gradually people will drift away. That is something that I have been talking about for quite some time.

I would also like to tell the Senate of the horrific problems associated with heavy rains in the north in the last little while. There were seven inches of rain in one area: the Berambil, Big Jacks Creek, Millers Creek, Yarrambar Creek and Warrah Creek catchments, which all converge onto Pine Ridge on the Liverpool Plains. That is one of the richest areas in Australia as far as soil is concerned. I recently toured that area and, if money is not forthcoming and this Government does not realise that it must look at these bigger projects, bigger catchment groups-by the way, New South Wales has led the way in total catchment management-we will lose some of our beautiful resources. When representatives from areas such as that come to the Government asking for big national soil conservation programs to be put into those areas, this Government should take on hand what is being put to it, look sympathetically at those people and look to the future of Australia by making sure those areas are protected for future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee on the national soil conservation program, I must say, first of all, that I am pleased to see the progress that has been made. I also make a couple of brief comments about Western Australia where 75 per cent of all agricultural areas and about 80 per cent of pastoral areas are now covered by landcare districts. This constitutes about 75 per cent to 80 per cent of all the landcare districts in Australia. I am particularly pleased to see Senator Panizza sitting here. His district was the third one established in Western Australia. That is where it all began.
—It should have been the first, but anyhow.

—Yes, but you were a bit slower than the rest of us. I want to talk about a couple of things in the broader context. The first is that, with the downturn in the wheat industry, and the wool industry in particular, which are the two big land users in Australia, both agricultural and pastoral-I hope that Senator Bolkus, the Minister at the table, is listening to what I have to say-at this stage it is very important that the national soil conservation program be resourced properly and the funding be used very carefully. With the downturn in income, the resources available to individual farmers will be eroded significantly.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Minister's attention to the fact-and I raised this matter in Estimates-that we still do not have in place an effective mechanism for approving farm plans. One of the contingencies of qualifying for the assistance given in the last Budget was that there had to be an approved farm plan. Until that mechanism is put in place, those farmers who involve themselves will not have the incentives to assist them in putting the program in place. In addition to raising this matter in Estimates I have raised it with Minister Kerin and Senator Cook, as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in this chamber.

It is of paramount importance that the issue be addressed. It is an indictment of the Government that this situation has continued since the August Budget last year and we still have not had an answer. I re-emphasise the importance of the total funding structure and the mechanisms that are available being used with the utmost efficiency. The resources in farmers' hands are very limited at this time.

The other point that I draw to the attention of the Minister-I hope that he takes it back to his colleagues who are responsible-is the situation with the landcare program and the national soil conservation program. Quite clearly, now that the political advantages from having a landcare program have gone, it is time to unite these two programs. If we examine the two reports which I have here, we find that the function of the landcare program last year was virtually to transfer $23.4m to the national soil conservation program. If ever we had an instance of duplication of two programs, this is it. There are two boards, two infrastructures and two bureaucracies behind these programs. There is no need whatsoever to continue with the wastage that occurs in the administrative side of these two programs. I am not decrying the programs; I am just saying that it is time to think about utilising them better, getting the resources out into the field where they will be more effective and not tying them into two programs. There is little point in continuing one government landcare program whose function it is to transfer funds to another program.

In the remaining few seconds available to me, I draw the Senate's attention to one point concerning the national soil conservation program. It is very pleasing to see that soil structure decline, invasion of productive land by native woody shrubs and water repellency are being looked at. These three things are not obvious in terms of soil conservation yet they are problems. They are very important in terms of the impact of wind erosion. It is very important to broaden our horizons when looking at these problems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Jones:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intriguing thing about the annual report of the Canberra Institute of the Arts is that it is the annual report for 1988 and we are dealing with it in 1991. I concede that it came forward towards the end of last year but it is not a terribly zappy way of reporting to the Parliament. The body no longer exists. This does indicate some of the problems that this Government is having with its arts bodies. The supreme arts body is the Australia Council, which is in charge of spending the largest amount of money that the Government invests in the arts. I must say that generally I believe it is a sound investment. My criticisms are only at the margin, although there are some pretty substantial margins. I do have some criticism about the way it is managed.

SPEECH.PARA: When looking at the management of the arts and, hopefully, early and sound reporting of the management of the arts, it is important to note that there is a chairman of the reporting body. I remind the Senate that there is still no chairman of the Australia Council, as I mentioned the other day in the Senate. I have been assured by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) that an appointment will be made shortly. In fact, today's Australian reveals that that person is to be Rodney Hall. This follows the rejection of the job by Miss Noni Hazelhurst when she was told that she could not have an extra $80,000 a year on top of what Professor Donald Horne had received.

That raises some interesting points. Apart from the fact that it is quite clear that Mr Rodney Hall will be only the second choice, this job has been hawked around considerably for some time. The ill feeling that has developed is evident from a letter that Professor Horne wrote to Miss Hazelhurst when he became aware that Noni Hazelhurst had asked for this extra money to lift her salary from that which Professor Horne was paid of $21,000 for working one day a week to $100,000 for a full time position. The letter states:

``I wonder if anyone informed you of the possible consequences of the chairman becoming full-time earning $100,000 a year?'' he wrote in his December 21 letter, the day after Ms Hazelhurst issued her public statement.
``The difference between that and the $21,000 I received is the equivalent of two positions on the Australia Council staff.
``In other words, in a staff already debilitated by economies, there would have to be a further reduction of two places.

``In addition to this I should imagine that, due to your lack of administrative experience, you would have required one or perhaps two staff to assist you. So that means a total reduction in staff of three or four people.
``I was also wondering whether you had been counselled as to possible reactions from the public if you had been appointed as a full-time chairman . . .
``It would have been, to my mind, an extraordinary misallocation of scarce resources to have both a chairman on $100,000 and a general manager on $100,000.''

That is what Professor Horne apparently wrote to Ms Hazelhurst. According to the media reports Mr Hall is prepared to take that post on a part time basis but we do not know whether he will get $21,000, as Professor Horne got, or something in between that figure and the $100,000.

What has happened to the Australia Council clearly shows a lack of real concern by the Government for the Council and for the arts in general. Its delay in getting around to appointing a chairman-the second, third, fourth, fifth or sixth choice; who knows-is far worse than the delay of the Canberra Institute of the Arts producing its annual report for 1988. Both indicate a pretty poor approach to the requirement, first, to report and, secondly, to the bodies that they represent. I only hope that Mr Hall gets better support as chairman of the Australia Council than the position received from this Government in its failure to appoint a chairman for so long after it was evident that Professor Horne was retiring.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING TRIBUNAL: TELEVISION VIOLENCE IN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Collins:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments about the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report entitled TV Violence in Australia. This subject has had wide community concern. It is encouraging to note that the interest of the public in the inquiry was overwhelming, with 1,114 individuals and organisations making submissions. This only emphasises the degree of concern about the issue in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Next to the family, television is probably the most important influence on child development in our society. Indeed, these days when children watch so much television, we might say it has even more influence, and I do not know whether it is always for the good. Children view an average of three to five hours of television daily. By the time they graduate from high school, the average adolescent will have spent more time in front of the television than in the classroom. The popularity of television is easy to understand. It informs us, it entertains us and it can keep us company. Television, to use its own cliche, brings the world into our living rooms. People can now have the opportunity to watch the Senate and the House of Representatives on television. I do not know quite how many people watch it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it's R-rated.

—Sometimes it is, but I want to deal with the effects on children of extensive television exposure. That should concern us. Television viewing may be linked with: violent or aggressive behaviour; obesity, because some people eat while they sit and watch television by the hour; poor academic performance; active sexual behaviour; and the use of drugs or alcohol. I know that such programs have such a critical influence that the Chairman in the preface wrote that:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence which emerged provides compelling reasons for considering the recommendations in relation to other areas of the media: for example, Pay Television, if and when it begins in Australia.

Thus it is essential that television be used as a positive, creative force and to avoid its negative influences. Until now television stations have been feeding the Australian community a steady and constant diet of violence and tasteless entertainment. This is not only in their normal programming but also in their so-called news and current affairs programs. When watching the night-time news, especially since the Gulf war started, we certainly get plenty of stories about violence. I am sure that this would play upon the minds of children watching these programs.

It has been estimated that by current standards an average viewer will see some 45,000 murders or attempted murders on television by the age of 21 years. This standard diet of violence is not only de-sensitising the community and young people in particular to violence but also encouraging an acceptance of violence as a norm of behaviour. Indeed, I sometimes wonder whether that is the reason why violent crimes seem to be increasing. I could talk about many of the programs on television in which violence takes place and which seem to be typical of this.

The standard of television stations should improve. Perhaps following aggregation, people in rural outback areas will have more choice of programs and will be able to turn to something else. I have always believed that parents have a great responsibility when their children watch television. These days many parents can never say no to their children. They never say, `That is not suitable. Turn it off'. I often feel rather sad about this. The report maintains that the best response to the acknowledged community concern about violence on television is by way of supervised self-regulation by television licensees. In the preface the Chairman wrote that:

. . . until the release of our research and the conduct of public conferences, the commercial television industry had not fully addressed or even accepted that the public was concerned by the portrayal of violence on television.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Robert Ray is here. I refer to a strict undertaking given to me by Mr Duffy, the then Minister, and by Mr Hawke. I am waiting for that undertaking to be honoured. In fact, I assume that it will be honoured after the current review has taken place and that the undertakings given will find expression in the amendments to the Broadcasting legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I am ruled out of order, I relate what I have said to the report entitled TV Violence in Australia. One of the problems with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is that it does not have a statutory obligation to consult, other than with licensees. In this exercise clearly it did consult, and consulted broadly. The submission received showed the extent of concern in the community about the level of violent programs on Australian television. It must be recognised that broadcasting and television help to shape personal values and mass culture.

This report urges that action be taken to lessen the level of violence that is currently on television. But I think the recommendation that there be a self-regulatory code is inadequate. There are several problems with that. One is how the code is to be established. There are certain recommendations about that-about the Minister being involved; about the industry being involved; about the Tribunal being involved; and so on.

I might point out that under the existing legislation there is provision which envisages the exclusion of programs which are blasphemous, indecent or obscene. From memory, I think this comes under section 119. It is important to remember that section when establishing the code. The undertaking given to me included an acceptance that there was a need to establish and maintain program standards relating to violence, sex and drugs, which appropriately reflected the community's standards for television. I am not talking about theatre; I am talking about television.

The second point was that the Tribunal should have greater powers to take disciplinary action in between hearings of licence renewals. At present, the Tribunal can exercise either a feather duster power or the sledge hammer power-the denial of license renewal. In some circumstances the latter punishment is too severe and the former too light. There should be something in between. This was a subject for consideration and agreement at that time.

The third matter concerns the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I am talking about something that happened some four years ago-I cannot remember the actual date but I will get it for the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), if he wants it. Even then it was agreed that the ABC was a law unto itself in respect of program standards and, of course, some other arenas as well. It was considered that there ought to be some independent body to which complaints should be made about the program standards of the ABC.
I thought it might be appropriate to remind the Minister and the Government of these things. Mr Duffy knows what I am talking about and so does the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of some of the things that Senator Harradine has taken up. He says that he was given an indication or a firm commitment by Mr Duffy and Mr Hawke. I did not pick up exactly what that was from what he said. Do I take it that it was in terms of a complaints body for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)?
—There are three points.

—I will have a look at the honourable senator's speech and make sure that these matters are drawn to their attention and, of course, the attention of the current Minister who, while not morally obliged to keep deals made by previous Ministers--
—It is an understanding.

—I am sorry-an understanding. I know that I am very unsubtle and crude in the way that I put things. Whilst they are not compelled to, it is always regarded as desirable to if those undertakings have been given.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take those matters up. I will draw them to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). I do recall Mr Beazley answering a question in the Parliament, I think, last week on the third leg of the matter raised by the honourable senator, which caused some aggravation around the ABC groupies area. Nevertheless, I am sure that is going to proceed. Of course, the whole Broadcasting Act is being totally reviewed at the moment. I would also suggest that Senator Harradine write to the people concerned and remind them of his views on the subject.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the second annual report of the Privacy Commissioner on the operation of the Privacy Act. It is of concern to me that no senator has spoken to date in the chamber on this report. I do not want the opportunity to pass without raising issues that the Privacy Commissioner addressed in his report.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1989 the Privacy Commissioner claimed that increased delegation, multiskilling and computers meant that the possibility for corruption-that is, for the providing of private information about citizens to other organisations such as banks and financial institutions-was increasing. He also claimed that it was incumbent upon departments to implement monitoring and security practices to minimise the likely occurrence of the problem and to ascertain how it occurred when it does occur. He also claimed that the receivers and those who benefit from this information must also be deterred. He said that to meet these ends the criminal law should be changed so that parties to this information, including the principals, could be effectively prosecuted.

He suggested too that the Privacy Act be amended so that he could investigate such occurrences and impose damages on procurers of such information. Having looked at what the Privacy Commissioner has said in the previous annual report, I was concerned to find on page 14 that he refers to the problem of corrupt disclosure, and says:

Last year's annual report referred to the problem of corrupt disclosure by officers of Commonwealth agencies; and noted that an agency may have done all it could to avert breach of security by an employee, only to find that information has been released to outsiders for a price. There were press reports in the early part of 1989 (which have continued during this year) referring to the activities of private investigators, who pay for information held in government agencies. It was recommended in the Privacy Commissioner's last annual report that the Government should consider amending:
1. If necessary, the criminal law, to enable those that are parties to these transactions to be prosecuted and possibly to place some direct liability on the principals.
2. The Privacy Act, to allow the Privacy Commissioner to investigate the entire circumstances in which these events occur.
3. The Privacy Act, so as to impose on those that procure the improper disclosure of personal information liability in damages.
He is repeating the same things that he said in 1989. The Privacy Commissioner continues:
No action has yet been taken on proposals 2 and 3. As to proposal 1, there has been a limited but important response.

The Social Security Act has been amended to incorporate a new offence provision which makes it an offence for a person either directly or through an agent or employee, to solicit, receive, use or disclose information concerning a client without lawful excuse or authority. Offering to, or holding oneself out as being able to supply protected information is also an offence . . .
The problem of corrupt disclosure has-perhaps inevitably-continued to arise.

I have not been able to investigate the authenticity of this facsimile which has been forwarded to me, therefore I will not refer to the name of the company, but it is an investigating company in Sydney. It states:
To whom it may concern.

As requested by your office, we are now enclosing particulars of inquiries and searches we are currently using in an effort to locate missing persons. We hope we may be of assistance to you in the near future.

We find that we can have a check done, a search of motor transport records. It is $8 for New South Wales searches and between $20 and $40 for interstate checks. A search of the social security records will ascertain whether the debtor is receiving a pension or unemployment benefits. It will give the latest address on record and the date of last payment. This can be carried out in all States for $20. For another $20 one can get a search of Medicare records or a search of Immigration Department records or ascertain whether the debtor has left the country. The records show the flight number and date of departure. They also show whether the debtor has arrived in the country and give the flight number and date of arrival. This search does not give a destination. Bits of information are not given.

A full check of some of these items would be $30. There are phone checks, post box checks, criminal history checks and all sorts of other services. It is claimed that there are 44 agents Australia-wide. It ought to be of great concern to honourable senators in this chamber that that practice still continues. The Privacy Commissioner addressed this issue last year and is readdressing it this year. In his report, he states:

As the Privacy Act stands at present, personal information held by a Commonwealth agency can be corruptly disclosed by a Commonwealth officer to an outsider, and nothing can be done about it under the Privacy Act . . .

He says that remedies should be taken to ensure this is not so and that he has some power or that other measures are taken. I put on notice that I will be moving a motion at a later date that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs addresses the issues that the Privacy Commissioner raises. Obviously, if the Government is not going to raise these matters, a Senate committee ought to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I note that the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council (FIRDC), which operates under the Fishing Industry Research and Development Act, first met in October 1988. This annual report is the first full year of operation of the Council, so we are dealing with the early stages of development of this particular body and its research. In the Executive Summary, the report states:
The Council has the responsibility to fund research and development (R& ) in Australia for the benefit of the fishing industry.
It further defines its function during the year as follows:
. . . the development of two important proactive projects: A national seafood consumption study and a compilation of available national fisheries statistics.
Under the Council's objectives it states:
In broad terms Council's objective is to fund research and development (R &D) which will improve the economic position of the fishing industry consistent with the general needs of the community-
I stress the following point-
and within the limits of sustainable economic production.

One could not agree more with that. It is a very desirable aim. I return to the theme which I was dealing with in an earlier paper this afternoon: the destruction of over half of the mangrove areas around Port Adelaide and the imminent imposition on that area of the multifunction polis (MFP) which will effectively prevent any reconstruction of those mangrove areas and over the next 40 to 50 years will progressively mean the loss of the remaining half of the mangroves.

As sea levels rise, the area subsides. It has been established that the area is subsiding at about one to two millimetres a year, and that additionally leads to the drowning of the mangroves in the aquatic reserve areas around Barker Reach. Under the Council's objectives, the report continues:
conserve existing viable fisheries, in particular where species are vulnerable or habitats are under threat;

I simply point yet again to the way in which this Government, and specifically Senator Button-he is hell bent on imposing this MFP on the Port Adelaide region-and his Australian Labor Party colleague, Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, are proceeding to impose a major habitat destruction on Port Adelaide which will result in the loss of both commercial and recreational fishing at Port Adelaide.
Just the other day I was speaking to a longstanding colleague of mine who has worked in the Fisheries Department in South Australia for, I would say, 30 years. He was pointing out that most of-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was it?

—I would prefer not to divulge the name of this officer. But the information which I am about to give honourable senators is in the public domain anyway; it has been covered in a press release by the Fisheries Department and also broadcast on Channel 10 in Adelaide. The information is that it has discovered that some 80 to 90 per cent of three commercial species which are fished in the St Vincent's Gulf-namely, the king and queen scallop, and the abalone-together with about five other species of molluscs, which are not of commercial interest, have died this season in the mid-water; that is, about 15 metres of depth water in St Vincent's Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: Inquiries as to the cause of that reveal that there is no viral cause, no bacterial cause and no pollutional cause; but the waters in St Vincent's Gulf at that depth are the warmest that they have ever been. The implication quite clearly is that this may-although there is no proof of it-be an early effect of greenhouse warming. Adelaide has certainly had some very high temperatures during this summer. So, we have imposed this environmentally destructive MFP project on an area which is already under severe threat. I note, therefore, that in the amount of money which this--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Michael Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING FOR THE 1991-93 TRIENNIUM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to take note of the document. In glancing at the document, with its list of statistics, it is impressive. However, the figures that are presented in this report really are not surprising. In fact, the 1993 allocations essentially represent a continuation of the 1992 allocations. There are the normal adjustments for inflation and some programs shift ground a little, such as the Aboriginal initiatives program, which is now incorporated in the base operating grant. The rolling triennium does give institutions some financial security. But when we look at the entire document, all it does is demonstrate that policy changes are needed and that the allocations in the current triennium will require substantial supplementation to avert what will be a disaster in Australia's higher education system unless something is done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, and there have been for some time, considerable and growing resource demands in higher education; to ignore those would be a crime. A report which should be read in conjunction with this Department of Employment, Education and Training higher education funding report is the recently released Blandy report on the academic labour market. It confirms the worst predictions of a crisis in academic staff shortages.

The Blandy report was commissioned by the Federal Government. It predicts a national shortage of up to 19,000 academic staff by the end of the decade. We must read the Blandy report in conjunction with this report; this report really cannot stand alone. It does not make sense unless we take that into account. As soon as we take that into account, what is needed is greater contribution from the Government towards the funding for higher education. The Blandy report also finds that poor academic salaries and conditions are in fact a major cause of the failure to attract suitably qualified academic staff, in Australia and from overseas. It foresees an inevitable decline in teaching and research standards.

In Australia we have a huge unmet demand for tertiary places. That demand continues to outstrip the student load. This report, which we wish the Senate to take note of, gives insufficient attention to those findings. Action must be taken immediately to encourage students to attain higher education degrees to make that academic career more attractive. Of course, the tertiary fees that are applic- able at the moment do not do a thing to make that academic career more attractive. The higher education contribution scheme really is working against the solutions which are suggested for higher education staffing.

As a first step, we could extend the exemption to the higher education contribution scheme to everybody doing masters degrees, PhDs, or higher degrees of any description, especially including those who are involved in part time studies. They should not be penalised for having a part time job while they are doing it. Unless we take the projected acute shortage of academics seriously, we really cannot make any sense of this now often dismissed description of the `clever country' phrase. It is mere rhetoric. To encourage postgraduate studies really requires a commitment beyond producing the report that has the statistics but not the answers.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Short:
That the Senate-

(a) notes the damning admission on 8 February 1991 of policy failure by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that `the Government did not want a recession, it wanted a slowdown' and that `it is a slowdown, not a recession, that Australia requires';

(b) notes the equally stunning admission by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Sunday program on 10 February 1991 that `we obviously got wrong a proposition that said that there would not be a recession';
