SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the cutting edge of the Government's failure in economic policy are the young people of Australia. The Senate is well aware of the cruel statistics of unemployment among young Australians. I want to dramatise today not the facts that the Senate is aware of but some hidden facts about unemployment of young Australians that show an even more severe and depressing consequence of this Government's incompetence than the raw statistics show. The raw statistics are bad enough. For January, for example, they showed something like a 25.8 per cent unemployment rate among young people aged between 15 and 19 years. That compares with the January 1982 figure of 21.3 per cent. It also compares with the 25.9 per cent figure for December 1990. As the Senate is well aware, that was something like the worst December figure for seven years.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is far worse than that. The situation is being hidden by Government spending on arrangements that massively reduce the number of young people coming onto the job market. We would have no complaint with that if the money were being spent on improving the prospects of young people in getting jobs. I believe that there is some question over the extent to which the device the Government is using, which is Austudy, is in fact providing to a large degree any increase in the ability of the young people returning to school only as a result of Austudy to better their way of life and to get jobs.

Let us face it-this Government is spending an amount well over $300m on secondary school Austudy, which is benefiting something like 160,000 to 170,000 young Australians. They are basically the people who may well have left school had there not been Austudy for secondary students and have come flooding on to the job market, the way so many have, thus worsening the situation and simply not being able to get jobs.

I know that in my area of Illawarra, for example, the unemployment rate among young people aged under 20 and looking for full time work is 36 to 37 per cent. It is interesting to see what the consequences for these unemployment rates are of the Government's extension of Austudy a few years ago to secondary students. I quote from the Budget Papers:

AUSTUDY is available, subject to certain academic criteria, to full-time secondary and tertiary students aged 16 years and over undertaking either an approved secondary or accredited tertiary course . . . Assistance is targeted to low income groups through income and assets tests applying to the student and, for dependent students, to parents as well.

As I mentioned, the 1990 projected figure for those who will be receiving this benefit is 164,000. This benefit, by the way, was not available in the last recession, in 1982-83. There is no doubt that the groups being funded-the targeted area is low income groups-would be more prone to unemployment than those in higher income groups who do not receive the benefit of Austudy. So there is no doubt that Austudy itself is diminishing the number of people coming onto the job market-that is, secondary school Austudy-and in particular diminishing the number of people coming on to the job market who would probably have a worse chance of getting a job than the average of those who have failed to get jobs. Even if we adopt the average figure of about one in four-that is, that one in four of Australians coming onto the job market cannot get full time jobs-if we applied that to the 164,000 young people receiving Austudy in secondary schools, we would get an increase of something like 41,000 in the number of young Australians unemployed. When we look at the December figure, which was 138,700 young Australians unemployed, we should probably add 41,000 or so to that to get up to around 180,000 young Australians who are in fact unemployed even though 41,000 of them have decided to go back to school because there is no point in their trying to get work.

The reality is, of course, that something like 80,000 of those people getting Austudy would have had difficulty finding jobs and as a result are going back to school. In other words, the hidden level of unemployment that has emerged from the Government's extension of Austudy into secondary education pushes the figures for those young people who are seeking jobs, or would want jobs if they were available, to well over the recession figures of 1982-83. Honourable senators will remember that that recession was drought induced-the worst drought for 50 years in Australia-backed by deteriorating world economic conditions. This recession is one that the Treasurer says we had to have, that he engineered and has nothing to do, basically, with the world economy. So these figures dramatise the serious problem of hidden unemployment, making the position even worse than the horrendous figures for youth unemployment that are coming out now from the Australian Statistician.

I believe that this is even further evidenced by the fact that young people are staying on at school because they cannot get jobs. This has meant a substantial increase, almost a doubling in fact, of the retention rates in secondary schools from something like a third of those entering school to about two-thirds. As I say, to the extent that improves their training, their background and their capacity to earn, obviously there is a net benefit. But I wonder whether in fact this is really taking place in all instances or whether to some extent Austudy has to turned the schools into a young Australians' minding operation to keep young Australians out of a super-saturated job market where they could not get jobs. Something like 36 per cent-a little over one third-of secondary students aged 16 and over are being assisted by Austudy this year. That accounts for the doubling of the retention rate in secondary schools-that is, if all those people had not been prepared to continue at school without Austudy.

We have here, I believe, a tragic situation which looks as though it can only get worse, with about 200,000 or maybe more young Australians out of work and not likely to get work. Let us recognise that these figures of genuine unemployment are being hidden at massive cost to the Australian taxpayer. As I said, well over $320m is being spent on secondary Austudy, and on top of that there is the enormous pressure on the State governments to increase the facilities in secondary schools to cope with the enormous increase in retention rates. With hidden unemployment and the facts of unemployment as they are, it reinforces what the Opposition has been saying: that the young people of Australia are at the cutting edge, are the major sufferers from the Keating recession that we had to have. I hope that the young people of Australia recognise that they deserve more in terms of the government they get than the sort of government that the Hawke Administration has given them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the proposition that stands in the name of Senator Short and to defend the Government's record and its policy prescription. In joining a debate it is always instructive for any speaker to look initially very carefully at the proposal that has been outlined. I find the proposal that originates with the Opposition very disappointing in the four points it seeks to make because it is an extraordinarily negative document. The four-point proposition is critical of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and then moves on to condemn the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point urges the Government to pursue policies advocated for so long by the coalition to restore sustainable private sector growth and employment. But where is the policy prescription? Where is the positive agenda? There is not one word specified below the policy initiative in the document. There is not one word by way of the outlining of an alternative policy mix. It indicates quite simply and beyond doubt that the long period of opposition has engendered sterility. Just prior to coming into the chamber I was talking with Mr Fred Daly in Senator Jones's office. Mr Daly made the point when he looked at this proposition from the Opposition that it was reminiscent of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in the 1950s, when something was put on paper just to be put on paper.

There is only one advantage in the proposal that we are debating this afternoon. The sole element is that it does enable the Senate to choose between two alternatives: the Labor Government that is endeavouring to come to grips with problems in a policy framework that has an agenda, and an Opposition that simply runs slogans. For too long the Labor Party in its long period of opposition did that, not only to our cost but also to the cost of the Australian people.

The Opposition does lack a coherent response. I listened to almost all the debate a week or so ago when the motion first came before the Senate. I waited to hear a single Opposition initiative by way of breaking ground on policy, but not one was put forward by any of the Opposition speakers. This does suggest that the Opposition simply cannot construct a policy mix beyond running off some 17-second television grabs.

For a start, there is no evidence of a wages policy anywhere, and no initiatives in fiscal policy beyond a slogan, `We will slash $3 billion off current expenditures'. The Opposition has to come close to political lunacy to pursue that in a time of current recession. Slashing $3 billion off Federal expenditures, as every senator knows, would simply mean greater contraction and greater hardship, particularly amongst working men and women and their families. It would also mean a considerably greater number of jobless and a total elimination of confidence. And, of course, those cuts in expenditure, given the measures that have been adopted by the Labor Government over the last seven years to eliminate waste, would be concentrated in the areas of social security, health and education. That cannot be an excuse for a policy. It is little bit like the old song about Quinn the Eskimo.

This Government has had a phenomenal record in terms of employment growth, which is first class by comparison with any other country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). But that is not to say that the most recent unemployment figures are troubling. There is no question about that. That has to be said immediately. We have the highest employment, in fact, since the coalition was in power. But we might pause momentarily to look at the circumstances when the coalition was in power and when there was a conservative majority not only in the House of Representatives but also in this chamber until the middle of 1978.

The coalition engendered double digit achievements in both unemployment and inflation. Many policy changes have had to be introduced since that time during the life of this Government. Many of the policy changes have been introduced after careful negotiation with the Australian community as represented by interest groups, and opinion has been carried across the board. Senator Cook repeatedly makes that valid point in this chamber in terms of dealing with industrial relations.

We should compare and contrast the policy changes of this Government with the slogans that we hear from the other side of the chamber. For example, we continually hear that Australia needs reform in transport and telecommunications. Senator Knowles specialises in this kind of sloganeering. But how? Where are the hard decisions going to be made that have not yet been taken? Where are the difficult decisions going to be taken? What is being proposed by the Liberal and National parties? What is the coalition's agenda? We also hear repeatedly that we must have a simpler tax system. How? What less tax is going to be raised?

TALK.START.PARA: —Vouchers.
—Vouchers, Senator Bell interjects quite legitimately. What absolute and utter nonsense! Vouchers could be introduced for conservative party preselection.
—A voucher-led recovery.

—A voucher-led recovery. The laughter also indicates a response not only of the Parliament but also of opinion leaders in the Australian community generally. Where on earth are we going to see additional revenue generated if taxes are going to be cut in unspecified areas?

SPEECH.PARA: We hear continual talk on waterfront reform. There is no doubt that this Government has concrete and definite proposals that are coming into play for reforming the Australian waterfront. There is also no doubt of the necessity for reform there. But waterfront reform for the Liberal and National parties, of course, is always equated simply with making working people redundant. There is no agenda beyond that.

It is time-honoured in this country's history amongst the conservative parties that working people are held responsible for economic downturn-and I note that Senator Kernot nods agreement. Working people, according to the Liberal and National parties, are always to be held responsible when the country goes into a economic slump because, in the view of those parties, working people are always expendable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, even now.
—Even now on the Liberal and National Party agenda; there is no question about that.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of reform of government operations, what are we dealing with by way of a coalition alternative? We are told to `shake up GBEs' but, again, there is no detail at all. I heard Opposition senators talking about reform of the immigration program but not once was there an indication of changes to be made, of a new direction or of policy initiatives. Indeed, there was no suggestion of which categories of potential immigrants would be placed under greater scrutiny. We have got to remember that over one million people apply to come to Australia every year but less than 10 per cent are accepted. So if there are going to be changes, as the coalition appears to be demanding, where would the greater scrutiny be placed and where would the liberalisation occur? Where would the tightening occur? There is no policy again; a total intellectual void. We have in this debate a string of cliches from the Opposition tending to be delivered these days by professionals.

We also hear endlessly from the Opposition about what needs to be done with Qantas. People are calling for 100 per cent sale. The Government has opted, sensibly in my view, for a sale of up to 49 per cent of equity. If the Qantas issue was so pressing during the period 1975 through to 1983, why on earth did the Fraser government not act then? Let me remind everybody that Malcolm Fraser was a Prime Minister in the style of Billy Hughes. When Mr Fraser put pen to paper the law of the Commonwealth of Australia could be written because he had a comfortable majority in both Houses. Why on earth was no action taken at the time?

We hear that the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions should be scrapped and this, apparently, passes for policy from those opposite. But replace it with what-the record of 1982 when we had stagflation where interest rates were rising; where there was the remains of a wages explosion; where inflation was up; where unemployment was up; and where the only elements in Australian economic indicators that were receding were business and consumer confidence, and both of those elements approaching bedrock?

As my colleague Senator Maguire made clear last week in an excellent contribution to this debate, the consumption tax is perhaps the greatest nonsense that we have seen from the other side in very recent times, because a consumption tax would be both discriminatory and regressive. Since the period of 1985 and the National Tax Summit, the Labor Government has systematically and comprehensively reformed Australian taxation rules. The record speaks for itself in terms of not only making the taxation laws better and fairer but also introducing equity in the methods of collection. Overall income tax scales have been reduced and there is no question about that.
Senator Short interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short interjects, but he cannot get around the undeniable truth that income tax scales are well down on the period when the coalition was in power. When John Howard was Treasurer it was 62 per cent; it is now well under 50 per cent for individuals and under 40 per cent for companies. He cannot get around the undeniable fact that income tax scales are down, corporate tax scales are down and there is more efficient collection of taxes which, for the first time in the country's history, is based on a system of honour. Most of the rorts over which the Fraser government presided like Pontius Pilate have been eliminated.

SPEECH.PARA: Capital gains tax has been introduced, fringe benefits taxes have been introduced, and the bottom of the harbour scheme has disappeared. And in response to that record of achievement we have the nonsense of a consumption tax. I am always staggered by the fact that the conservative parties in Australia trumpet ideological obsessions. Fundamentally, those obsessions are unfair and regressive. Not only are those obsessions trumpeted; they are embraced, highlighted and illustrated by the Liberal and National parties. Those are options that we on the Government side reject outright, just as the Australian people will reject the coalition on the next occasion as they have on the previous four occasions.

A few days ago in the House of Representatives the Treasurer, Mr Keating, comprehensively demolished the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and his manifesto. For the first time in the current political circumstance and in current political debate, we have condensed what the Opposition manifesto actually has come to be. The subject of vouchers was raised by the Australian Democrats earlier. That is a nonsense which clearly has not been thought through. It is inapplic- able in an Australian context. We will see that rejected in a very short while, just as we saw floated ideas quickly disappear when Andrew Peacock was the Leader of the Opposition.

What is the current Opposition manifesto, as far as we can tell? We know that the manifesto includes double taxation, with State and Federal income taxes. That has been revived from the Fraser period. We remember that vividly. That is another reason that the conservative parties will be rejected. We know that it includes a consumption tax on all goods. We know that it includes vouchers for health and education and we know, of course, that the absolute chasm in policy is that there is no wages policy existing anywhere within the Opposition at any level. So how on earth would costs be kept under control?

As Senator Cook made clear in the Senate this afternoon in answer to a question that I placed before him, the latest OECD economic outlook for the December quarter in 1990 demonstrates conclusively that Australian unit labour costs in the business sector are well below the OECD average. Some of the information that Senator Cook put to the Senate is worth not only repeating, but emphasising. The Australian estimate is for an increase of 4.4 per cent, against an OECD average of 4.6 per cent.
Senator Short interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short will have every opportunity in reply to challenge the facts that Government senators have put before the Senate-including the OECD statistics from which Senator Cook quoted in Question Time earlier this afternoon. Look at the Australian record in terms of an estimate for an increase of 4.4 per cent against the United States figure of 4.9 per cent; against the United Kingdom figure of 8.3 per cent-and its trade union movement has been crushed by anti-union laws; against Italy's figure of 6.3 per cent; and against figures for countries which have, by all accounts, first-class competing economies: Austria at 5 per cent, Finland at 6.9 per cent, and the like. The Australian outlook is very promising and we can afford to take some pride in that.

SPEECH.PARA: What has produced those figures? It is the prices and incomes accord between the Australian Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There is no wages policy from the Opposition that may stand in competition with that or be contrasted with that record of achievement. Again, we have from the Opposition an absolutely ludicrous notion that we should turn back the clock and move from a 35- or 38-hour working week to a 40-hour working week. Senator Cook or Senator Jones may correct me if I am wrong on this, but this is the first time in Australian history since the period in the 1920s at the onset of the Great Depression that the conservative parties have tried to increase the working week after there have been decisions by the Industrial Relations Commission to grant shorter working weeks; in other words, it has not happened in 50 or 60 years. People claim that this--

TALK.START.PARA: —That shows how far behind the times they are.

—Senator Jones is right. It shows how far behind the times the National and Liberal parties are. They are three generations behind the times. I look forward to Senator Crane coming into the debate and defending the lengthening of the working week. We have seen great progress under the prices and incomes accord, not only in containing costs but also in cutting working hours, in guaranteeing real wage increases and in underlining the social wage.

SPEECH.PARA: Is there anything from the Opposition that ought to be highlighted? For the purposes of this debate and for the information of the Australian people, the coalition is proposing two brand new taxes-State income tax and a consumption tax. Education will cease to be a public responsibility-so far as we can tell by an analysis of what has been said by the coalition-being transferred from the Government to individuals. In health, the first result of the coalition's agenda being implemented would be an income blowout for the medical profession, simply letting the medical profession determine what it could charge for services through this nonsensical voucher system.

That brings me to my conclusion. Mr Keating described Dr Hewson aptly and accurately as a visiting professor of politics-visiting the issues without saying what the Liberal and National parties really stand for-and all on a pretence of not being a politician, like the rest of us, but being some sort of commentator rather than someone who has clear responsibilities to articulate a policy: a one-dimensional person. We have seen the suggestions of privatisation of social security, the re-establishment of the soup kitchens for people on welfare. That is another nonsense that will be rejected. It is a simple fact of political life that much of the bravado we have heard from the Liberal and National parties of recent times, we heard from the coalition prior to the 1987 and 1990 general elections. It turned out to be bravado only. In 1992-93 the Australian people will reject the Liberal and National parties, as they have on the previous four occasions, for the reasons that Government senators have outlined in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today debating Senator Short's motion on the recession, a debate which commenced last week. Senator Spindler has already spoken on the motion to put forward the Australian Democrats' view and I want to take the opportunity today to expand on his remarks of last week. The motion notes, first of all, the damning admission on 8 February of policy failure by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, that the Government did not want a recession, it wanted a slow down, and that it is a slow down, not a recession, that Australia requires. The second point of the motion notes the equally stunning admission by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, on the Sunday program on 10 February 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we obviously got wrong a proposition that said there would not be a recession.

It goes on to condemn the Government for the massive hardship that its disastrous miscalculations and mismanagement have wrought on all Australians. Finally, the motion urges the Government to pursue the policies advocated by the coalition, which, it claims, would restore sustainable private sector growth and employment.

The Democrats say that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were wrong in their economic policies and their predicted outcomes. As those policies have been expounded and put in place, we have continued for many years to stress our view that they are not the policies for this country. They have caused massive hardship, especially in my State of Victoria. So the Democrats agree with that part of the motion that points this out.

Because of high interest rates, Australia is in recession, as the Prime Minister admitted. In effect, the Government is trying to buy lower inflation by increasing unemployment. Unemployment has increased by almost 300,000 since October 1989. Yet last week's figure shows that inflation has dropped from 8 per cent to just under 7 per cent. That is not much gain for a great deal of pain. Indeed, since Senator Short gave notice of this motion we have seen the economic indicators get even worse. The horrendous December 1990 inflation figure of 1.9 per cent delivered us an inflation rate of nearly 7 per cent. Retail sales again went down in December by 0.9 per cent. Private new capital expenditure, which is an excellent indicator of whether we will create any new jobs, for the September 1990 quarter was 4 per cent below the September 1989 figure, and this is expected to worsen.

The really bad news of last week was the January unemployment figures. There are now 767,000 people unemployed-up by more than 60,000 in one month. Even the seasonally adjusted figures show a rise of 27,000 to nearly 720,000 unemployed. This equates to a 9.1 per cent unemployment rate or 8.4 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis. The recession does exist and is getting worse. In recessions the disparities in the distribution of wealth get greater. Unemployment impacts most heavily on lower income occupations and on people on fixed incomes, and then we see the effects in the community at large.

It is important in this climate of increasing unemployment and therefore increasing deprivation to have a look at some of the evidence that is already out there about the way in which many Australians are living-evidence which supports the part of the motion which talks about the consequences, the massive hardship of the disastrous economic policies under which Australians labour. We had a lot of that evidence brought to us in the recent report from the Catholic Bishops' Conference called Common Wealth Common Good resulting from their inquiry into wealth distribution in Australia. That was an inquiry which this Government has not yet been prepared to undertake and which the Australian Democrats continue to believe should be undertaken at Government level.

Some of the evidence from that inquiry has been put into this debate by my colleague Senator Spindler, but it is important to add to that. The Catholic bishops had something to say about financial deregulation, which the Democrats have condemned throughout the life of this Hawke Government. That financial deregulation is supported by the Opposition. I do not think we can ignore the significant direct hardship that this policy has caused many Australians when we are discussing the Government's miscalculations and mismanagement. Financial deregulation by this Government would have to rank as one of the biggest miscalculations of all times.
I will quote from the Bishops' report because it not only succinctly sets out our recent history, but also puts forward a view that is shared by many Australians. The report said:

Following deregulation of the loans market in Australia, virtually unlimited finance became available to those who were regarded (wrongly in a number of widely publicised cases) as the best credit risks-the wealthy and ambitious entrepreneurs. Some used this opportunity responsibly, but others indulged in socially (and in the end personally) damaging speculation. Those with wealth were in a position to maximise their gains, shielding them from tax with the help of the devices like negative gearing or through the capital gain on their properties.

Where has this left us? It has left us with real poverty in our midst: the homeless and the increasing numbers of unemployed, the disabled, sole parents and their children, other single income families and members of some Aboriginal and migrant communities. Professor Fred Gruen from the Australian National University estimated that in 1990 between 80,000 and 100,000 Australians live in dire poverty or homelessness. The Bishops' report notes:

The members of this underclass may not be dying in a famine but the lives of some of them are greatly and sometimes brutally shortened as the outcome of such byproducts of extreme poverty as malnourishment, disease, drug-addiction, violence, crime and a pervading sense of hopelessness. The loss is not only theirs, but the whole society's.

This does not sound much like the sort of Australia that we should be proud of. I do not think that any of us would want a society-I certainly do not-that tolerates 100,000 of its members living needlessly destitute lives in extreme poverty.

We see increasing examples of the numbers of young families forced to live in caravan parks increasing because 200,000 Australian households are still on public housing waiting lists. Poverty in rural areas is increasing alarmingly, domestic violence is increasing and in general child poverty still exists at much too high a level. The Burdekin report on youth homelessness estimated that at least 250,000 children are either homeless or at risk of homelessness. All of this is taking place in a climate of very speedily increasing unemployment-unemployment which is part of the program of this Government's economic policy.

It is the people at the bottom of the pile who are being asked to pay. As I have said, in a recession which has been particularly regional in its effect my own State of Victoria has borne the brunt of that policy, in particular because of the simultaneous problems in the State's financial system and the high concentration of manufacturing industry in that State.

Bankruptcies have skyrocketed, with almost 3,000 occurring in the December quarter. This compares with 1,874 in the previous December quarter-a rise of 56 per cent. Credit growth has collapsed from the speculative binge of the late 1980s level of nearly 20 per cent down to 7 per cent. It appears as though the banks have over-reacted because of their massive bad debts and non-performing loans and are actually rationing credit even though interest rates have dropped considerably. Ordinary Australians are paying for the excesses which were committed by the financial deregulation put in place by this Government.

The drops in official interest rates have not been fully passed on to home owners or small businesses. The banks are now operating on historically high margins. We now have evidence of practices far worse than profiteering being undertaken by at least one of the banks, yet the Government will not do anything about it. As the Senate is well aware, my colleague Senator McLean has been trying for years to get an inquiry into the corrupt practices of banks in Australia, and even where clear evidence is available he has been denied the right to bring matters to the notice of the Parliament and thereby to the Australian people.

In short, bank deregulation has contributed to the severity of the boom and current bust. Venture capital is even more difficult to come by for fledgling businesses than usual. This will be to Australia's long term cost as businesses go offshore for that venture capital. If we cannot rely on the market to come up with the capital that Australia needs, then the Government must intervene to provide or direct that capital to the appropriate sectors.

All the Government's policy responses have been directed towards reducing the current account deficit. Their lack of success caused the Treasurer last year to say that reducing inflation was the top priority. As I have already outlined, in spite of increasing unemployment and interest rate drops, we have not had a relative reduction in inflation, but a figure of only about one per cent. The only equitable demand management tool is fiscal policy, and that is what the Treasurer should have tightened. The tax system works on the capacity to pay principle and through the tax system paying can be equitably distributed.

Whilst deregulation, privatisation and cutting government expenditure are all discredited policies of the Government, the Opposition's remedies are, unbeliev- able though it may seem, even worse. To inflict Opposition policies-as the last point in the motion before us today asks the Government to do-on a community which is already reeling, as I have demonstrated, from the economic rationalism and deregulation of this Government would be an impossible thing to contemplate.

Let us have a look at the policies that the Opposition has floated since this motion was proposed by Senator Short last week-just in the last week. This is on top of its policy to sell off public assets-assets which are currently owned by all Australians which will be bought, either by the wealthy who are the few at the top of the pyramid in this country, or by overseas interests to further unbalance our economy and put an imposition on future generations. It is also on top of earlier proposals for the privatisation of welfare payments, the abolition of unemployment benefits and so the list goes on.

Just in the last week, to add to that, we had the resurrection of the proposal for the voucher system for educational services-a relic of the past. A system that would have to, in the end, involve the payment of fees in State schools to have any effect, and would introduce absolutely unacceptable inequity into the education system and lead to an increasing social inequity which could not be contemplated by any society which had any concept at all of social justice, let alone of effective education for all of its citizens.

A similarly appalling proposal of a voucher system for health services has surfaced since we last debated this motion. That really amounts to a proposal for the destruction of the universal system of Medicare, a system which, we need to remind the Opposition, is supported by over 70 per cent of Australians which, of course, includes at least half of the supporters of the Liberal Party of Australia. It is a proposal which would, as I think Senator Loosley has pointed out, in the first instance, certainly lead to a blow-out in the incomes of medical practitioners; would in no way address any of the real problems of the costs of the provision of health care in this community; and would certainly not be in the interests of the most disadvantaged in our community.

Indeed, it is precisely because of the prospect of this type of proposal that my colleague Senator Spindler amended the Medicare Levy Act to ensure that any alterations by any government to the Medicare levy-and, therefore, to the financing of Medicare-cannot be done under the table; they must come before the Parliament. The protection of the balance of power held by the Australian Democrats in this Senate in decades to come will be very important, and is a guarantee to ensure the survival, in the long term, of Medicare, in spite of the ridiculous and inequitable policies that are coming forward from the Opposition. It was precisely because of our fear and belief that such a policy would be promoted by the Opposition that we moved that amendment. Therefore, Medicare remains safe because that amendment was supported by the Government and is now in the Act.

Another proposal to have come forward in this past week is to give income taxation powers back to the States-or, rather, should we say, to encourage the States to use the powers of income taxing. It is a proposal that has no community support and makes no economic sense. We have often heard from the Opposition about the need to simplify the tax system and that runs counter to this proposal to increase the complexity of the system and to have State governments raising their own taxes.

Probably an excuse for it comes from the fact that State governments have a range of responsibilities for the provision of services and, under the Hawke Government, the responsibilities of States and local government have increased as the buck has been passed with regard to them. The problem is that the buck, with regard to the dollars, has not also been passed down the line to the States and to local government. Therefore, there are funding problems. The Opposition proposes what I would call a cop-out system in its proposal for State taxation powers.

What we must have is a Federal government which is prepared to accept its responsibilities for a socially equitable community, both in the funding and in the distribution of the responsibility for the services that are needed to create such a society; we do not need the cop-out which is represented by the Opposition's proposal this week.

We have also had the announcement from the Opposition that it would permanently abandon a reserve price scheme for wool. In Australia's very important primary industry export sector, the Opposition this week has announced total abandonment. What the Government has done is bad enough; what the Opposition has proposed is a disaster. It is a very good illustration of the total deregulation, hands off, dog eat dog, level playing field myth that underlies the policies of this Opposition. What a week it has been!

To this must be added the other policies. The one which I would mention here in particular is the policy of the consumption tax to tax all goods and every service-not to implement just one new tax, but a whole range of taxes on everything that everybody buys. Of course, it will and must impact most heavily on low income earners and people on fixed incomes-people who have no discretion about whether to save or not. They simply have to spend all of their dollars to eat, to clothe themselves and their children and to be housed and educated.

One of the rationales for this broad-based consumption tax is that it encourages savings. There are people in our community who cannot afford to save and those who can afford to do not. This is not the way to create savings. There is also the previous announcement of an Opposition policy to cut high income earners' income tax even further; a pro- cess which is well and truly under way, of course, under the Hawke Labor Government.

The destruction of our manufacturing industry at an even faster rate than the Industry Commission recommends is also Opposition policy; a tariff reduction program not geared to the national interest but based on an ideological, mythical level playing field approach. In addition, the Opposition wants to fuel speculation more by abolishing capital gains tax where an asset is held for more than five years.

Clearly, the Opposition's policies, of which these are only a few, are even worse than the Government's, and the Democrats cannot support the final paragraph of the motion before the Senate which exhorts the Government to take up these even more disastrous Opposition policies. That is why Senator Spindler has moved an amendment to the motion to remove paragraph (d).

On the other hand, the Australian Democrats do have policies to address the mess which the Government has created. Many of those policies were demonstrated in our alternative Budget brought forward last August, and many of them were outlined in the earlier contribution to this debate by Senator Spindler.

They were, in brief, the development of our public infrastructure-not selling it off in the way that the Government and the Opposition want to do; and direct import limitation taxation policies on luxury goods, such as the luxury car tax which this Government has implemented and which has worked successfully. We have campaigned very strongly during the past two Federal elections on import limitation taxation policies. We were pleased to see just one picked up by this Government; it should now do more.

Anti-dumping provisions must be streamlined to allow quick and effective action to be taken before it is too late, before we destroy our primary industries sector, and in particular our horticultural industry. We should take that action before imported goods reach this country. We should examine import-export matching systems which are similar to the existing export facilitation schemes which currently operate in the motor vehicle industry. We need to reorientate the tax system towards productive enterprises instead of favouring paper shuffling and speculation-which would be even more strongly favoured by the Opposition. We need to lift interest withholding tax rates from the ridiculously low 10 per cent which currently prevails, and there should be accelerated depreciation provisions for major productive investments.

Those have already been mentioned in this debate and I would like to add a few more urgently needed measures. We must further tighten corporate regulation. Although I acknowledge that the Government has made progress in this area, more needs to be done. Another area critical to Australia's business is our cost of capital. This is one area where we are definitely not internationally competitive. We face interest rates in excess of double those prevalent in the successful Asian and European economies. I hope that the Industry Commission can suggest some effective measures in this area in the reference that it now has before it.

We need to boost training massively now so that those people who have recently lost their jobs do not become long term unemployed. The Australian Council of Social Service has recently requested at least 20,000 extra training placements to be allocated by the Government in the March statement, which we are all awaiting. Even this is not an optimal solution to the problem. However, as has previously been stated by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats, the most important policy change which must occur is an ideological shift away from deregulation for its own sake. There is a role for government, especially in industrial development. Because of Australia's high capital costs and transport costs arising from its isolation, it needs an interventionist industrial policy. Ken Davidson's article in the Age newspaper last week refers to the success of the Asian economies which involve government planning and assistance, especially in the early stages of the development of industries. Those countries do not suffer from the constant critics claiming that they cannot pick winners. They have created winners on an awesome scale-winners with whom we now need to compete. I also refer colleagues to an article in the Age on 19 February by Tim Colebatch who, as the article states:
. . . travelled to Germany to find out what makes a clever country. He found a wealthy society whose priorities differ greatly from Australia.
While we are talking about picking winners I will quote from that article:

Like the Cain Government, German state governments pay big subsidies to attract research institutes, and have units promoting technology transfers between researchers and companies. If John Hewson went to the stronghold of German conservatism, Bavaria, and told them governments cannot pick winners, they would laugh at him. Why, they have been picking winners for years.
The article goes on to point out:

Before the war, Bavaria was the rustic hinterland of the country, where poor Catholic farmers lived amid picturesque hills and run-down textile factories. Now, thanks to aggressive use of taxpayers' funds to pick winners and build up a scientific base, it is the fastest-growing area of Germany, and the centre of its emerging high-tech industries: aerospace, semi-conductors, robotics, fibre optics and biotechnology.

I commend Tim Colebatch's article to my colleagues. Were they to read it to find that the award rate for a qualified metal tradesman is $32,000 a year, yet most earn more; that workers in German factories are actually missing six weeks of the year because they are on holiday; that they work 38 hours a week, five of them in their traditional lunchtime beer break, and have the shortest working hours in the world; that their governments do pick winners; that they have an industrial relations system in which the interests of labour and capital are seen as complementary-and the list goes on-we might be spared futile debates such as this in which the Opposition deludes itself that it has any answers to the improvement of the economy and, therefore, of society and the lot of individuals in this country.

I shall conclude with another quote from this article in the hope that Senator Short will listen and perhaps not attempt to refute-in a way in which he probably will-the policies of the Australian Democrats, which accord so closely with all of the points that are made in this article, this analysis, of the very successful German economy. The article states:

If big government is the road to damnation, Germany should be burning in hellfire. Its governments spend almost half the national output. They own business enterprises and shares worth $350 billion. In eight years of conservative government, little has been sold off except Volkswagen.
But one lesson from Germany is the irrele- vance of our passion for small government and level playing fields. Governments, like companies, can do badly or do well.

We agree with Senator Short: this Government has done badly. But we do not agree with Senator Short that to take up Opposition policies would be any better for this country. We have a different set of goals, a different view, a more responsible view in terms of government's role in the economy and, therefore, in the interests of our community. We support the first three parts of this motion and, as I said, will move to omit the final clause because we believe that both the Government and the Opposition are on the wrong track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Senator Short's motion, I shall keep my comments to about 10 minutes to allow Senator Short to wind up the debate. Before I get onto the points that I wanted to make, I must say that the Australian Democrats never cease to amaze me as they spell out their recipe for solving the Australian problem. One of the unfortunate things about what they spell out is that 99 per cent of it is about stopping or knocking and saying, `This one can't do it or that one can't do it'. The recipe that the Democrats deliver up to us each time is about what they will stop, not what they will do.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of things that need to be commented on. It is unfortunate that the wool situation has been brought into this debate, because it is before the Senate now. I doubt whether anybody in this place really believes that the current reserve price scheme for wool is not finished. If there is something we have to do in the future when things settle down and the industry recovers, we will deal with that then on its merits. But it is absolute and total nonsense for us to be in a position, as far as the current situation of the wool industry is concerned, where there is a potential to mislead our customers and to give false hopes to the producers in the bush. The sooner we recognise basic facts in this place, the sooner we can be a little more honest with those people whose livelihoods we are now looking at legislating for.

I also want to make some comments about deregulation. One of the things that needs to be recognised absolutely in terms of the Australian situation is that a decision to go back to a regulated society would mean in effect that we wanted to isolate ourselves from the rest of the world. In terms of deregulation of the financial system, the big mistake that was made--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about wool and wheat?

—Senator Kernot can shout all she likes; she has had her turn. The big mistake that was made in deregulating the financial system was that it was done in isolation from manufacturing, wages policy, the waterfront and a number of other areas. It is not practical to have a partly deregulated system. That is the fundamental problem we have now.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall just quickly run through some of the key areas on which I wish to comment. Some key words in Senator Short's motion are paramount in respect of Treasurer Keating's failed economic policies-and how they have failed. The national debt is out of control and growing, seven times higher in the life of this Government. The current account is equally out of control and, with the collapse of the wheat and wool industries, can only continue to deteriorate unless the Government changes direction.

I emphasise a couple of matters in principle because they are relevant to the current situation. They can be summed up very simply in three key words: incentive, productivity and reward. None of these three things currently apply in our taxation and industrial systems. Until we correct those simple things-incentive, productivity and reward-there will be no improvement. We will not sustain productivity without reward. The accord has screwed the work force into the ground. It has lowered the standard of living. The accord is a recipe for mediocrity. To get productivity we must revamp the taxation system; it should be overhauled.

I will make a few comments about a goods and services tax and the way it has been misrepresented by previous speakers in this chamber. They always talk about the benefits to the rich. There are some very important components in the various goods and services taxes and value added taxes around the world. First, there is an overall lowering of direct taxation to everybody, not just the rich. Secondly, there are adequate compensation components to assist the underprivileged. These are key and very important components. I mentioned a substantial lowering of income tax rates. It is very important to reward those who are prepared to put in the effort.

In moving through the taxation system we must take the burden of indirect taxes off our export industries. The Government talks about a level playing field internationally. I do not disagree with that; in fact, I support it. I also support the Cairns Group very strongly. What about making it a level playing field in Australia? We could do things in Australia to substantially level the playing field. The indirect tax system now penalises our exporters. A classic example is that, since the Hawke Government came into power, fuel excise has increased from 6.155c per litre to 24.9c per litre. Why do we not hear something about that from the Democrats? It is an absolute outrage. This is a penalty, a tax, on distance.

Our sales tax laws are full of anomalies and holes. One can quote all sorts of examples of how they can be abused and how they favour certain situations. But, in the short time I have left this evening, the classic example I can give is the definition under which one can use a chainsaw in a productivity based capacity. It is very simple. If one buys a chainsaw and nominates that it will be used to build sheep yards for 40 per cent of the time and that it will be used to cut fence posts for 40 per cent of the time, what happens? Because it is not used primarily and principally for one action sales tax is paid. But if two chainsaws are bought and it is nominated that for 60 per cent of the time one will be used to build sheep yards and that for 60 per cent of the time the other will be used to build fence posts, no sales tax is paid on either of them. How can a tax system be judged as being sensible and consistent when there are these anomalies? I could run through them, example after example.

I will now talk about the industrial system. I have emphasised the importance of the taxation system providing incentive to people to perform, thereby increasing productivity. There is nothing wrong with the Australian work force and the Australian people. They are like everyone else; they need a little reward at the end of the day. I will now give two examples that show that good results in productivity can be achieved.

First, I will talk about the Northern Territory meat award at Mudginberri. I was involved in this for some years. Looking at the result, it is interesting to note that the wages went from $600 per week to $1,100 per week. Productivity went up 450 per cent, yet the cost of killing came from $134 down to $33 per beast. If that is not rewarding all components of the equation, I do not know what is.

Secondly, I was also involved in the Newcastle continuous loading case. Just by rearranging and staggering the relief breaks, the morning tea breaks and the lunch breaks into two seven-hour shifts so that the work did not stop, and things were kept running for 14 hours a day instead of having to stop and start, output was increased by a whole 40 per cent. This did not cost anybody a cent; it was just a bit of commonsense.

I will mention fiscal policy. I was rather interested in Senator's Loosley's comments. He said that if we were to tighten government expenditure at this time it would lead to chaos. It is worth quoting Senator Peter Walsh's thoughts on this. I am sure honourable senators have read it. In an address which he gave in America recently he said:
. . . we do know that when fiscal policy was really tightened in 1986-87 and beyond, employment growth actually accelerated . . .

That puts an absolute lie to the myth that is peddled around this and other places when people talk about being a little bit more fiscally responsible. The greatest challenge we face regarding the debt blow-out in the wool industry is fiscal responsibility.

I will now comment on the waterfront and why the Government has not progressed in this as much as it could have done and why we have this recession on our hands, which for many people out in the country is a depression. The Cairns agreement can be described only as a Clayton's agreement. On the waterfront, there has been a reduction from 23 men to 10. The Northern Shipping Stevedoring Co. said that it needed only five to perform the required functions. But the big problem is that there have been no corrections to the wasteful work practices. That is where the real cost lies, not in the number of people. It is not appropriate to employ people in positions in which they have nothing to do. It is far better to restructure it so that these people have something useful to do. They would at least then have some quality of life. I must emphasise that there have been no corrections of the wasteful work practices. The countdown on Senator Collins continues. I think we have 73 or 74 days to go.

I will now wind up my comments. I am sorry that there is not more time available. It is only fair that I give Senator Short ample time to round up the debate. I emphasise what I said at the beginning of my comments about policy development and the direction we must take. It is important that we provide incentive to get productivity increases, and those productivity increases must be rewarded. It is no good continually screwing people down and making life harder for them because they will not respond. A carrot has to be offered to provide incentive. The Government's current policies, particularly in the taxation and industrial arenas, provide none of these.

In finishing my comments I state that, if we were to provide a bit of incentive and reward in the Victorian meat situation and we were to develop an award based on the Northern Territory award, many of those problems could be overcome. This would benefit the whole of Australia. It would spill over into other States, including Western Australia. We could get killing costs in the meat industry down. We could protect the jobs of those involved and, instead of exporting and domestic abattoirs closing down, we could see a resurgence of this country's meat industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This debate is now in its second week, having been listed for discussion last week under General Business. In winding up the debate, I would like first of all to thank those honourable senators from both sides of the chamber who have contributed. In particular, of course, I thank my own coalition colleagues who spoke last week and, in the case of Senator Baume and Senator Crane, today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is debating a very important motion. It is a motion which draws attention to the quite damning admission-indeed, the stunning admission-on 8 February by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the policy failure of the Government when he stated that `the Government did not want a recession, it wanted a slowdown' and that `it is a slowdown, not a recession, that Australia requires'. The motion also notes the equally stunning admission by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Sunday program two days later that `we obviously got wrong a proposition that said that there would not be a recession'.

The motion condemns the Government for the massive hardship its disastrous miscalculations and mismanagement have wrought on all Australians. Finally, the motion urges the Government to pursue the policies advocated for so long by the coalition, to restore sustainable private sector growth and employment.

I am very pleased to note that the Australian Democrats propose to support the first three clauses of the motion. I very much regret that they will not be supporting what is really the key clause of the motion, namely, the need for the Government to pursue the policies that the Liberal and National parties have been advocating for so long. Those are the only policies that will restore sustainable private sector growth and employment to a nation which is now in a state of deep recession and which, unless a major policy turnaround is not taken very soon, will find that the problems it faces will be even more intractable than they appear to be today, and that is bad enough.

Let me just go through some of the points of the motion in more detail and pick up some of the comments that have been made during this debate. The Government has been on again, off again, on again, off again in relation to the question of the state of the economy. On 22 March last year, which is a significant date because it was only two days before the Federal election, the Treasurer said in Adelaide in response to a question, `We won't let a recession occur'. That view was echoed the same day by the Prime Minister, who was campaigning in Brisbane.

When the national accounts figures came out eight to 10 weeks ago in December, the Treasurer was forced to admit, `It is a recession'. But he said this time that it is a recession that we had to have, whereas only nine months previously he said, `We won't let there be a recession'.

We again had a turnaround on 8 February when the Treasurer admitted that it was not a recession that we had to have, that we did not want a recession-that really we only wanted a slowdown but that we got it all wrong. Despite the fact that he said early in December that it was a recession that we had to have, he said that we had used the levers to pull Australia into a slowdown and now a recession. In other words, he was saying then that it was a deliberately contrived policy.

Eight weeks later he says, `No, we made a mistake'. Indeed, two days later his Prime Minister went on television Australia-wide and said, `Yes, we got it wrong. We are sorry'. This is despite the fact that, again, early in December, the Prime Minister told the Australian people, when it was quite obvious that every Australian was suffering from this recession, that they should not fear the recession.

Could a Prime Minister make a crueller statement than that at a time when unemployment was rising at a rate over the last 12 months almost unprecedented in Australian history? The number of persons who have been put out of work in this country has increased by more than 200,000. The number of recipients of the unemployment benefit has increased by over 160,000.

Perhaps of all the Government's fond claims which might have had any credibility and credence in terms of what they had achieved for Australia over the last eight years, one could point to the Government's job creation claim. In the last 12 months, and increasingly over the last few months, that claim has been blown out of the water with the enormous, cruel, unnecessary increase that has occurred in the level of unemployment in this country and the massive, tragic and disastrous lengthening of the dole queues that this has produced.

Senator Loosley had the audacity to say this afternoon that ordinary working people in this country were expendable under coalition governments. What has this Government done in the last 12 months but treat ordinary working people as expendable? It has used them as fodder to fuel its disastrous economic policies-policies which are disastrous in their deliberateness but even more disastrous in terms of the miscalculations that have accompanied them.

It is not just in the areas of unemployment and employment where the Government has got it wrong. The Government has got it wrong in terms of the total national output of this country. We now have a deep-seated recession; we have negative growth in four out of the last five quarters in Australia; and it is quite obvious that that is going to continue for several quarters yet. Personally, I do not believe that there is going to be a cyclical upturn in this country during the course of calendar year 1991. But even if there is, the deep-seated problems of the economy, because of the lack of attention to those problems by the Government, will mean that any upturn will be ephemeral, will be short lived and not able to be sustained.

The number of bankruptcies has gone up in Australia by 56 per cent in the last 12 months. Retail sales have crashed; motor vehicle registrations are down; and dwelling approvals are down by over one-eighth. The Confederation of Australian Industry has measured this country against nine other major industrial countries in terms of our ranking in economic activity. According to that body, we rank 10 out of 10.

In the last six months the Budget which was introduced in August has unravelled to an extent that is unprecedented in Australia's history. The Government went for a Budget surplus estimate of $8 billion when the Treasurer introduced the Budget last August. That $8 billion is rapidly disappearing. There is now every probability that, at best, the Budget will be in balance this year. However, more likely, it will in fact go into deficit.

On top of that, there has been a major blow-out in State government and public sector borrowing. The public sector borrowing requirement this year is going to be not the nil that was forecast in the Budget but of the order, I estimate, of 3 per cent or thereabouts. Yet it is only six or seven months ago last June that the Treasurer said at the Premiers Conference-and, of course, he was right:

It is very important for Australia to be able to paint the position always, at least in this immediate period, that the public sector has not got its hands on the savings cookie jar of Australia, that it has it out of that jar.

He was right-he should have been right. But, indeed, what has happened is that, as a result of the mismanagement, miscalculations and wrong policies of this Government, there will be this financial year, and even more so next financial year, a massive call by the public sector on the savings of the Australian people. This will occur at a time when there will be a great need for capital by the private sector as the economy makes some attempt to recover. As I said, this will be extraordinarily difficult, if not impossible, given the fact that the fundamental problems underlying the economy are unchanged because of the failure of the Government's policies.

The hardship has been very strong indeed. I cannot think of a period in the last 20 years when the immediate hardships of the Australian people have been more than in recent months. I believe that the hardship occasioned by this recession is much more at this stage, and certainly will be much more than the hardship which occurred in 1982-83. That recession was triggered primarily by a world recession, whereas ours has been home grown. But the problems and the hardship facing all Australians are quite massive. It is for that reason that the Opposition has urged the Government in this motion to pursue the policies advocated by the coalition to breathe some life back into this nation and our economy.

Indeed, far from the comments that have been made by Government and Democrat speakers in terms of lack of policies, the whole approach of the Government, and the whole approach of the Democrats, has been a reactionary approach. The Democrats have certainly put forward policies-I accept that-but they are the policies of the 1940s and the 1950s; they are the policies of big spending government, of building more rigidities into our society and into our economy, and of going right back to the road of regulation which has been shown throughout the world to be the wrong road to take.

So far as the floating of ideas is concerned, the coalition now seems to be criticised by the Government and by the Democrats because we have the courage to take the Australian community into our confidence and to share with them some of the thoughts and some of the ideas that might possibly be developed to get this country out of the recession it is in. If the Government, the Democrats, and anyone else want to criticise that policy, be that on their heads, because the Australian community is reacting very positively to that approach. That is not to say that every policy idea that is floated is a proposal that will end up as firm policy. It will really take some doing for any honourable senator in this chamber to tell me why it is wrong to take the Australian community into one's confidence in debating and looking at these issues.

We have a very full list of policies that have been out in the public arena for a long time. It is nonsensical and simply untrue to say that the coalition does not have a range of well-developed policies. On fiscal policy, we have made specific proposals of a major nature in terms of expenditure restraint, the simplification of the taxation system and the introduction of a consumption tax to get some incentive back into the Australian work force. We have major proposals for labour market reform to try to get rid of the troubles and the disasters that have been caused by the accord, which has eroded real incomes, propped up inflation and given the Australian Council of Trade Unions far too much power.

We have made specific proposals on infrastructure, reforms of government operations, privatisation, industry reform, better balancing of policies between the needs of the environment and the needs of development and so on. We have called for all of those proposals and we have spelt them out in great detail. For that reason we have included-because it is very clear what is involved-paragraph (d) of the motion before the Senate today. I could say much more in a debate such as this, but time is of the essence at this stage. I conclude by again thanking all contributors to this debate. I hope that this motion will achieve the support of the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I table a letter received by the Committee relating to its report on Operation Ark. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the letter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a tabling statement agreed to by the Committee.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The letter tabled relates to several matters in the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Operation Ark which was tabled in both Houses on 17 October 1990.
Justice Stewart notes in his letter that he writes on his own behalf and on behalf of two former Commissioners of the National Crime Authority, Mr L Robberds QC and Mr P M Le Grand.

In his letter, Justice Stewart draws the Committee's attention to two findings of fact in the Committee's Operation Ark Report which he asserts are incorrect. (These findings relate in particular to the status of a report prepared immediately prior to the end of Justice Stewart's term as Chairman of the National Crime Authority on 30 June 1989 which dealt with certain allegations of corruption in the South Australian Police Force following the 1989 Operation Noah in South Australia-the Stewart Report).
The two findings of fact which Justice Stewart asserts are incorrect are in paragraphs 18 and 19 of the Committee's Report, and are that
* the process of drafting the Stewart Report was completed on 4 July 1990
* the Stewart Report was not completed on 30 June 1990

(In order to avoid confusion as to the date relevant to this matter, I note that the Committee's report is incorrect in the paragraphs referred to by Justice Stewart where it mentions June and July 1990; the paragraphs should refer to June and July 1989.)
Justice Stewart's letter also makes a number of other comments about the Report related to those findings of fact. These further comments are as follows

* the Committee's Report was contradictory in that its description of the NCA Operation Ark Report did not agree with a description of the status of that report used in material before the Committee in the course of its inquiry
* the Committee's report neither summarises nor analyses the evidence upon which the two findings of fact were based; and
* the Committee's process of reasoning concerning these two findings of fact, is not exposed in the report.

In its Report, the Committee primarily dealt with a direct conflict of views which exist between Justice Stewart and his successor as Chairman of the NCA, Mr Faris QC, on the status of the Stewart Report. The Committee received evidence from two then members of the NCA (Messrs Leckie and Dempsey) to the effect that the Stewart Report was not a Report of the NCA and because it had not been duly authorised for transmission to the Government of South Australia prior to the end of Justice Stewart's term as Chairman of the NCA, it was incumbent upon the newly appointed membership of the NCA, following their commencement as members after 1 July 1989, to decide whether to transmit what it regarded as a draft report.
Messrs Leckie and Dempsey considered that the Stewart Report had not been duly authorised for transmission because there was not evidence of a minuted meeting of the Authority.
Justice Stewart's view directly conflicts with this belief, and is recorded in a letter sent to the South Australian Attorney-General, which is reproduced in the Committee's Report.

Mr Speaker/President, the Committee did not table Justice Stewart's letter immediately it was received at the end of the last period of sittings because Committee members believed that careful consideration should be given to Justice Stewart's assertions.

Having considered the evidence dealt with by the Committee in arriving at the findings in its Operation Ark Report the Committee considers that it is necessary to seek evidence from Justice Stewart in relation to the matters raised in his letter and to then, if necessary, report further to Parliament.

At this stage, the Committee considers that it would neither be constructive for it to reconsider the Operation Ark case, nor to attempt further adjudication on the conflicting claims about the status of the NCA Operation Ark Report at 30 June 1989.

Having reached that view, the Committee nevertheless recognises that several aspects of the situation that arose regarding the NCA Operation Ark Report continue to give it cause for concern. In particular, the case identifies important issues regarding the transition of the NCA from one membership to an NCA of a different membership.
Included amongst these matters are
* how disputes can be resolved between new and old members of the NCA
* whether a new NCA could overturn or alter a decision of a previous Authority
* whether it is appropriate for the expiry of the term of more than one member to coincide on or near the same date
* where several members of the NCA end their term on the same day, whether some mechanism should exist for clarifying the powers of a new NCA over matters put in hand by a previous NCA
* what mechanisms could be employed by the NCA during a change over period of its members to minimise discontinuity and uncertainty within the organisation.

The Committee has decided that, as part of its present evaluation of the NCA's constitution, role, effectiveness and powers it will specifically address the administrative problems which emerged during the transition period from the Authority under Justice Stewart's Chairmanship to the Authority under Mr Faris's in July 1989.
To assist the Committee in such an examination, and also to allow it to discuss his letter, Justice Stewart has agreed to give evidence to the Committee on 11 March 1991 on these and other matters.

I have read the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on Operation Ark and wish to bring to your attention that it contains factual errors. I should note at the outset that I am writing this letter on my own behalf and on behalf of both Mr Robberds QC and Mr Le Grand.
One of the objects of the Committee's deliberations is stated in paragraph 28 of the report:

The Committee's report appears to make two findings of fact (both of which are incorrect) concerning this object:

I note that:

(i) Although the report picked up the words of Mr Faris' letter of 30 January 1990 (paragraph 28) and spoke thereafter of ``the proposed report'', the opening words of that letter quoted in paragraph 24-``Although prepared before July 1 . . . '' contradict the Committee's findings in paragraphs 18 and 19;
(ii) The Committee's report neither summarises nor analyses the evidence upon which the two findings of fact were based; and
(iii) The Committee's process of reasoning concerning these two findings of fact, is not exposed in the report.
The facts are:
(A) Mr Robberds QC, Mr Le Grand and myself (Mr Clark being on leave) decided on 30 June to forward the report as a report of the Authority to the South Australian Government.
(B) The report was completed by the time I signed the letter of transmittal of 30 June 1990.
(C) There was no statutory or other requirement to minute the decision referred to in (A), above.
Evidence of these facts is available from me, Mr Robberds QC and Mr Le Grand.
If the Committee wishes to obtain this evidence it might consider it appropriate also to obtain evidence on the matters referred to in the qualifying statement published with its report.
Finally, I refer to paragraph 34 of the Committee's report and draw your attention to section 59(9) of the National Crime Authority Act which provides:
``Where any information relating to the performances of the functions of-
(a) a Department of State of the Commonwealth or of a State;
(b) The Administration of a Territory; or

(c) an instrumentality of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory, comes into the possession of the Authority in the course of any investigations conducted by it, the Authority may, if it considers it desirable to do so-
(d) furnish that information to the Department, the Administration or the instrumentality; and

(e) make to the Department, the Administration or the instrumentality such recommendations (if any) relating to the performance of the functions of the Department, of the Administration or of the instrumentality as the Authority considers appropriate.''

In this context I also refer to section 6 (3) of the National Crime Authority (State Provisions) Act 1984 of South Australia which provides inter alia, that where the Authority is performing a special function (as in the instant case) the Authority considers that a recommendation should be made to the Minister (in this case the Attorney-General for South Australia), for reform of administrative practices (section 6 (3) (b)), the Authority may make the recommendation to the Minister.

It is refuted that the Authority had sought to comment adversely on the management of the Police Department by reaching broad generalised conclusions based on its examination of one limited aspect of police operations. The terms of paragraph 34 do not make it clear whether the concern mentioned therein was that of the Police Commissioner, the Committee, or both. In any event the Authority was exercising its statutory rights, and in this case what it saw as its obligations.
Yours sincerely
Mr Justice Stewart
Question resolved in the affirmative.
