DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Maguire:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, may I congratulate you, Senator Vanstone, on your appointment to be a Temporary Chairman of Committees. This report, of which I was delighted to be a part, has produced a useful statement on Australia-Soviet Union relations. Of course, it is an interim report-a report given midstream-because it would be a very brave person who would predict the end point to which developments in the Soviet Union may take that country. It is right to say that there is economic chaos in that country-and even social chaos. There is enormous tension on the nationalities question.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent months, every week there is someone-perhaps someone extreme-who reflects on the possibility of civil war. I do not make exaggerated statements or predictions. Rather, I rest with stability with the words of this report. I think it is a measured report. It certainly was thoroughly investigated by us. We have written several chapters. We have brought down some conclusions and recommendations; and these ought not be neglected by the Australian Government, because they are appropriate and can be acted upon, I believe, whatever may develop in economic and political terms in the Soviet Union over the coming year or two.

I first visited the Soviet Union in 1968 when I was in transit to take up research studies in the United Kingdom. At that time I was protesting the invasion by the Soviet Union of Czechoslovakia-that happened the month before I actually visited, when my plans were already set-in August of 1968. My first understanding that there was a Soviet Union was when I was 12 years old in 1956, with the invasion of Hungary; and I recall the terror that we felt that a country could be pushed around by tanks in such an invasion.

Therefore, in coming to this Parliament more than a dozen years ago I had a strong impulse to try to bring light and justice, to the extent that an Australian can, to the relationship between eastern European countries and their neighbour, the Soviet Union. I dreamt that we might see a just relationship develop in eastern Europe between the various nations and that there would no longer be invasions such as those of Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Also, I was increasingly conscious through my teenage years of the liberty having been snatched away from Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. Year by year, for more than a decade now, I have been at annual memorials of those who have suffered at the hands of the Soviet invasion of those three countries. I have never recognised the incorporation of those countries into the Soviet Union.

So one of the themes that is very much in our considerations of developments in these recent years in this report that we have called Perestroika-as the policies of perestroika are applied to the foreign policy of the Soviet Union-is to see whether or not there is some redress to the concerns that I have just reflected upon; and there is redress. There has been a rejection of the Brezhnev doctrine of intervention into other states.

I welcome these developments. I believe that we have a new revolution in Hungary, Poland, in eastern Germany being incorporated with the West, and even in Czechoslovakia. I believe that we have seen only a preliminary change in Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia, especially the Serbian part of it; and there will be need for a second revolution in Serbia, Bulgaria and Romania. But there is a great deal of heart to be taken with the new freedom of the eastern European nations.

We looked at the implications of perestroika not only for Europe but also, of course, for the Asia-Pacific region and Australia in particular. What new strategic assessments ought to be made as a result of the policies that we call perestroika, the economic and social policies that have been led by President Gorbachev in recent years? A second area of enormous concern to members of this Parliament has been the absence of solid human rights in the Soviet Union. Indeed, there was a joint parliamentary inquiry into human rights in the Soviet Union some years ago-in the days of Senator Wheeldon and even Mr Kim Beazley Senior-and, of course, Andrew Peacock and many others were involved in that report when I first entered this Parliament. That report of the Australian Parliament set out as thoroughly as anybody the enormous abuses of human rights in the Soviet Union.

Our concern, then, has been not only to see an end to imperialism in the Soviet empire of the Brezhnev kind and before that of the Stalinist kind but also to see such a change of domestic arrangements and a new liberty and freedom for the peoples of the Soviet Union that the abuses that they have suffered for more than 70 years will be redressed. So we looked at the policies of perestroika and glasnost with some caution after the 70-year track record of that country with awareness that economic chaos was pending as there was a transition towards a more market-oriented economy and, of course, the nationality tensions, but with enormous heart and enormous acceptance of the new foreign relations and the new liberties for the Soviet citizens. We are part-way down that track. This is an interim statement; we are yet to see the full outcomes of these developments. I am not one who is cheering now that all is going to be well for the domestic situation for the peoples in the Soviet Union or for its foreign relations until we see perhaps a number of years of consolidation of the freedoms which I have spoken about and which we are all heartened to have seen.

I am also aware that the Soviet Union is still one of the superpowers, with an enormous nuclear arsenal. It is still an enormous threat to world peace should it ever be used or be contemplated to be used. We welcome the end of the Cold War, and we welcome the cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States-indeed, this country and many other allied countries in present international matters.

The conclusions and recommendations of our report address our two terms of reference: first, the strategic implications for reassessments in our region and, secondly, new opportunities for trade. Our recommendations, of which there are some 16, address those two areas. I have not time to go over them but, as to the first recommendation about a Cabinet review of the whole relationship, I stress that we do need to look for multilateral dialogue in this whole region, not just the bilateral relations between our two countries. We need to be realistic about the short term, with perhaps even decreases in trade such as we have seen with wool and wheat, but an eventual middle term expansion that we need to be totally prepared for with new information mechanisms, joint working groups between the two countries, lines of credit such as we have seen with wool and wheat, review of the Co-ordinating Committee on Exports of Technology to Communist Countries restrictions and in other ways.

We need to provide for Russian studies in our universities; liberate the skills of ethnic communities that are relevant to the Soviet Union; and make sure that we offer management training, increased air flights and so on. And we should not only concentrate on the Soviet Far East. I believe that the greater preponderance of our relationship will be with Russia proper, with the main western end of the Soviet Union. I believe that this is a sound report. I concur with all the recommendations and conclusions in the report and I think we have served Australia and the relationship with the Soviet Union in a positive way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine myself to a couple of observations only. I must say that I agree with virtually all that Senator Teague said by way of his contribution. The report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on perestroika and its implications for Australia is one that I believe will be meeting with a favourable response from the Australian Government. The recommendations were arrived at very carefully and I am certain will be taken very seriously. There is a focus on relations with the Soviet Far East on matters of trade and investment and on matters of security. That was agreed deliberately at the level of the Committee and it has broken new ground.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague referred to economic and social chaos in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). He is absolutely right. There is also political chaos in the Soviet Union at the moment. The future of the Union itself is in question, not only in terms of the nationalities and the legitimate aspirations for people in a number of the republics for independence and greater autonomy, but also on the basis of the breakdown in the economic framework of the country and in social relations. Indeed, as Andrei Amalrik predicted in 1969 in his classic book Will the Soviet Survive Until 1984?-The Nationalities Question may be at the core of Soviet politics. Within Soviet politics at the moment we see the Soyuz group in the Soviet parliament-colonels such as Alknis and Petrushenko-who have no hesitation in talking about a military government for the future. We have seen the elimination of liberal elements within the government-people such as Yakovlev and Shevardnadze. The evidence suggests to date that Defence Minister Yazov remains loyal to the President but there is no doubt that there are elements in the military who yearn for a return to the unfettered authoritarianism of the past.

The circumstances in the USSR at the moment are very dangerous indeed, not only with the food shortages, with the breakdown in health services, with the black marketeering and the spiralling rate of crime but also with the dangers in the kinds of populist sentiments that are given free rein by some of the more irrespon- sible elements in the Congress of the People's Deputies of the USSR.

Much has happened since I led the first Australian Labor Party National Executive delegation to the Soviet Union in the middle of 1989. The situation now is unrecognisable over what it was just two short years ago. To take up one of the points Senator Teague made, we have seen liberalisations in the past under Nikita Khrushchev in 1956 with the classic `secret speech' to the Twentieth Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. We saw it again later at the end of the Khrushchev period when Novy Mir published One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich. Those liberalisations came to abrupt ends. We must do all we can in terms of developing relations with the USSR to make certain that this liberalisation becomes irreversible in political and economic terms. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991 relates to the wool industry and the problems that the wool industry is experiencing. The whole wool industry is a very complex one that has engaged many hours of discussion and consideration by many different parties, including the Government, the Opposition and wool industry organisations. It is one in which there is, quite frankly, no easy solution. It is a question of trying to get some sort of resolution which might deal as well as possible with the problems that presently confront the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It must not be forgotten that to a very large extent the crisis in which the wool industry finds itself at present can be sheeted home to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. For many years, Mr Kerin has been running around the countryside showing himself up and purporting to be the farmers' friend, but it must not be forgotten throughout Australia that the real recession in the wool industry has occurred under Mr Kerin's leadership. There are many things, of course, for which he cannot be blamed, but there are many things which he could have done but did not do, or which he did at the wrong time, and which have exacerbated the real problem in which the wool industry finds itself.

Mr Kerin's problems with the wool industry are well known by now, and how he attempts to find a solution has also been a matter of public record. There is a decision made today and a different decision made tomorrow and, quite frankly, the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has no idea what to do in this particular instance. The lack of interest of the ALP in this particular matter is shown very clearly by the fact that, in this particular debate in the Senate, the ALP's contribution to the debate has been from one, might I say, very junior senator.

All that senator's contribution shows is that it is better to say nothing and let people think one is ignorant, than to speak and prove that one is ignorant. It did seem that the contribution from the ALP senator really missed the point completely. It almost seemed from listening to Senator West that she had not read the Act and she certainly had not read or understood the Opposition's proposals and amendments to the Act. It is something of a disgrace to the wool industry that the interest that the ALP takes in this matter as it comes through the Senate is left to one very junior senator.

I do not speak with any particular knowledge about the wool industry. I am concerned about it and I have tried to follow the ins and outs. But it is, as I mentioned initially, a very complex matter with complex problems and a complex solution. The reason why I wanted to speak on this Bill was not so much to address the tangible issues of the Bill but to talk on aspects which were raised at the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

It probably does not need me to speak on the tangible matters about which the Bill relates because our side, in contrast to the ALP, has had a series of very qualified speakers who understand the wool industry and who, in fact, nearly to a man and woman have some involvement in the wool industry. They are experienced people; they understand the wool industry; they understand the problems; and they have contributed to the solutions which the Opposition has proposed. We cannot propose all the solutions because we are not in government and, were we in government, I venture to say that the problems in which the wool industry finds itself would be nowhere near as bad as they are at the moment.

I wanted to address the Senate on aspects of the Bill which were referred to in the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I do not, of course, purport to speak for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee or any other member of that Committee. The Committee will issue a report in due course but, with the way things go, that report may come well after the Bill is dealt with by this Parliament.

I wish to bring to the Senate's attention, as other speakers have done, proposed section 140 of the Wool Marketing Act as it will be when amended by this Bill. The proposed section 140 gives the Minister the power by notice in the Gazette to:
. . . issue guidelines for and in relation to the making of supplementary payments to wool producers . . .

That power authorises the Minister to spend very large sums of money that are put under his control to deal with a particular problem. But the Minister has to account to no-one; he simply has to make his decision and publish it in the Gazette. The Parliament will have absolutely no scrutiny in relation to that matter. It really means that the Executive-the Minister-will be able to spend large amounts of money and make decisions in relation to very public matters without any scrutiny from this Parliament. That is a situation which should be highlighted, and it is something that we urge the Government to be very careful about incorporating in legislation.

I should mention that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is actually a standing committee of the Senate put into place to watch the powers of Executive Government. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is authorised or asked to look at all Bills that come before Parliament with particular reference to scrutinise:
. . . whether such Bills or Acts, by express words or otherwise- . . .
make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers;
make such rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable decisions;
inappropriately delegate legislative power; or insufficiently subject the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

In the course of carrying out its charter, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee particularly looked at this Act, and drew to the attention of both the Minister and the Senate the provisions of section 140, as they relate to matters which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is asked to look at.

Furthermore, there is an even worse provision of the Act, proposed section 144, which provides that the Minister can issue guidelines in relation to reducing the indebtedness of the Australian Wool Corporation. In this instance the Minister does not even have to do as much as report it in the Gazette. At least in proposed section 140, the first instance I referred to, the Minister has to give notice in the Gazette. In this particular instance, he makes a decision in relation to a very large sum of money and does not even have to publish it, let alone submit it to the scrutiny of Parliament.

This is a matter that particularly the people of Australia and the people who represent the people of Australia in this Parliament, and particularly in this Senate, have to be very careful of. I would certainly urge the Government to reconsider those two aspects of the Bill, particularly as they relate to the Minister doing things without allowing his actions to be subject to the scrutiny of this Parliament.

Finally, I wish to speak on the amendment that our side of Parliament has proposed to what will be section 148 (2) (b) of the Act if it is incorporated. As has been mentioned, it gives the Minister power by regulation to amend any part of this Act, that is, any provision of this Act as amended.

When that sort of thing happens one might as well send parliament home because the Minister can completely rewrite the Act by regulation. Admittedly, if it is done by regulation-and at least it does have to be done by regulation-it can be referred to by the Senate and can, in due course, be disallowed by the Senate. But, as I understand the Constitution, until it is disallowed, the amendments that the Minister makes to the Act stand. He has enormous powers in that regard.

It is a very frightening day when this Parliament abrogates its responsibilities and gives to the Executive Government the power not just to make decisions in relation to certain matters, as it has in proposed new sections 140 and 144, but in this case rewrite the whole Act by regulation. That is a matter which should be viewed very seriously by this Parliament and the people of Australia. It is for that reason that the Liberal and National parties have moved to amend the Bill-to remove that provision; to take away from the Minister the power to rewrite the Act by regulation.

I urge the Senate to seriously consider the matters addressed by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee which caused it a lot of concern and which it referred back to the Minister with a `please explain' note. I hope that the Minister will explain during this debate, either now at the second reading stage or in committee, why he needs those powers and why we as a parliament should allow him those powers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very sad week for us to be debating the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991 because it highlights the appalling situation that the wool industry has fallen into, or been led into, over the last two or three years. Like my colleague Senator Macdonald, who spoke before me, I wish to draw attention to the good work done by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and, like Senator Macdonald, invite the Government to respond at some stage to the concerns raised by that Committee. The work the Committee does is just another example of the behind the scenes work that the Senate does to improve legislation brought forward by the House of Representatives which, frankly, does not pay attention to the detail of improving legislation that the Senate, through its committee system, does.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a sense of deja vu about this debate because everyone is running around saying this is not their fault. It is quite amazing. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) seems to say it is not his fault-heaven knows why: he has been in charge of the portfolio for some time and is a very well-respected man. But there are many serious questions that he needs to answer about the state of his knowledge at certain times and how incompatible some of his remarks could be seen to be with the state of his knowledge. He says that he is not responsible, and the Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation say they are not responsible.

The sense of deja vu lies with the Premier in my State. We have just had some quite disastrous financial revelations about the State Bank of South Australia. Those revelations are not surprising to the business community and my State colleagues have been talking about this matter for months and months. The problem relates to a significant number of off balance-sheet companies, which means that the state of indebtedness-assets and liabilities-does not have to be reported in the annual report. If that is all the Premier bothers to look at, all he will find will be the on-balance sheet assets and liabilities. But what does the Premier say?-he is, after all, the Treasurer of that State- `I did not know; it is not my fault'. I have been amazed. My Party, the Liberal Party, is not in government; the coalition is not in government either here or in my State. But whenever anything goes wrong, either here or in my State, the relevant Minister says, `It is not my fault'. If Ministers are not prepared to take responsibility and own up to what is their fault and what they are responsible for, and if they cannot do their jobs, they should get out. There are plenty of people on this side of the chamber who are more than willing to take over their tasks.

TALK.START.PARA: —As they should do under the Westminster system.

—As my colleague Senator Olsen, who has recently made the wise choice to move from the State Parliament to this better place, says, under the Westminster system they should get out if they cannot do the job.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. There are a number of what, to some, might seem technical points but there is good reason for them to be made. Under this Bill, the Minister would have the power to issue guidelines, as my colleague Senator Macdonald said, for and in relation to the making of supplementary payments to wool producers. Pursuant to a particular subsection in the legislation, he has that responsibility from the date the legislation commences until a date to be fixed by proclamation. Similarly, pursuant to proposed new section 143, from the date the legislation commences to a date to be fixed by proclamation, the Corporation is prohibited from operating the reserve price scheme. What is particularly unusual about both of those sections-that is, the power to make these particular guidelines and the prohibition on the Wool Corporation-is that there is a date at which these things commence, but there is no date at which they finish.

We have traditionally drawn to the attention of the Senate any legislation which does not have a clear commencement date on it. It has got to be within six months. It is not open-ended where we say, `We will pass a Bill which will come into effect some day, never, maybe, or whenever. All you poor sods out there can keep looking out to see if it is ever proclaimed'. It is totally unacceptable to have that attitude. There has to be a time limit where we say, `This Bill will come into effect not later than' and nominate some time. So if it is unacceptable to have a piece of legislation passed but not operative until some not yet nominated date in the future, and to have that in an open-ended way, surely it is unacceptable to have powers or responsibilities similarly cast in an Act. It is the same thing. We know the starting date, but we do not know when it will finish.

What makes this particularly unusual is the fact that proposed new section 147 would give the Minister some special powers for the purpose of amendments proposed by the Bill. However, for that particular section this would cease to have effect on 1 July 1992. The geniuses that put this legislation together have put a couple of clauses in giving rights and responsibilities in an open-ended way and not saying when they will end, but they have the capacity in relation to other rights being given under the Bill to nominate when those rights will cease. It is a fair thing for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to draw this to the attention of honourable senators so that they can ask the Government what is going on.

One of the aspects of the maxim that we use-that one is presumed to know the law-is that there has to be some certainty in it. One element of certainty is not only that we use plain language and that people can understand what their rights and responsibilities are, but also that we do not set upon them the task of constantly having to check with someone whether an Act or power is still operative, or whether it has finally come into operation having been lying around in a basement somewhere for God knows how long. That is an element of uncertainty-not knowing when powers and rights and responsibilities come into effect or cease to have effect. That element of uncertainty makes it very difficult for ordinary citizens to know the law. Some might say, `Well, it doesn't matter. The Minister is not an ordinary citizen and neither is the Wool Corporation. They both know what they are doing'. I know a few wool producers who would not go along with the proposition that either the Minister or the Wool Corporation know what they are doing. In any event, it is not up to Parliament to distinguish between the capacity of one or another citizen. It is up to us to pass legislation that normal people can understand. That includes, as I say, understanding when it would begin and when it would end.

There are further problems drawn to the attention of the Senate by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. There is the question of the guidelines that are to be issued pursuant to proposed new section 140. Those guidelines simply have to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette; they do not have to be tabled in parliament. That means you, Madam Acting Deputy President, myself and honourable senators opposite do not get the opportunity to disallow them. We all know that frequently a disallowance motion on some regulations is put in to allow parliament to express its view about the regulations. It may not proceed to an actual disallowance, but at least the scrutiny is there and whoever is making those guidelines knows that someone is watching what he is doing. But in this case the Executive has been given the power to make these guidelines and to publish them in the Gazette, and then it is a free-for-all after that. That is simply not satisfactory.

There is also provision in clause 144 for the Minister to issue guidelines to the Corporation as to how it should reduce its indebtedness. There is no requirement for these guidelines even to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Some may say, `So what, that is a matter for the Corporation and the Minister and does not affect public rights and responsibilities'. Nonetheless, the Minister should explain why he believes that if the Executive is given this power Parliament should not have the capacity to scrutinise it.

Last, but not least, I turn to the Henry VIII clause, to clause 148(2) (b). As Senator Macdonald pointed out, this is a new provision which sets out the regulation making power attached to the legislation. This provision would, if enacted in this form, allow the making of regulations to amend any provision of this Act other than this part. That is unacceptable because it allows a piece of primary legislation which has to be debated here to be amended by subordinate legislation; that is, by regulations. If we think that the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill is worth our time debating these clauses, why do we take the view of saying to the Minister that if he wishes to change anything afterwards, that is acceptable and that the Minister can do that effectively for a substantial time without scrutiny? That is just not satisfactory.

I conclude by returning to the substance of the Bill as opposed to what I refer to as the parliamentary deficiencies in the drafting of the Bill and in the granting of the powers, rights and responsibilities. Let us come back to the problem that we now face. I speak from some knowledge of the hardship that this legislation will cause as I have woolgrowers in my family in New South Wales. As Senator Chapman pointed out, the woolgrowers in New South Wales have increased their production far beyond what is produced by the woolgrowers in South Australia, and that has caused a problem for people in my State. Nonetheless, that relationship gives me a small insight into the hardship that the wool industry is now facing.

That hardship has come about by changes to the Act in 1987 which gave the Wool Corporation and the wool industry their head. It allowed the agro-politicians, as somebody else said, to shoot themselves in the foot; it allowed them not to keep their own industry informed; it allowed them to let their industry believe that 870c a kilogram was an acceptable price when everybody knew that it was not. Everybody was kept in the dark about what was happening until the problem was insurmountable. This Government, with the knowledge that this problem was insurmountable, has shillyshallied around for months on end, which has caused devastation to the industry greater than otherwise should have happened. For that, the Government stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the past 24 hours this chamber has heard many versions of a theme. Listening to my colleagues express their views and feelings on the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill, it occurred to me that if the rural sector of Australia had been able to hear the debate, it would have realised that not one of us on this side of the chamber has made decisions lightly or easily about this difficult legislation, and in particular the termination of the wool floor price, or without knowing that our duties as politicians to make the right decision for the long term good of the industry often mean making hard and unpopular decisions. These are decisions which we know could hurt, and hurt badly, many families across Australia in the short term. But we must have the courage of our convictions or we should not be here in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator from South Australia, who has lived most of his life in the country, I recognise only too clearly the pain that this legislation and my Party's amendments may inflict in the short term. I accept the inevitable backlash from some sections of the rural community which no doubt I shall receive, especially for the view that we should terminate rather than suspend the reserve price scheme. But let there be no mistake that the sickness of that reserve price scheme was indeed terminal.

The Labor Government, to compound its sins, after allowing its policies effectively to dismantle the wool industry infrastructure, still wanted to take what I would term the coward's way out. It wanted to leave the matter in cold storage suspension for a few months, setting the perception that it would try to resuscitate it when it had no intention of so doing. That was cruelty and cowardice rolled into one. No-one could have breathed health back into that scheme. Many in the wool industry recognised that, but the fact that it took the Opposition to act on it illustrates yet again the failure upon failure of Labor decisions on wool since 1987.

Let us get back to some basics. The year 1987, not 1991, was the real end of the reserve price scheme. As it was legislated in 1972, it had worked and worked successfully. It worked because the checks and balances of government control were there. It did its job of providing wool users with a greater degree of price stability and predictability, so that they were encouraged to choose wool over other fibres. It also provided price stability for growers, which was an additional but subsidiary aim. But when in 1987 John Kerin abrogated responsibility for setting the reserve price through a change to the Wool Marketing Act, in effect he signed its death warrant.

The Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) has not been blameless either. Only avarice can explain its decision to jump the minimum reserve price in 1988-89 by 35 per cent to 870c a kilogram in one season. That price covered production costs also, which was not a reserve price scheme objective. It was also far above long term wool price trends and above sustainable price ratios between wool and alternative competing fibres. And it was a price set just as the textile industry was heading for a downturn. It was out of line and, as has been proved by our massive stockpile ever since, it was priced out of sight.

John Kerin's 1987 abrogation of responsibility coupled with the Wool Corporation's actions are the reasons that we are making the decisions we have to make here today. There is simply no point in talking in euphemisms about a situation that is so critical. Because of bad decisions Australia produces too much wool. The maximum amount that we have ever sold to the trade is 910 million kilograms. Yet last year's production was 1,049 million kilograms and this year's production is estimated to be 1,012 million kilograms. We have a stockpile of 4.8 million bales. At the same time we have attempted to charge too much for it, and for that our rural community is now suffering. It is the fault of Government mishandling and industry mismanagement and it takes hard but well-considered decisions to fix it.

I believe we have gone some way towards that with the carefully thought through amendment to the legislation proposed by the coalition. A return to free and open market competition is the only strategy for the survival of the wool industry in the long term. Unfortunately, but hardly, I suppose, unexpectedly, it is an issue clouded with emotion, for the country which once rode on the sheep's back is now shooting them. Nothing we do or say here today can change that in the short term. There is a crisis in rural Australia which this difficult legislation and the amendments we propose cannot, by themselves, cure. The Government's mishandling has taken us to the point of no return.

I, like most of my colleagues, was a supporter of what the reserve price scheme was, not what it became because of the Government's decisions. After supporting Government legislation to drop the floor price last year from 870c to 700c a kilo, in the vain hope that we could return to some degree of normality in the marketplace and provide some base for a future for our woolgrowers, all we could do was watch helplessly as the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing, charged with specific responsibilities and discharging those responsibilities effectively, in the process, perhaps unintentionally, effectively undermined those aims.

Whilst it was overseas researching why our wool was not selling, how to revitalise the industry and how to bring buyers back into the marketplace, the message was clear: price and quality. The revival of our wool industry is vital, yet here we had a committee, under the direction of the Government, travelling the globe and virtually saying, `At what price will you buy it? At 500c a kilo?'. No wonder the doors did not open up for us at 700c when we were sending signals like that out into the marketplace.

The long term future of our woolgrowers relies very much now on getting it right in this Parliament. Market forces must be allowed to prevail. Australian Wool Corporation borrowings must be limited if it is to survive the burden of debt, and also so that growers are not dealing with an open-ended scheme. The handling of the reduction of the stockpile must be legislated for if growers and buyers are to have any security at all, for why should they trust government after the debacles of the last few years?

Rural Australia-and, I suppose, many of us who live in and have small businesses in rural Australia-will understand the impact that this crisis has had, as with the grain crisis, as with the recession, as with high interest rates and as with the Government's economic policies. We need to get it right not only as it relates to this piece of legislation before the chamber now; it is also important to underscore the importance of the 12 March industry statement to this Parliament. That is a statement which will tackle, one would hope, a number of policy areas that will be crucial not only to manufacturing industry and job opportunities in that area but also to rural Australia, which has to go through our port system to access world and international markets.

I talk of micro-economic reform; transport; communications; our waterfront, in particular; our infrastructure; our fiscal policy-and so the list goes on. We look forward to the 12 March statement setting a signpost for the future that we are going to, for once, get some of the policy settings of Government right so that we can relieve the burden that has been on the shoulders of small business across this country now for far too long-small business that simply cannot sustain those on-costs. With this piece of legislation we have a particular component of the rural industry, primary production, that has gone through enormously difficult times not necessarily the result of the individual -the small business operator out there on the farm-but through Government mishandling and industry mis- management.

I hope that the legislative measures that we take today will at least start the return of the wool industry in the long term to its rightful place in this country as an important component of our export market potential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991. I say from the outset that it seems to me that the wider Australian community has not yet become as conscious as we would expect it to be of the devastation that will prevail in the rural sector-particularly the wool sector-in the next 12 months. It is like the recession that we are currently experiencing. We are far from the bottom. There will be an enormous economic cost to this country. We know the prognosis now is for a reduction of 67 per cent in gross income for the average farmer. We know there will be a very significant reduction in rural land prices per se, as many producers are driven out of the industry and become bankrupt.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be enormous social implications and upheavals to so many rural families, because Australia is one of those countries whose rural industry is very much based on the family farm; farms which have been held for generations by the same families, who have acquired special skills and talents in that area but who do not necessarily have any corresponding skills in other areas. When families are removed from an area they know so well it will have enormous implications for them. As they face bankruptcy there will be enormous pressures on the fabric of those families.

There is provision in this Bill for a rural counselling program but that, of course, could go only part of the way to assisting in the consequences which will befall us. The economic consequences are not restricted to the various families that will be driven off their farms, but will have very significant effects in rural towns around Australia as they are beginning to do.

Can I say, and not in a glib way, that it was predictable that we would reach the position we are now in. It achieves no good end to have recriminations. It is unhelpful to saw sawdust in resurrecting the reasons why we are where we are, provided we understand the consequences for any industry that insulates demand from supply-the results, of course, are absolutely compelling and inevitable.

The Australian Wool Corporation seemed to imagine that the high was the norm. It seemed to imagine that there was no elasticity in demand. It seemed to imagine that wool was not price sensitive. It seemed to believe that Australia had a mortgage on the production of quality wool. The truth is to be found elsewhere. We all know, as we artificially held up our wool price at 870c a kilo, that our competitors were becoming more efficient and more competitive, and they are now into our markets. I note that between 1986-87 and 1988-89 the floor price went from 508c a kilo to 870c a kilo, an increase of 70 per cent in the floor price in that short time.

It was no longer a floor price. It was no longer a safety net. It was no longer fulfilling the function for which it was originally intended. One can say now, with 20-20 vision, that there are other ways, other mechanisms, to smooth out the highs and the lows, the peaks and the troughs. Be that as it may, we moved from a position of having a safety net to one of having a minimum price. The minimum price for the first time in 1988-89 rose above the long term average price. It was inevitable to anybody who knows the slightest thing about such matters that there had to be a downturn, and that the downturn would be significantly below the minimum price. Yet we faithfully held on to this minimum price of 870c.

The consequences are all around us. The Wool Corporation has debts of $2.8 billion, with a $4.8m stockpile anticipated in 1991-92, to climb as high as eight million bales in the following year, and to reach 8.6 million bales, with that debt continuing to blow out to the point where the support scheme will be in deficit by $4 billion. It was inevitable that very quickly we would arrive at a position where the Corporation was technically bankrupt, technically insolvent, where no longer would the 25 per cent tax-or whatever figure was put on it-cover the cost of the purchases, the maintenance and the interest repayments.

In the past when we found ourselves with an oversupply, there was a simple solution: the Government unilaterally devalued the Australian currency. That made our wool more competitive because it was cheaper for overseas purchasers. We now live in the real world. We now have a floating currency of sorts. Originally, when the dollar was first floated, it adjusted as it should have: it went down. But, thanks to this Government's economic chaos, the dollar in recent times has strengthened and stayed at the higher level because of an artificially held high interest rate. That has meant that the stockpile has become worth less and it has been a great deal more difficult to sell it on the world markets.

One can look back to see why in the past two years, the last 12 months in particular, the price of wool has collapsed. One has only to look at the economic chaos that is being wreaked throughout the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to understand, at least in my view, that the purchases are neither short term nor medium term and, whatever the description of long term might be, it will be some considerable time before the Soviet Union has a capacity to come back into our market at the levels that existed previously. Much of that is also true of China, although its financial circumstances are quite different. I suspect that this year there will be a worldwide reduction in demand because we will have an ever-increasing contraction in the world economy.

As I say, we are living the reality of allowing an insulation of demand over price. We now have excess stock of about 185,000 sheep. I think that New South Wales increased its flock by 40 per cent in the past couple of years. The average amount of wool sold is 750 million kilograms and we are now producing in excess of 1,000 million kilograms. There is no sign that that production will retreat other than by taking the steps that have been proposed in this legislation.

I raise one matter which does not have universal support, certainly not on the Government side and I suspect in modest terms not on this side. I notice that the legislation proposes to wind down the slaughter scheme. In part it has been effective; it has taken out about 10 million sheep. That has not dramatically reduced production because the sheep that have been removed are those least likely to produce quality wool.

As I say, we are presently producing about 1,000 million kilograms. It is suggested that abolishing the scheme will quickly reduce production. It is my view that that will not happen for at least two years. For the next two years we will have depressed prices that continue to be forced down by oversupply. To get production equivalent to demand means taking out about 250 million kilograms, or removing 40 million or 50 million sheep. The target originally set by the slaughter scheme was to take out 50 million kilograms, and I understand that that was based on a projection of slaughtering 15 million to 20 million sheep. To remove 250 million kilograms from the market requires a slaughter of between 40 million and 50 million sheep. For reasons that are not thoroughly clear to me-no doubt the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Cook) will explain it in due course-we are not proceeding with an enhanced slaughter scheme, which would have reduced production significantly. Until such time as supply comes in line with demand, prices will continue to be depressed.

I conclude by saying that this is the first step in putting some order into the wool market in Australia. It will cause enormous dislocation. There is no panacea, no easy solution, no way of avoiding a crisis, no way of preventing bankruptcies, no way that we can prevent many families from being forced from the land. The sooner we can get the price up by getting production down so that wool is on the market at the right price, the sooner we will have some stability in the industry. This legislation, notwithstanding its flaws, is the first step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament is debating the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991. On behalf of the Government I begin by thanking all honourable senators-and there have been quite a number-who have made a contribution to this debate. Clearly, not all of the views expressed are views that the Government necessarily supports. This debate has shown that, from vastly different philosophical positions and, from within parties, some different considerations and principles, there is a core view that concentrates on the passage of this Bill in the second reading. The indications are that the Government will achieve a second reading of this Bill. The Opposition has moved an amendment, which we will oppose. But I expect that the second reading will be passed.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of amendments are proposed to be moved during the committee stage by the spokesman for the Liberal Party of Australia, Senator Grant Tambling; the Leader of the National Party, Senator Ron Boswell, who is now just entering the chamber; and I think the spokesman for the Australian Democrats, Senator Bell, although I need to be advised on that. As I speak, there is still some toing and froing in terms of discussions about some of those amendments.

The amendments and the totality of the debate show that there is unanimity on the point that significant change is needed here and this issue needs to be sorted out. There might be differences of degree. Nonetheless, the thrust of what we are proposing is fair enough. I say that, acknowledging the views that have been put forward.

I begin by saying that the Government intends to oppose two of Senator Tambling's amendments when they are moved in the committee stage. There has been some discussion between the parties on amendment No. 3 on the list as circulated. As I speak, I am advised that there is agreement to a compromise outcome which would obviate the need to move amendment No. 3 on the list as circulated.

The Government's understanding of that is as follows. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has asked me to put forward the following compromise position on the understanding that it is acceptable to the Liberal and National parties-and I understand it is-and, I hope, the Democrats. This will obviate the need for the amendment to proposed section 148 (2) (b) in the name of Senator Tambling.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, notes, first, that it is his intention that proposed section 148 (2) (b) apply only to the operation of the supplementary payment scheme and that it not be included in the legislation package to be brought forward later this session, and should not be seen to create a precedent. Secondly, he reiterates his undertaking to the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Lloyd, to adequately consult the shadow Minister on the use of proposed section 148 (2) (b) should he ever contemplate using it. Further, he extends his undertaking to adequately consult on the use of proposed section 148 (2) (b) to the Democrats spokesman. It is well to have that out in front.

The debate entered into has covered a wide area. Many points have been raised. It is inappropriate-indeed, time is not sufficient-for me to refer to each particular speaker in this debate, isolate the points in each address and reply in each case to each one. For the convenience of the Senate, I have reduced my reply to seven significant points. The first is: what has the Government done? The Government has announced a package of measures to address the critical situation facing the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and woolgrowers and outlined a two-stage plan to ensure that the situation is stabilised and that recovery can begin. There have been media releases which list those measures. They are well known in this chamber. I say that up front because demonstrated in this debate has been a clear understanding of the progressive development of this issue.

Why has the Government suspended the minimum reserve price for wool? This question underpins many of the comments. The Government has taken action in response to the following unprecedented series of events: the continuing deterioration of the wool market; the rapidly growing stockpile of wool held by the Australian Wool Corporation, currently nearly five million bales; the burgeoning borrowings of the Australian Wool Corporation, now close to $3 billion; the ever-increasing wool levy necessary for growers to pay for the interest on the debt from 25 per cent this year to 35 per cent in 1991-92; the opposition, by a large number of growers, to the introduction of quotas in 1991-92, which is an integral part of the AWC strategy; the doubtful outlook for wool markets in the near term, especially in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) and China; and the apparent lack of recognition, at least publicly, by the wool industry leaders of the enormity of the situation.

All of these have resulted in the need for the Government to take action to ensure that this vital industry does not bankrupt itself completely. The measures announced are directed over the next few years to lead to the recovery of the Australian wool industry. Whilst painful for all concerned in the short term, in the medium term the recovery plan will enable Australian wool to compete effectively for markets. The measures provide for confidence and stability to be returned to wool markets, which in recent times have been suffering under the uncertainty created by the public recognition that the debt level of the Australian Wool Corporation was not sustainable. In short, they are the reasons why we have suspended the move to suspend the minimum reserve price for wool.

In some of the comments made there was an accusation made that the Government has waited too long to act. Why has that been the case? How do I answer that? The Government has not been sitting on its hands; it has been taking actions to address this problem since the world market for wool began to collapse in November 1989, more than one year ago. Over that period a wide range of measures has been implemented by the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation to try to restore confidence in the market and put the wool industry on the road to recovery. Dropping the floor price last year, the loan guarantees, the Vines committee inquiry, the establishment of the interim wool policy council, Mr Kerin's call for a business plan and a strategic plan for the Australian Wool Corporation, the wool mission overseas, the $400m USSR credit facility-these are examples of the actions we have been taking throughout a very difficult period.

However, despite the adoption of this range of measures, the situation has, as we know, continued to deteriorate, largely as a result of continuing speculation that the scheme itself was unsustainable. Other influences have hit as well, such as the crisis in the USSR-who could have foretold that?-and the Gulf war. Who could have foretold the certainty of that conflict? For those reasons the Government has not acted dilatorily; waited too long. In fact, it has been tracking this matter with the most reasonable responses in the circumstances at the time.

One of the other criticisms raised is: what is the cost of all this? It is not possible to calculate the actual cost to the Australian taxpayer of all the measures that we have taken until we are able to see what happens to the price of wool in the absence of a floor price. The direct cost to the Government of the assistance package to alleviate the impact of changing the game mid-season, as we know from this Bill, will be $300m.

A question that has underpinned the debate is: why should the wealthy growers be given any assistance? Of course, not all woolgrowers are wealthy. In fact, many have relatively low net incomes. In the absence of any assistance, growers yet to sell their wool in the current season would suffer the full impact of price falls. This would place them at a severe disadvantage in comparison with growers who sold their wool in the earlier part of the season with the support of the reserve price scheme.

For example, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates that sheep specialist farmers yet to sell their wool will face an average farm-cash operating surplus of minus $19,500 for the year compared with the same surplus of $15,100 that they could have expected with the continuation of the scheme. A means test based approach would be impossible administratively and would not work. Many growers receiving large payments have, of course, low incomes.

I wish to reply to two other points. The first is: would retaining the 700c reserve price as proposed by the Australian Wool Corporation not have been better? The second is: did the Government not create this crisis by dropping the reserve price in May 1990, an allegation which has been embodied in much of the argument that we have heard in this debate?

Let me reply to the first of those two points. The Australian Wool Corporation's draft strategic plan incorporated the following: the retention of the 700c per kilogram floor price; the introduction of marketing quotas of 700 kilotons from 1 July 1991 for a period of two years; a 35 per cent wool tax; a flock reduction scheme; and more aggressive wool marketing.

This scheme has been carefully examined and not accepted as the most advantageous because it results in the Australian Wool Corporation's debt continuing to rise to nearly $4 billion, with total stocks of wool possibly growing by 8.7 million bales by 1995-96 compared with 4.8 million now. Because it relies partly on the introduction of unpalatable marketing quotas, it also presumes that if there is any further deterioration in the situation, the Government will pick up the tab.

These outcomes compare with a no floor price approach where the AWC stocks fall from their present level of 4.8 million bales to around 1.5 million bales by 1995-96 and debt peaks with a 12 per cent wool tax at $3.1 billion and then declines to $69m in 1995-96. In all options examined, grower incomes are very low or negative in 1991-92 and recover only slowly over the next few years.

Let me answer the accusation: did the Government not create this crisis? No, of course we did not. The cause of the collapse has been an unprecedented combination of events. The only events that could have been foreseen, which I will now address, were that the reserve price scheme would be put under stress with a floating exchange rate; that a minimum reserve of 870c per kilogram would induce extra production; and the negative reaction to customers to the very high prices of 1987-88. These three factors were foreseen but ignored.

The minimum reserve price was dropped to 700c per kilogram for the following reasons: at this level it would be roughly on a par with long term price relationships with cotton and polyester without unduly hurting users who would just have experienced a rapid rise and fall in wool prices over three to four years; it would limit the cost of buying into an already excessively large stockpile, thereby helping to finance storage costs; because the 18 to 20 per cent wool levy was not considered adequate to influence growers to reduce production rapidly, it would send a price signal to growers to at least limit production. Since July 1990 the situation has deteriorated in communist countries and Western economies. The Iraq war is the culmination of a long sequence of events that, in themselves too, were unprecedented.

As the situation got worse, Mr Kerin asked the AWC for a business plan for the 1990-91 season and a three-year strategic plan for 1991-92 to 1993-94. Recommendations of the AWC and the WCA in October 1990 resulted in the Government agreeing to end or legislating for a 25 per cent levy for 1990-91; a possible levy up to 30 per cent and a surcharge of up to an additional 20 per cent; an open-ended borrowing guarantee by the Government but with monitoring; the minimum reserve price to be set at 700c per kilogram to June 1992; auction sales to be restricted to 140,000 bales per week; a humane flock reduction scheme; a middle market campaign; additional credit facilities for overseas customers; and the introduction of marketing quotas for the 1991-92 season.

These measures, except for the marketing quotas and the possibility of a large flock reduction program, are now in place. It was hoped that in the peak December-January selling period, together with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics back in the market, the Wool Corporation's business plan would work. For it to work required a buy-in rate of 28 per cent of the remainder of the current season. The buy-in rate plummeted in January to about 30 per cent but progressively returned to unacceptably high levels over the next two weeks.

Faced with a rapidly expanding stockpile, the knowledge that the buy-in rate was far too high and the prospect that the Wool Corporation may not have the finances to continue for much longer, the Wool Corporation decided on 21 January to defer sales for three weeks to enable it and the Government to consider their positions. The result of the Government's consideration of its position is, of course, this legislation tonight.

I conclude my second reading reply by saying that Senator Tambling has moved a motion to add certain words to the second reading motion. The Government opposes that amendment. It is an amendment which, in effect, calls for the termination of the minimum reserve price. First, I must say in relation to that amendment that we have stated the ground rules for any future minimum reserve price. Those ground rules specify that it must be self-funding and that any floor must be conservatively set well under the prevailing market price.

Secondly, the Vines Committee has already received submissions on minimum reserve price issues. The Committee will report at the end of March and we shall await that report. Thirdly, the Government's suspension of the scheme has provided a breathing space in which all sectors of the industry can discuss the future of the minimum reserve price. This is something that we were not able to do while the minimum reserve price was in place in an operating market. The Opposition amendment, if carried, would cut off that consideration.

The Opposition also ignores all of the complex consequential amendments that would flow from immediate termination of the minimum reserve price including, presumably, the immediate abolition of the Australian Wool Council, the sacking of staff, the Government taking over the debt, the total Government management of the stockpile and the complete derangement of promotion plans and research and development plans. For those reasons we will not be supporting the amendment to the second reading that was moved by Senator Tambling.

I did intend to conclude at this point. However, it has been drawn to my attention that during the second reading debate this morning Senator West of the Australian Labor Party commented that the guidelines for the management of the stockpile until 30 June have been released and that they will be included in the guidelines which will be published in a special gazette tomorrow if the Bill is passed. A number of senators opposite seemed to be unaware of those facts when Senator West was making her speech. Senator West's comments were factually correct, notwithstanding the comments that they drew in reply. I am happy to make the AWC announcement available to honourable senators opposite, if they wish. I table a copy of it for the information of the Senate.

That concludes the reply on behalf of the Government. I look forward to joining honourable senators opposite if this Bill is debated at the committee stage. I commend to the Senate the second reading of this Bill but not the amendment moved by the Opposition.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 2, proposed subsection 141(2), line 23, omit ``(whatever the source of that money)'', substitute ``(whatever the source of that money, but amounts payable from so much of that money as is attributable to payments to the Corporation under paragraphs 47(1) (a) and (d) are not to exceed in the aggregate $200,000,000)''.

This matter was canvassed in quite some detail by a number of speakers during the second reading debate. I will not take up a lot of the time of the Senate in retracing many of those arguments. Suffice to say that the proposals that have been put forward by the Government would achieve a much higher loan facility being available to the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC). It would increase the Wool Corporation's borrowing under the Government's proposals to some $3.5 billion plus to pay for an open-ended supplementary scheme which would have critically threatened the viability of the AWC. Therefore, the total potential pay-outs would have been the $300m that is separately appropriated. This gives considerable cause for concern.

I argue very strongly that there needs to be a degree of discipline in this regard which is in the interests of the long term financial viability of many of the woolgrowers. It is a matter that requires our urgent attention. It is necessary to place a cap on these borrowing facilities in this regard.

The coalition would endeavour to limit the scheme to $500m-the $300m from the Government subsidy and the remaining $200m, which I am now proposing in this amendment, from the industry. This would take the current borrowings from just over $2.8 billion to a figure slightly in excess of $3 billion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats intend not to support the amendment because the effect would be that there would only be some $500m available for the supplementary payment scheme. Because some 40 per cent of woolgrowers have yet to offer their wool for sale, the cap would mean that there would be likely to be insufficient funds available to meet these supplementary payments. Therefore, those 40 per cent of woolgrowers would be likely not to be equitably served by the wool sales which have occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument could be put, and I have heard this argument, that the Australian Wool Corporation could find additional funds by flogging off some of its assets or raising money in ways other than loans. The effect of that would be to emasculate that organisation to such an extent that it would not be able to fulfil its duties to guide the industry through this very perilous time. To constrict it in such a way as suggested here would be counterproductive in the extreme. We cannot see any reason for that. The producers who have contacted us in this regard have begged us not to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I canvassed this point this afternoon in my speech in the second reading debate. I calculated that from 1 July next year the wool tax on existing woolgrowers will be roughly 20 per cent. It will work out at 20 per cent if we put a cap on it at $3 billion. In other words, if this amendment were to be successful and we were locked in at $200m out of the Corporation, giving a total debt of $3 billion, we would need approximately $400m per year in interest alone.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking my estimation, and a lot of other people's estimation, of next year's wool clip being worth $2 billion, if we put $400m over $2 billion and multiply it by 100, it works out at 20 per cent. This applies if there is a cap on at $3 billion. There are estimates around that for sales between next week and 30 June of the stockpile that is available the bill may run up to $1 billion extra and we could finish up at $3.8 billion.

I know that figures of $600m to $700m have already been admitted to, but I believe that could blow out to $1 billion. If we finish up-being conservative and to make the figures easy-with a $4 billion debt, we will need a 40 per cent wool tax on the growers next year, assuming that we average 300c greasy. If it does not average 300c greasy, the 40 per cent figure will go higher. If it averages more than that, it will come down. To make it easy, I have allowed for $4 billion; but if we use $3.8 billion-because that is, in my guess and the guess of plenty of others, where it will finish up-then we will need approximately 36 per cent to cover it.

I am assuming that we are going to get 300c. Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) tell me how any grower, even if he is viable now, is going to survive on that? He will be getting 300c greasy, as I just said, and if we take 40 per cent of that, it is 120c per kilo off. That leaves 180. If we multiply that figure by 200 kilos per bale we get $360 per bale. No woolgrower will be viable.

So this is affecting the future of Australian woolgrowers-because we will not get out of this for the next five years-for the sake of worrying about that 40 per cent who have not sold their wool. But I am not wiping them off because, as Senator Bell admitted himself when he spoke, they could be looked after by the fixed assets of the Corporation-wool stores that they can do without because this system, if it is not finished now, will be finished after 1 July. They can be fixed up then. Those woolgrowers can be given the first lien on those assets to bring them back up. We could have that $500m cap that the Opposition will agree to under the amendment, plus what the Government is putting in. With $500m we can make advanced payments to the ones who sell between now and 1 July-a certain amount by advanced payments-and by 1 July we will know exactly what is owed and then we can use these other fixed assets or mortgage them to square up those woolgrowers.

My question to the Minister, and I want him to answer it, is: how many woolgrowers will be viable with what is left after the Corporation gets almost 40 per cent, if they are lucky enough to get 300c greasy, which is 600c clean? Tell me how anyone is going to be viable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment. If the loan is extended to $3.5 billion it will put an almost impossible burden onto the remaining growers. There will be casualties in the industry. If the loan is extended to $3.5 billion and the wool makes 300c at auction, the tax will be 41 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: If that tax comes off the 300c, we will make the viable growers less viable and they will not be able to sustain their businesses. I accept the intention of the amendment and I know where it is going, but-and I say this with a fair degree of worry-the Government is trying to strengthen the weak but will end up weakening the strong. In the end all this will do is create more casualties because the Government is burdening the industry with a debt it is incapable of repaying. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has encouraged the Australian Wool Corporation to go even further into debt. The Government had guaranteed a $3 billion debt which it says the Corporation could take and now says that that amount should be extended to $3.5 billion. The Government is now encouraging the Corporation to take out an additional debt of $700m. Whose debt will this be? It will not be the Government's debt, nor will it be the Corporation's debt; it will be the woolgrowers' debt. The woolgrowers are already $2.8 billion in debt; that means each farmer is currently in debt for $55,000. On that $2.8 billion debt woolgrowers are paying annual interest of $400m and the levy they are paying deals only with the interest. The Government wants the woolgrowers to take an additional debt and that additional debt would put growers in debt to the tune of $69,000 each. That means that the annual interest on that $3.5 billion would increase from $400m to $600m.

SPEECH.PARA: The woolgrowers left in the industry after the dreadful debacle the Government has created will be expected to cover the interest on that $3.5 billion debt with no floor price, because after June there will be no floor price. If the Minister and the Government are not truthful now, when are they going to start being truthful? After June there will be no floor price but the interest on the debt alone will be $600m. What has the Minister calculated if, as Senator Panizza suggested, that debt stays at $3.5 billion and does not increase to $4 billion? What will be the levy imposed on every farmer and grower left in the industry to pay the annual interest of $600m on the debt? I would like the Minister to calculate the levy payable under those circumstances; I am sure his Department has already done so.

If the Minister thinks for one minute that any grower can pay a 20 per cent levy without any floor price, he has another think coming because the whole industry will collapse around his ears; and that would be as a direct result of the Government encouraging the Corporation to take out additional debt. I do not know how growers will cope with the interest they already have, but to allow them to take out, and to encourage them to take out, that additional $700m is grossly irresponsible. I request again: what levy will growers be paying once the floor price is gone after 30 June?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two issues under this heading. Firstly, to carry on from where Senator Walters got to, in my office we have been doing quite a lot of number crunching to try to work out where these figures are heading. I do not know which figures are easier for the average farmer to understand, but on the quantity of wool we have in storage at the moment and on the costs the Minister has himself used, each bale of wool is losing value at a rate of 60c a day. The total cost of interest is now in excess of $1m a day and the cost of storage and interest on the wool we have at present is $1 billion a year. I do not know-and the Government has not said-what it would presume the recovery value of the existing stockpile to be under the circumstances it has in mind for its disposal, but in the course of my speech in the second reading debate I quoted one journalist who said that under express disposal conditions, the likes of which will probably have to happen, the whole stockpile, whatever it has cost and whatever it may technically be worth, may be struggling to bring more than, say, $2 billion. How will we fund that? Who will fund it and who will be left with that $55,000 per grower debt?

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a matter of raising money. In my previous business, before I came here, I always used to say to people borrowing money, `Money is hard to borrow; it is a lot harder to pay back'. I think we are now seeing it the way it is. A few months ago one of the arguments used was that the value of money was changing and that interest rates were coming down. I do not believe interest rates are coming down at present and I do not think they will come down for some time so we cannot bank on saying, `Oh well, if we started off at this level, it will get better'.

The second issue is an associated one which I raised with the Minister. I asked the Minister to ensure that, as a matter of equity, private treaty wool merchants be included for consideration in the deficiency payments scheme. We all look forward to the regulations and guidelines in this instance and I will look forward to finding out how the private buyers are taken into account in the proposal. We all know that the private buyer is generally a fairly small business which does a mighty job in country areas around Australia. Recently those private buyers have continued their jobs; they have been working on the Government's and the Australian Wool Corporation's undertakings; they have been buying wool and they have been paying people, particularly people who have been short of money. Many of them had wool ready for the auction system but due to decisions outside their control those sales were cancelled and the credit of those buyers is now very tightly stretched. From a recent letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), I note that at the time the sales were stopped the buyers had stock of 40,000 bales with a value of approximately $18.7m, which is only about $400 per bale.

I have a particular consideration about these buyers; namely, that as from now we are going to need them with their expertise and dedication as we have never needed them before. The buyers should all have adequate records to verify their position and that all the wool that is under discussion is in first ownership after shearing: it is not wool from dealings; it is not wool that is second-hand; it is wool that has come straight from shearing.

In the overall level of funding under discussion, the amount is quite small-$18.7m-but the significance of the buyers in the future recovery of the woolgrowing industry is quite large. Therefore I believe that consideration of their particular case should be given and dealt with in the regulations and/or the guidelines. I look forward to having the regulations and guidelines to look at in the very near future because, as I said in the second reading debate, the growers are only one group in the overall wool industry, which includes the buyers, the brokers, the scourers, the processors, the manufacturers and, most importantly, the customers. No section of this industry can be prosperous without the co-prosperity of all the others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this amendment, I want to reiterate a couple of points that I made last night. I said firstly that it was a very sad and emotional day for me, being a woolgrower, and, secondly, as well as castigating a number of other people, I castigated myself for not trying a little harder 12 months ago when we saw what the situation obviously was.
—You should have persuaded your colleagues to do something different on that occasion.

—Just be a little bit quiet for a couple of seconds. We have heard enough from Senator Powell. The amendment before us is about putting some fiscal responsibility into the Australian Wool Corporation in terms of its expenditure and looking a little further down the track than the next four months and, in effect, minimising the mortgaging of our children's future. That is what we are doing in allowing the Corporation to have a virtual open chequebook in terms of this payout. A much better mechanism for the Government to use would be to adopt this amendment, give certain instructions to the Corporation regarding its assets and overheads and, in terms of money allowed to be borrowed, to pick up the difference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation does have significant assets. In addition, with the changes to the scheme it will not require the same overheads in operation, so both those things have to be looked at closely in terms of this situation. We need to make some calculations-and this is why I am looking a little further down the track-and I have made some, but it is almost impossible to do any calculations because there are two things that we do not know. However, one thing we do know is that over the next 12 months we are going to produce close to six million bales of wool-five and a half million or thereabouts. What we do know is that the average sales over the last 10 years have been just over four million bales. This year, if we are lucky, we may sell three million bales. So when we look at the debt against the possible sales we start looking at a horrendous taxation burden, and that is where the mortgaging of the future comes into it.

I am just going to run through some calculations which we did for the debt at its current level of about $2.8 billion. If in the next 12 months starting from 1 June we sell four million bales-which is the average for the last 10 years-at a price of 400c, the tax just to sustain the stockpile will be 22.7c. If the selling price is 375c, the tax will be 24.2c; if it is 300c, it will be 30.3c; and if it is 250c the tax will be 36c just to hold the stockpile-the holding costs.
