At this year's figures, if we sell 3.3 million bales at 400c, the tax will be 28.4c; at 375c, it will be 30.3c; at 300c, it will be 37.8c; and at 250c, it will be 45.4c. It does not matter which of those figures we select; by allowing the debt to blow out further we are increasing those figures and thereby creating a situation where there will be very few in the industry who can afford to pay.

In addition to that, a percentage of the wool will almost certainly be virtually unsaleable in the short term. I hope that all the wool sells and brings a reasonable price, as I think we all do, but we must be realistic. Those figures I have quoted include absolutely nothing for research and development, so that has to go on top of them. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has said that that issue will be addressed later on in the term-I understand next May.

We have to look not only at the short term but also at the medium short term, which is next year; the medium term, which is the year after that; and thereon in. In terms of handling this problem, I emphasise the necessity of placing some fiscal discipline on the Corporation in regard to its borrowing levels. We must have a situation whereby assets which will not be required in the future under the current arrangements are liquidated so as to meet the costs of the deficiency payment. We must also see a significant reduction in the overheads of the Corporation, because the role of the Corporation, with the sales coming up, will be significantly less than it was in the past. I just make a plea that honourable senators give consideration to what we are doing in terms of mortgaging our children's future and in making it virtually impossible for most woolgrowers to show any profit next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, there have been quite a number of figures quoted in the debate over this amendment. I would have thought it was plain that, with 40 per cent of the clip still to be offered for sale, 40 per cent of the growers would be asked to shoulder whatever deficiency there is between the $500m-which is being proposed as a total ceiling-and the potential total requirement, which could be anything up to $900m or even $1 billion. Those 40 per cent of growers will not receive the income under this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: However, if the money that is needed to meet that payment were to be shared across the entire industry, then 100 per cent of the growers would then be sharing in that debt. That is far more equitable than just allowing the 60 per cent who have been able to sell their wool so far to be at a considerable advantage by sheer good luck because nobody was able to predict what this Government was about to do to them, while the other 40 per cent just go singing in the wind for what they will not get.

If people are concerned about the future of the children who are involved in this industry, they should be concerned more about those 40 per cent who will be saddled individually with a huge debt. I cannot see the difference between not receiving the money and owing somewhat less all round. I would have thought that would be plain to anybody.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment and does so knowing, as we have just heard from the Australian Democrats, that they too oppose it. We welcome that support in defeating this proposal. I want briefly to reply to the debate and answer some of the questions that have been posed to me by honourable senators opposite. The best way of handling the reply is firstly to deal with the substance of the motion and then go to the comments of the individual senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling's motion proposes limiting grower input to the supplementary payment scheme to $200m. Far from helping woolgrowers, it is the Government's view that this amendment puts the effects of the suspension right back on those growers who happen to be selling between now and the end of June. Those growers selling between now and June would not get supplementary benefits under this proposal until July at the earliest. They would get a lesser payment than currently proposed. The Opposition is effectively saying to the growers, `You agree to $500m being put aside until the end of the season, and then we will stand back and watch while some other poor blokes work out what sort of scheme costing $500m can be put together. If you don't get any supplementary payment until August or September, it's your problem-not ours'. This is being described as a fiscally responsible policy which stands on the problems of the wool industry. The Opposition is being panicked by a number of back-of-the-envelope costings of this scheme. It is a feature of some of the questions asked of me. I am being asked to answer questions based on assumptions and back-of-the-envelope costings. There are a number of these back-of-the-envelope calculations floating around at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us yours.

—I am answering Senator Panizza's question and coming to the point. I hope Senator Panizza will not be too upset if I say, in all honesty, that he is presenting a back-of-the-envelope costing for me and one has to look at the assumptions involved in those sorts of costings. As far as the Government is concerned, a proper costing for the scheme takes account of these five elements, at least: the type of wool coming forward till June; the likely market response to those types; the provisions of the wool tax legislation; tax receipts; and cash flows. All of those elements have to be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The kinds of complications that do not really exist get taken into account on back-of-the-envelope calculations. I do not think it can be fairly said that all of those have been properly weighted in the calculations that have been put forward. When these complications are considered, the picture is a little different. We estimate, after careful work, the cost of supplementing growers receiving a 375c floor price equivalent at $677m. That amount is estimated to cover the difference between what the grower is paid and what he would have received in hand under the minimum reserve price scheme. This amendment, if carried, would allow supplementation only up to about 470c, not 525c, from a 375c floor price. The difference might not sound much, but it is about $65 per bale. I do not think the amendment achieves anything other than disruption in the industry.

I will answer some of the individual questions that have been asked. I think the first honourable senator to ask questions was Senator Panizza. He claimed that a 40 per cent tax would be required to meet the costs of a $3.8 billion, as I took it down, Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —A $4 billion debt.
—Senator Walters is changing the ground as we speak.
—Read Hansard.
—I will read Hansard. I said, `as I took it down'. Of course, we can all do back-of-the-envelope calculations, as Senator Panizza has done, based on false assumptions.
—He hasn't got an envelope at all.

—Then he has done them on the back of his hand or in his head. However he did them, they are trial balances arrived at on assumption. For a start, Senator Panizza uses a 300c price per kilogram greasy wool, whereas the Government has costed the scheme on a 375c price. The estimated levy to meet the cost of the borrowings up to $3.5 billion is nowhere near the 40 per cent he estimates. It is more like 12 per cent, plus the cost of promotion and research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as that, he has asked me how any grower is going to be viable if 40 per cent is taken out of the price he receives. This is an assumption, of course. It is not likely that anything remotely like a 40 per cent tax would be required in future years. It is likely that the tax rate would be considerably less in 1991-92 and later years than this year-1990-91. The net producer return, under suspension of the floor price, is likely to be higher than under a continuation of the 700c figure. It is under the 700c figure that very high tax rates would be required. So the assumption of 40 per cent is not accepted.

Senator Archer asked me about private buyers. Private buyers bought at discounts but then sold the wool at auction and received minimum reserve price support. In other words, private buyers received the benefits of the system, but did not pay the costs of supporting it. They did not bear commercial risk under the minimum reserve price system; the growers had to bear that risk for them. Now that that risk has come back to the growers, sales to private treaty wool merchants are eligible for grower support. Small private buyers are like all other buyers, fairing less when the market reopens.

However, Senator Archer ignores a few salient points. Firstly, if a private buyer is holding wool to sell on consignment for growers, the growers are eligible for support. Secondly, when the minimum reserve price was operating, private buyers were seeking a benefit that was more than 50 per cent paid for by growers. I understand the private buyers concern but find it difficult to support this argument, obviously, from what I have said. Senator Walters put a series of questions to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, only one.

—I took down at least two, but Senator Walters may have changed them to one. It may have been simply the way in which Senator Walters made her speech when she said that we want the AWC to take up further debt which was--
—Encourage.

—We are providing a facility; we are not saying that all of it needs to be taken up. That is a question of judgment. The fact that there is a facility does not mean that the whole of the facility has to be exploited or expended. Senator Walters's assumption that, by providing that facility, we are forcing them to do that is an assumption that is not true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow up Senator Cook's comments, but I will deal with private buyers first. Senator Cook said that private buyers got the benefit of the reserve price scheme without having to pay into it to get that support. That is wrong.
—They bought in at discounts.

—That may be Senator Cook's opinion, but the point is that the only discount was for freight. There was a discount on the freight that the farmer would have paid to the store and the broker would have discounted certain selling charges if the wool went to auction. That is all that was discounted. On that the growers paid their 25 per cent wool tax or whatever tax applied at that time. They processed so much wool and put back on the floor what was left over, getting the protection but without having to pay again. That was the situation under the old scheme. The fact that they had a heap of wool already catalogued in the sales that were cancelled I cannot see is any reason for leaving them out totally. They are not overseas companies. They are Australian companies that work-I will not go through all that again; I did so at the second reading stage-in this country and with farmers. They were left out without any explanation whatsoever until we questioned the Minister tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to Senator Cook's figures, and I assure him that I can generally do figures in my head without having to use the back of an envelope. I presume he meant that the price the industry will be getting from now until 30 June would be 375c, and I presume he meant that that would be the price for greasy wool. I am sure that he did not mean that it would be clean wool. For ease of calculation, I took a yield of 66 per cent, which I think is a pretty reasonable figure around Australia because dry areas yield only about 62 per cent and the better areas yield up to 70 per cent. I took my figure of 66 per cent to make it easier. On the back-of-the-envelope calculation or in my head I worked that out as 560c clean. But the Minister did not specify what sort of wool he had in mind-whether it was 21-micron or the average of the clip. Would he explain that? I believe that the industry has not a hope. If we have to get 560c clean for 21-micron wool when the floor was 700c before, and 60 per cent or 70 per cent was being passed in, I believe that the Minister is just looking at the blue sky. Those are the figures he used to debunk my argument that we could be slipping towards a 40 per cent wool tax.

I presume that another assumption the Minister made was that all the wool sold would remain constant. But it will not remain constant. What is available will remain constant for one year, as Senator Crane pointed out. We are heading towards another 5.5 million or 5.6 million bales for next year but, again as Senator Crane pointed out, we are not going to sell that. I think we have only ever sold about 3.8 million bales in one year. We will sell only that amount next year. Therefore, the tax has to be worked out on that and not the total amount that we produce. Then we have to discount in the years to come. This problem will not go away tomorrow. We shall have five years of the present position at least before we get out if we are lucky, and seven years if we are unlucky.

The production of wool in Australia will go down. I cannot see any woolgrower in his right mind who will keep producing wool at the present rate. There will be fringe woolgrowers, especially speculators, around the place-one honourable senator mentioned what would happen in New South Wales public stock routes. They will get right out. That production of 5.5 million bales can go down quite dramatically in three or four years time. I know that the Minister will say that the price will go up. I hope it will, but I do not think it will. Argentina and South Africa and other countries are now growing quite a bit of wool, and that will keep up the production and the price will not run away.

The Minister should think again and give the Committee an answer. He is asking us to give the industry an open cheque to run up what it needs. I have said before, and the Minister did not discount it, that that could be a billion dollars extra, as I think Senator Bell admitted. I believe that the Minister's figures are wrong because he based them on the wrong assumption. He based them on the assumption that production will stay and that the price will be 375c greasy, I presume, and I do not see that we will have a wool tax of anywhere less than 35 per cent. I hope that the Minister will give an answer on those points, especially as to what kind of wool he has in mind when he mentions a figure of 375c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) a number of questions. Perhaps I phrased my remarks badly and did not put them in the form of questions, but I shall do so now. In terms of the 12 per cent calculation for the tax next year to carry the cost, on how many bales of wool is that calculated and at what price greasy and at what price clean? I would also add that my calculations were not done on the back of an envelope-they were done by a consultant and I asked him to do them for me so that I could get somewhere near the mark.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the proposal to raise funds to meet this deficiency payment, what is the Government's attitude to the sale of the assets of the Australian Wool Corporation and what is its attitude to cutting back the overheads of the Corporation in view of its reduced role? While the Minister is obtaining those answers, I remind Senator Bell that I was not suggesting that growers should not be paid out in full. I was saying that the figure should be made up through the sale of assets and the cutting of overheads.

TALK.START.PARA: —All $700m?

—No. Senator Bell has heard the Minister's calculations and it is not $700m. There is another question I would like to ask the Minister. Is it correct that the Government's intention through the Wool Corporation is to net the price out at 525c and not charge the 25 per cent tax to the woolgrower? If that is correct, it substantially alters the figures and is different from what I was told the other day.

—There was only one question that I asked the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). Could he tell me what the Government proposes, or has worked out, the levy will be after 30 June if the floor price has been withdrawn?

—In addition to asking, as did my colleague Senator Crane, about the Government's attitude to the sale of assets, could I be somewhat more specific and ask what the Government has allocated to the sale of assets in his figures?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the last question, I can say that the answer is nothing. As for Senator Walters's question, I must say that I was distracted again when she framed her question but, as I understand her question, the answer is no, not at this stage.
—That does not answer the question.

—Perhaps Senator Walters could ask her question again and while she is framing it I will answer some of the other questions. Senator Panizza started his contribution on the second helping by talking again about the private treaty merchants. I say once again-and I shall continue to say this if the same questions are asked-that the purpose of the supplementary payments scheme is to benefit growers. The growers and not the private treaty merchants pay the tax. That must always be the consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element of Senator Panizza's questions was that he believes that my figures are wrong and that his are right. Well, a question of belief is an interesting philosophical debate. My figures are based on Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics calculations, which are based on the weighted averages for the market indicator price. There will be no accounting for, in Senator Panizza's back-of-the-envelope calculations, sale by additional measurement or by weighted tax effect. In the dispute about figures at least I have the recognised Government authority to provide the basis for the calculations I have put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) asked me to rephrase my question. What will the levy be to the growers to pay their $400m debt at 2.8 per cent and what will the levy be to pay the $600m-these are both just interest rates-in terms of the $3.5 billion once the floor price has gone or should the floor price go after June? I am sure that the Government would not have left it to the gods to work out. I am sure that the Government would have worked out this levy because it is crucial to the survival of the industry.

—Senator Walters asked me a question which is based on a series of `what ifs', I should say, first of all. The levy for 1991-92 will be determined later this financial year, depending on the prevailing market price. That will be the basis upon which the levy will be determined. I could go on and try to work out answers to `what if' questions, but I think that really remains the answer.

—That was not my question. My question was: what will the levy be on the interest rate alone? That interest rate does not disappear. I am not asking about the interest rate on additional sales, but on the stockpile alone.
—I do not have a precise figure for that, but it would be considerably less than--
—Roughly.
—I do not have a precise figure and entering arguments based on `roughly' is not a fair way of conducting this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a series of questions of the Minister and I do not believe any of them were answered. I would like to repeat my questions. The first one was: in terms of the 12 per cent calculation for tax, how many bales are anticipated to be sold? What is the anticipated greasy price for those bales and what is the anticipated clean price for those bales?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister partly answered the other question I asked when he said to Senator Knowles that there were no plans at this stage for sales of assets. My other question was: what plans are there for cutting overheads? Further to that I said that it now appears from what the Minister said in a previous answer that the price to the grower would be netted out and, in fact, would be taken up to 525c. I wanted to get that clarified. That being the case, it means that no tax will be charged to the grower either on what he gets for his wool or what he receives in the deficiency payment. I want that point cleared up because if there is any tax, and it is to be netted out at 525c, that will not be equitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am waiting for some advice on these very precise questions of calculation. I do not have, on the top of my head, a direct answer to that question, and I do not apologise for that. Senator Crane has asked me some very precise questions about detailed calculations. Officers in the advisers' booths are able to provide those answers. They are actually doing some calculations to provide Senator Crane with an answer now.

—Just a few moments ago the Minister mentioned that we could have the advantage of additional measurements. Will the Minister agree with me that additional measurements can work against the grower as well as work for him?

—The Minister told me that he does not have a precise figure for what the levy would be on the interest rate alone. Senator Panizza has worked out that it would be about 20 per cent, and 40 per cent if the debt went the full way up to about $400m. The Minister has said it would be considerably less than that in the year 1990-91, and then he said that it will grow after that. Could the Minister give us more detail on the estimate that the Government has made as to what the growth of the levy would be over the next five years?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret the delay, but the reason for it is that I want to be as precise as possible in answering the questions put to me by senators. They deserve that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crane has asked me a question on a 12 per cent tax and the number of bales. The answer to that is 893 million kilograms of greasy. The second question was about the greasy wool price and the third one was about the clean price. For the greasy it would be 560c, and 375c for the clean. That is based on Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics assumptions for 1991-92.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other way around.

—I am corrected. I thank Senator Panizza for the interjection. Those figures are back to front. The price for the greasy would be 375c, and 560c for the clean. I must say, when I read them I thought there was something odd about this wool selling practice. As far as Senator Walters is concerned, I just cannot keep going on making assumptions.
—It was you who said it would be more after 1 July.

—I accept the interjection. That is what I said and I stand by that, but I cannot keep going on making predictions about what will happen in the case of this, and what will happen in the case of that. The answer that I have given is as complete an answer as I can give to that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not press the Minister any further but I hope he realises that growers are trying to plan. They know the floor price has gone. After the first couple of sales they will have a rough idea of what their wool will bring. They will know what it will bring the following year-or have a rough idea of what it will bring the following year. They will have no idea of what levy will be placed on them and the Minister is not giving them any idea for their planning, the debts they have to pay and all the rest that goes with the running of such properties in such a terrible crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Government has to make the assessments. It has to be honest and it has to tell growers what they have to look forward to-what debt has been taken on their behalf and how they are going to be asked to pay it off. All sorts of figures and all sorts of levies have been floating round ever since the floor price went. There have been rumours in the country ever since it was suggested that the floor price be dropped.

Minister Kerin went overseas making this cast-iron promise that the 700c would remain and he has since said it was very risky. He knew it really could not survive unless China and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics came back in. He believes it was his biggest mistake and he should have cancelled the floor price instead of lowering it.

Who believes the floor price will come back? The growers do not. The buyers do not. The Minister has to be able to give the growers some way of planning their future. I appeal to him and to his advisers beside him to give the growers this information, not hang back. He can give them rough old estimates and at least they would have something to go on. It is all very well for him to say that he does not conduct business that way, but he should give them some idea-will it be 12 per cent? Will it be 20 per cent? Can it be more, once the floor price goes?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether the Minister has an answer to my question as to whether additional measurement can work against a grower as well as for him.
—We are really entering into a debate now. Senator Panizza is asking me to agree with his presumption. I do not have a response to that.

—I would just like to pursue the other question that I have not had an answer to; that is in terms of the Minister's comments earlier when he said that growers would be paid out to 525c. What I was trying to establish in that price being netted out to growers was whether the Australian Wool Corporation would be paid 25 per cent tax on top of that or whether no tax would be paid on it. I think it is very important to answer this question because it certainly affects significantly the levels of borrowings that would be required to pay it out. I would just like to know whether the Corporation will be borrowing the full amount, the 25 per cent for tax, then paying it to itself in another account and increasing the debt to growers.
—I think that 525c is after tax; it is the 700c minus 25 per cent, which gives 525c.

—The additional measurement argument was introduced by the Minister in his backup explanation to tell us that the price of wool was going to be higher than what I had estimated. He introduced the subject. Now, can he answer my question? Can additional measurement work against the buyer as well as for him? Can he say yes or no, or tell me if he does not know?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a response.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:

Clause 4, page 2, proposed subsection 142 (1), line 30, omit ``not exceeding in the aggregate $300,000,000'', substitute ``sufficient to pay to wool producers the difference between prices paid to wool producers as a consequence of the suspension of the reserve price scheme and the prices which would have been paid to wool producers if the reserve price had been maintained at 700c per kg.''.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is consistent with the position that has been maintained by the Australian Democrats over a number of years. That position is, and has been, that we support the reserve price scheme, not necessarily as it has become and has been administered recently, but certainly in principle. We believe that part of the role of those who administer the wool sales on behalf of the entire Australian community, not just those who produce, sell and trade in wool, but also those who are affected by our imports and exports, should be to maintain an orderly marketing system. That would be a way of ensuring that there is a fair market. I am reminded of a phrase which is particularly true. It comes from the editorial of the Canberra Times of 14 February, which pointed out that a free market is not a good aim in itself; it must be a fair market as well. That identifies with our position.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the responsibility for making any alterations to that reserve price scheme rests fairly and squarely on the shoulders of this Government, which changed the rules of the game halfway through. In support of our position we have been contacted by several of the interest groups associated with the industry. I will quote some of the information given to us by those in the industry. Recently the Victorian Farmers Federation wrote to me and said:

The Victorian Farmers Federation Pastoral Council today resolved that the Federal Government must meet the full costs of the supplementary payment scheme for wool growers announced by the Government last week.

Taking that into account, we believe that we are doing the right thing in moving this amendment. It is not only on that group that we rely for advice; I was also contacted by the Western Australian Farmers Federation Inc. I am sorry that Senator Crane is not here to hear this. The Federation wrote to me and said in part:

The Federation believes that section 142 part (1) should be amended to remove any reference to a $300m limit on the Government's contribution. This section should clearly state that the Government will meet the full costs of the supplementary payments scheme.

I did not rely entirely on the support given to our position by just that organisation; I also took into account a communication received from the Wool Council of Australia. The Wool Council, with which I have been in constant contact over this matter, wrote to me recently and said in part:

The Council views the removal of the $300m limit on the Government's contribution to the supplementary payments scheme as critical to the future viability of the woolgrowing industry. I am in a position to inform you that if the Senate is forced to reject the Bill in whole or part that such an action would have the unanimous support of all member organisations of the Wool Council of Australia. The Council is fully aware that one of the implications of such an action might be a delay in the resumption of wool sales but believes strongly that the Government's commitment to the 700c a kg reserve price should be honoured and hence all supplementary payments to the end of the season without recourse to increase in the industry's debt.

We believe that our position is supported, as evidenced there, not only by a maverick group, not only a Johnny-come-lately bunch who might have a few theories that it dreamed up on the way down to a meeting, but also by substantial groups and, I repeat, all grower organisations connected with the Wool Council of Australia. As a matter of fact, I have even been contacted by those who might be considered to be breakaway groups. There are a couple of those in Tasmania and one in New South Wales. They are the groups which took a different line from that adopted by the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation in earlier advice. But on this particular issue of the supplementary payments, and with this particular amendment that I have moved, that support was forthcoming from even those groups that have been described as mavericks.

The coalition is hereby given an opportunity to act according to the rhetoric we recently heard about the earlier amendment. Its rhetoric said that an additional burden upon the growers was not what was sought by the Opposition. Here is its chance. The amendment proposes to make the Government accountable for its decisions. The amendment proposes that the full cost be met by those people who changed the rules in the middle of the game. If those who spoke earlier are really concerned about removing the additional burden from the growers, let them demonstrate that concern by sheeting home the full blame to the Government. Let them not hide behind the assertion that because this is a money Bill they are too frightened to suggest to the Government that it take it back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it off health.

—Senator Archer suggests that the amount be cut off health or some other such government commitment. If what I heard before is correct; that is, that only the 40 per cent of the woolgrowers who have yet to sell their wool this year should carry the whole cost of a Government decision, I really cannot believe that the welfare of the woolgrowers is at the heart of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Opposition wishes to shelter in the assertion that it is a money Bill and should not be voted upon in the Senate or rejected or amended in any way, I remind Opposition senators that on 1 June 1989 Senator Bishop amended the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) to excise the whole of the 15 per cent tax on investment income in the hands of complying superannuation funds. On 15 June 1989 Senator Bishop also made amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989 to raise the lump sum tax free threshold from $65,000 to $125,000.

I could give honourable senators other examples but these should be sufficient to show that certainly the alteration of Bills, including money Bills, is not sacrosanct and that they can be touched by the Opposition. This case is by far the best example of something which should be touched. By agreeing with the Democrats' amendment, the Opposition would truly demonstrate its support for our rural industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, with your concurrence and the leave of the Committee I would like to address comments to three amendments that are to appear before the Committee. We have the one currently standing in the name of the Australian Democrats. There is a second amendment that will follow this one if it is not carried. It is in the name of the Australian Democrats. There is a third amendment to the same clause standing in the name of Senator Boswell. In the interests of time and convenience, it would probably be fair to address comments across all three of those amendments. Perhaps other senators could do likewise. Mr Chairman, would that meet with your concurrence?
—That would be quite satisfactory, Senator Tambling.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. The Australian Democrats' amendment that is currently under consideration by the Committee is very open-ended. It proposes to increase the ceiling figure for the Government subsidy funds from some $300m to `sufficient to pay wool producers the difference between prices paid to wool producers as a consequence . . . and the prices which would have been paid to wool producers if the reserve price had been maintained at 700c'.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to take into account the responsibility that this Parliament has in looking at the Government's Budget and the whole ambit of economic management and the economy at the present time. Whilst I acknowledge that the wool industry is of major importance-and I said in the second reading debate that it is very significant-at the same time there are many other industries that must also impact on the Government's Budget. There are many other calls for services and for fair treatment right across the whole ambit of the Australian nation.

There is no guarantee that the Government would agree to more than $300m. In fact, the Government has consistently said that it will not and cannot give more. Therefore, this amendment, the second amendment proposed by Senator Bell, which contains a formula which lifts the Government's commitment by another $150m, and the amendment proposed by Senator Boswell to lift the ceiling to some $500m, will not be passed by the House of Representatives and, therefore, could only delay the start of the wool sales next week.

It would, therefore, not be in the interests of woolgrowers to delay this Bill and, as I said, there are certainly impacts on the Australian economy that must be taken into account. I think many honourable senators addressed this matter yesterday and today during the second reading debate. As I said earlier, we need to place this legislation in the perspective of our Budget responsibilities across all sectors of the Australian community.

We need to argue not just for equity for woolgrowers in a particular scheme-and comparisons have been made in this respect-but for equity between all sectors of all industries that operate in Australia at this time. Certainly, we highlighted yesterday in the second reading debate the very considerable situation that was facing woolgrowers and the extent to which the Government must accept responsibility for that. I think the Government, by providing $300m, has acknowledged that it has a responsibility in that regard. Therefore, I would indicate that the coalition will not be in a position to agree, and certainly would not agree, to either of Senator Bell's amendments to this clause or the amendment that has been proposed by Senator Boswell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the amendment that I propose to move that will lift the ceiling of supplementary payments by $200m from $300m to $500m. I have not picked out an arbitrary figure. It was not a shot in the dark. It is a figure that I have researched and that I can justify.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is giving a $300m supplementary payment. That is commendable. But the Government cost this industry $500m. This cost can be identified. On 31 May last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, dropped the floor price from 870c to 700c. That incident alone cost $600m. The woolgrowers did not make that decision. It was not made by the Australian Wool Corporation, the Wool Council of Australia, the United Graziers Association, Tasmanian farmers or South Australian stock owners and farmers. It was a Government decision. Mr Kerin made that decision.

Why should we inflict that loss on woolgrowers? That is why I say I am justified in moving an amendment to increase the supplementary payment from $300m to $500m. I believe very sincerely that, if this incident had not happened, the Government would not have had any responsibility. It could have walked away from the whole situation and said, `Well, it is on your head. Your industry made the decision. Your industry let the floor price go until it crashed'.

Mr Kerin could have said, `I told you what I thought'. But he did not. He refused every piece of advice that was offered to him by the woolgrowers, the Wool Council, the wool exporters, the weavers, the spinners and the wool industry in general. Everybody involved in the industry told Mr Kerin exactly what would happen. But he did not listen to them. He listened to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Mr Keating and all of his other advisers. But he did not take one bit of notice of the industry.

So it was not the industry's fault that Mr Kerin cost it $600m. It is the Government's fault. The Government is the culprit and it is the one that should pick up that $200m. If that happened, the industry could achieve some equity. That is why I believe that lifting the payment to $500m can be justified and supported.

I know that this is an immense amount of money. But the Government cost the industry an immense amount of money. Why should the farmers have to pay for Mr Kerin's mistakes? The ball is firmly in his court. Equity in the wool stockpile fell by $600m because Mr Kerin would not listen to anyone in the industry. He did not understand the market philosophy and he has now cost this industry between $500m and $600m. He is a Minister of the Crown, he is a Minister of the Government and he and the Government are responsible for his actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) a question which relates to the three amendments, at least one of which ought to be supported by the Committee. I heartily endorse the remarks that Senator Boswell has just made in respect of where the responsibility lies for the total disruption and the potential destruction of the Australian wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As the person who brought the voice of the industry into this chamber when the initial interference with the industry was perpetrated by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on behalf of an economic rationalist free market oriented ideological government, I feel that it is essential that I ask the Minister the following question: has the Government, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics or anyone determined what it will cost if hundreds of farmers to go out of production? These farmers cannot switch to wheat because the Government stuffed that up as well just a little while before it stuffed up the wool industry.

In both cases it did this, of course, in collusion with the Opposition, with the honourable exception of Senator Boswell and one or two of his colleagues. What is going to be the cost of the loss of hundreds of growers from the industry? What will be the cost in terms of the many rural industries-I do not know how many-and all that they contribute to the Australian community?

During the second reading debates in this place and in the other place, I heard talk from the Government side about rural adjustment, rural counselling, and helping people through this period. But this is happening in a climate of contraction of support by the Government for social welfare payments and income support payments which is, again, heartily endorsed by the Opposition.

What will be this social cost which will have to come out in dollars and which will have to come out in heartache, in loss and in despair? Has the Government done a costing of that? If it has, what is it? Therefore, why can it not support at least one of these amendments, all of which sheet the responsibility home to where it should be, to a government which interfered in an industry against the advice of that industry and certainly against the wishes of the Australian Democrats at the time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly to these two amendments. I certainly cannot support Senator Bell's amendment because of the reason he has given, namely, it is open ended. I would like to speak to a point that Senator Powell made when she said that this side of politics stuffed up the wheat industry. Perhaps she can tell us the next time she rises to her feet whether we started the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade war, if she has ever heard of it. That is what stuffed up the wheat industry. I cannot support Senator Boswell's amendment either because he moved the wrong amendment for the right reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the Government is to blame for the stockpile being so high, because the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) ran around the world telling people the price was ironclad. That added $1 billion. He did not have the gumption to bring the 870c down to 700c or get rid of the reserve price earlier. That is where we went wrong, so we built up the debt. I believe the Government is at fault. I have never criticised Mr Kerin in his portfolio before this wool debate. We have built up this stockpile because of his inaction in the first place and then his proaction in running around the world telling everyone it was viable at 700c, resulting in our having a stockpile twice as big as it should be. So it is the Government's responsibility. It uses up the assets of the Corporation and then tries to get out of it that way. I am sorry but I cannot support the amendments of Senator Boswell and Senator Bell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the initiative of Senator Tambling in suggesting to the Committee that we debate these three amendments together. I think it has brought the Committee alive, a bit at least, and brought the coincidence of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell) and the Australian Democrats supporting a similar point of view against the rest of us. It is often the case that the Government enjoys the support of the Democrats on amendments. This is not one of those occasions. We regret it is not, but we are familiar with the view of the Democrats on money Bills and money responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse the remarks of Senator Tambling about what it is a government must take care of in framing a Budget and meeting reasonable Budget outcomes. So, on this occasion, while I recognise the conscientiousness and sincerity of the views held by Senator Boswell and the way in which he speaks of them from the heart, and some of the views of the Democrats, despite the passion, the commitment and the emotion, nonetheless those views are wrong and cannot be supported. To accept Senator Bell's amendment would mean we would have an open cheque or a `hand in the pocket' of taxpayers to supplement beyond the $300m, whatever else was the costing.

I do not think that is a reasonable course of action for any government to embark upon. As has been said, $300m is a huge amount. It is a responsible contribution by the Government and, in the circumstances, we believe as well that growers should take some responsibility so that the price is not just driven too low and the supplementation is taken out of the pocket of the taxpayer.

In those circumstances, we cannot support the Senator Bell amendment or the Senator Boswell amendment, which is different only in degree, not in type. The changes to the legislation which brought about the Wool Marketing Act in 1987 were designed to put the Australian Wool Corporation on a more sound commercial footing and to allow it to operate without the intrusion of the Government. It was therefore responsible, with the Wool Council of Australia, for its own commercial decisions. This change in legislation, I point out, received the full support of the Opposition at the time and it is being consistent now. By asking the Government to fund the full supplementary payments scheme, the Australian taxpayers are being asked to pay for the failed consequences of decisions taken by the wool industry, were that to be the case.

I turn to the question that Senator Powell has asked me about particular calculations. I think that some of the circumstances she postulates about what should give rise to those calculations are hypothetical. But I can say, given the issues and the concerns that she has raised, that the Government will provide additional funds for carry-on assistance, for debt reconstruction, for farm improvement, for household support, and for counselling for individual farmers. The details of that assistance will be settled in the Cabinet's April review of the rural adjustment scheme and the rural counselling program.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot support Senator Bell's open-ended amendment. I think it is just carte blanche. Whilst I believe he is trying to help the wool industry, I sometimes suspect that most people in the wool industry would think it was overgenerous. Therefore, I put it on record that the open-ended commitment the Australian Democrats are making, whilst it may be made for the right reasons, is not practical.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I was distracted, in fact while my back was turned, an agreement was reached to debate these amendments-my first amendment, then Senator Boswell's amendment, and then my amendment which is headed `Option B', which has just been circulated. As far as I can understand it, two arguments have been put for not supporting my first amendment. The first is that it is open ended. That is patently ridiculous. There is a finite amount of wool. When it is sold, there is no further commitment so it is not open ended; it is finite in that sense. It is also finite because it commits the Government to meet up to 700c only. The people who describe it as open ended are the very people who earlier in the debate were figuring out how much it might be. Those estimates ranged from $616m to $800m or so, and we had speculatory figures given from all sorts of sources.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are the figures which would apply to this commitment. Therefore, it is finite. It is not infinite. It is not open ended. There are two limits to it. One is the amount of wool to be sold. The second is the price to be paid for that wool, which would be no more than 700c. So it is patently ludicrous to suggest that it is open ended; it is not. If that frightens either the Government or the Opposition into not supporting it, then my second amendment does have the sort of discipline and limit which is suggested by the Opposition has to be applied to this situation.

In case anybody is incapable of understanding it, I point out that the second amendment is merely to add a dollar for dollar arrangement to apply after the Government's promised $300m. That dollar for dollar arrangement would cease after the Government had been required to find an extra $150m which, up to that point, would be met by the Australian Wool Corporation. So there is a finiteness to that at the point of $600m worth of commitment. After that, the expenses which may occur would be met by the Australian Wool Corporation as a whole. The responsibility in that one, therefore, would be a shared responsibility with a limited Government commitment. So the complaints that are addressed to the first one are met by the second one.

The idea that any of this holds up wool sales is unbelievably naive. The wool sales have been suspended by ministerial decree; they could start again now by similar device. I am incredulous at the suggestion that doing anything to this legislation would hold up wool sales. That is to have not paid attention even when they were suspended in the first place. So I offer that rejoinder to the criticism of my amendments and I again implore the Opposition to demonstrate its commitment to the farmers. It was demonstrated in the rhetoric of its members earlier; let us see some action now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the debate has drawn out some interesting comments, but at the same time I think the merits of the arguments must be addressed as being those of economic responsibility. I argue very seriously that the three proposed amendments, both options A and B of the Australian Democrats and Senator Boswell's amendment, rely on economics that could be described only as pie in the sky and are unachievable. They are really an unrealistic wish list. In that respect, the amendments do not reflect appropriate responsibility in any form of budgeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a very short comment to make in terms of these amendments. The consequence of having an open chequebook philosophy-that is, when we have the sorts of levels of money that we are talking about-is that it opens up a gamut for collusion between the buyers and between growers and the buyers. I believe that there needs to be a significant amount of discipline in terms of the management of all of this. While this is a specific comment, I support and endorse the comments that have been made by Senator Tambling in terms of there being a responsibility to the greater scheme of things. The more we talk about putting larger sums of money around there, the more the people involved will put their heads together and the more they will work out ways of getting around the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the request (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Request (by Senator Bell) negatived:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 4, page 2, after proposed subsection 142 (1), insert the following subsection:

``(1a) The Minister may authorise additional payments by the Commonwealth into the Market Fund, as assistance for the purposes of section 141, of amounts equal to payments which may be made by the Corporation, provided that such payments by the Commonwealth do not exceed $150,000,000.''.
Request (by Senator Boswell) put:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 4, page 2, proposed subsection 142 (1), line 30, omit ``$300,000,000'', substitute ``$500,000,000''.
Question put:
That the request (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 4, page 2, proposed section 142 (1), line 30, omit ``$300,000,000'', substitute ``$350,000,000''.

This request omits $300m and substitutes $350m as the Government's commitment. I implore the Opposition to support this request. It is a minor extra commitment of $350m in place of the $300m, and I ask that the Opposition just seriously consider something extra. The request can and should be supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that the Australian Democrats have very poor economy. In fact, they are now seeking to ask us to play Monopoly for the rest of the evening. I believe all the arguments put with regard to the three amendments or requests we have just considered hold good with regard to this request.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 4, page 3, omit proposed section 146, lines 21 to 24, substitute the following section:
Disposing of wool stocks
`` `146. While guidelines are in force under section 144:

(a) for a period of 12 months beginning on the commencement of this Part, the Corporation must not sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products except in very limited circumstances as prescribed by regulation; and

(b) in any period after that described in paragraph (a), the Corporation shall sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products only in a publicised, orderly and predictable manner, as prescribed in a subsequent enactment.'.''.

We certainly need to create certainty in the wool stockpile and its reduction. The coalition believes that the criteria or guidelines for the sale of wool from the stockpile of 4.8 million bales should be incorporated in legislation, rather than just regulations, in order to create confidence in the wool market. The criteria should be to freeze release from the stockpile for 12 months to allow the market to settle and growers to sell the large amount of wool still being produced. Only minimal release should be allowed for the initial period to meet contracts and in special circumstances and, after that, on a well-publicised and predictable basis.

What we are proposing in this amendment sets up the criteria that ensures that that is the manner in which it would be carried out. Any guidelines that are developed will have to minimise the impact of stockpile releases on the operation of the market and be transparent and flexible enough to recognise the inherently commercial nature of sales from the stockpile. We want guidelines for the management of the stockpile in the legislation package that will be brought forward later in the session. I would certainly issue a challenge to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and to the Government that the subsequent legislation to be produced for the ongoing good of the industry make some commitments in that regard.

It was interesting to note the contribution today by Senator West, the only Labor Party senator prepared to participate in this debate. I commend Senator West for having the courage to come in here and put her personal views. I do not agree with many of them. In fact, her qualifications for participating in a wool debate relied on the fact that she lived on a family farm in 1969 and 1970 and her brother had to go and drive a truck. I am sure there are many other Labor Party senators who would have more identification with the wool industry and with the problems today, but not one of them had the courage to come in here and put down their views.

I would invite anybody to look at the rest of Senator West's speech in Hansard, because I am sure it will be seen for what it is-an historical document of one Labor Party senator who was prepared to come in here and make a contribution without prompting from the advisers' bar. In the early part of Senator West's speech she said that she had listened to the contributions made by members of all parties. I do not know how she even heard from one other member of her Party because at that stage the second reading speech of the Minister had only been formally tabled. She had not even heard it, let alone read it-very obviously, from the comments that she made. We are looking very carefully at an industry that requires careful handling and it is an issue that many of my colleagues, the 13 Liberal and National Party senators who made an excellent contribution to this debate, addressed in the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support what Senator Tambling has said. This is probably the most important amendment that we have had this evening; not that the others have not had a certain amount of merit. It has already been pointed out what is in the stockpile now, but we do not really know what is there because figures are available only to 1 January. Senator Tambling said that, at a present figure of 4.8 million bales, another 5.5 million bales are going to be shorn between now and this time this year. That adds up 10.3 million bales being available in the next 12 months. If one pours them onto the market without order, it is going to cause a great amount of chaos. I would also remind the Committee that we have never sold more than four million bales in one year.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to touch on the point made by Senator West. She said that her brother in 1969 had to get a job as a truck driver because of the downturn in wool at the time. I sympathise with her, but I can assure honourable senators that there will be many more people doing the same thing, and this time the jobs will not be there for them with the unemployment that we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also be very brief. The magnitude of the problem that we have, and the extent to which it is going to be felt throughout the Commonwealth, is terribly important. The skill that is going to be necessary-as well as the cooperation and the judgment between the present growers, the processors, the Government, the Opposition and everybody else-is going to require a lot of goodwill. I would make an appeal to everybody involved in this that we see how we can best make it work. I am sure that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will be taking advantage of whatever means are available to see that this is disposed of in an orderly manner to produce the best result for the people who own the wool and so as not to damage the future prosperity of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this amendment. In doing so I would like to join with previous speakers in congratulating Senator West for coming in here and making her contribution. Earlier, in answer to a question I asked, Senator Cook said that the estimate on which the 12 per cent tax figure for the coming years was based is that 893 million kilos will be sold in the 1991-92 season. That is the equivalent of 5,016,685 bales at 178 kilos per bale, which is the figure that the Australian Wool Corporation uses. To achieve this figure, it is absolutely essential that the stockpile be frozen for at least 12 months and a very strategic plan put in place on the management for future years, whether it be one, two, three, four or five years, or whatever it might be.

SPEECH.PARA: I say this against the background of our winning back the confidence of the world users. It is worth noting in terms of that figure of five million bales that we have achieved close to that figure only once. I believe that was in the 1987-88 season, but I stand to be corrected on that. If we look through the figures we see that in 1988-89 we produced 898 million kilos of wool, which is the equivalent of 5,044,943 bales. The stockpile that year was 188,300 bales. We sold 4,823,843 bales, which I believe is the second highest on record and significantly less than the 5,000,016 bales that is anticipated by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) in the figures that Senator Cook quoted to me.

In the 1988-89 season we produced 1,040 million kilograms, which is the equivalent of 5,842,696 bales. The stockpile grew to 3,064,600 bales and that year we sold-that is, the season just gone past-2,966,396 bales, which is, significantly, some two million bales fewer than what is anticipated for the coming season. We do know now that the stockpile stands at 4.8 million bales or thereabouts.

In addressing this particular amendment and emphasising the importance of proper management in the next 12 months, I hope the figures that Senator Cook has quoted to us from ABARE are correct, but I have grave doubts whether they will be. It will require a recovery of almost unparalleled belief in terms of any industry. Whether we reach that figure or not, it is very important in this total context that the signals on the management of the stockpile be made very clear. In terms of the ABARE predictions, I put on the record that ABARE was one of the advisers to Minister Kerin when the reserve price was lowered from 870c to 700c. The rationale that was given then was that we were moving back to the world trend line. I have grave doubts-and I do not want to pour cold water on this-that that figure is achievable in the next selling year. I just hope and pray that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us be clear what section we are trying to amend and what that section says. Proposed sub-section 146 purely says:

SPEECH.PARA: While guidelines are in force under section 144, the Corporation must sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products in accordance with those guidelines and not otherwise.

It tells us nothing. We do not have the guidelines, we do not have a clue. It tells us absolutely nothing. If the Government had the guidelines here, and those guidelines gave us some information, then that would be one thing. This gives us not a clue, nothing. I have a copy of a news release that the Australian Wool Corporation put out on 19 February. Its suggestion is that all sales of Australian wool stock held in Australia-and I emphasise `held in Australia'-will cease with the resumption of sales on 25 February. All sales of the Wool Corporation's stock held overseas will cease on 25 March in order to allow overseas processors with urgent commitments to have access to wool. Sales from overseas stock during the period up to 25 March will be allowed for inventory adjustment purposes, but will be at prices no less than the equivalent of the 700c floor price.

Neither the wool stock referred to held in Australia nor the wool stock held overseas has a restarting date for sales. In both instances the Corporation says they will cease, one on 25 February and the other on 25 March, but there is no restarting date. It is fun, is it not? We do not have a clue what the Wool Corporation is suggesting-just that they will cease on those dates. Are they never to be re-opened? Will they be opened again 12 months later, five months later or a week later? The Government tells us that it will all be done according to its guidelines. Is it any wonder that the Senate cannot possibly go along with that rubbish? We have to know what the Government is suggesting. We have to have some indication, and we certainly cannot get it from either the Government or the Corporation.
Naturally, our amendment is for freezing for a period of 12 months at the commencement of this part of the Act. It states:
. . . the Corporation must not sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products except in very limited circumstances as prescribed by regulation . . .
It makes it pretty clear that even though regulations are to come up with the detail, for 12 months the stock will not be sold. The amendment continues:

. . . in any period after that described in paragraph (a), the Corporation shall only sell, charge or otherwise dispose of its stocks of wool or wool products in a publicised, orderly and predictable manner, as prescribed in a subsequent enactment.

So at least with our amendment the wool growers-who surely are the people we are meant to be helping-will know what to expect. The next wool sale starts on Monday in Sydney. The growers do not have a clue how long the stockpile will be frozen or whether it is going to be frozen at all by the Government's legislation that we are putting through at the moment.

The Government is very keen on passing legislation without any guidelines. It refers to the guidelines that will eventually come but does not give the Senate any indication of what they are. I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) whether he can now give us some indication of what period of time those stockpiles are meant to be held for without any sales taking place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under normal circumstances, I would support an amendment such as this, the main reason being that to do otherwise is to buy a pig-in-the-poke, unless one knows for certain what regulations are going to govern at the disposal of the stockpile. I think that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) said earlier this evening that there will be discussions and consultations with the Opposition spokesman and the Australian Democrats spokesman on primary industry and that Mr Kerin had given this undertaking. I understand that, but I am not sure whether that is satisfactory for the Senate as a whole.
—You are on section 148, aren't you? We are on the stockpile.

—Perhaps the Minister was talking about something else. I heard it in my office and it may not have been about this matter that he was giving these guarantees. I say for the benefit of Senator Tambling that I too-probably along with a number of people in the Senate who are more familiar with other areas of industry than the wool industry-am perfectly well aware that the industry is facing a great crisis and there are large numbers of people going to be affected dramatically. A lot of families on farms are going to be hit, not least people with whom I have close contact. Although my knowledge of the industry is not great, I have attempted to listen to what is being said and have tried to decide what needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Somebody in the second reading debate raised a question about the stockpile and indicated that one of the factors that should be taken into consideration is whether the stockpile should be used to promote wool as a low cost, popular fibre. I do not know who raised that during the debate, but I think it is something we need to take into account. The same speaker was indicating that the Australian Wool Corporation had been concentrating on the elite nature of wool and suggested that we ought to get into the low cost area. Figures such as 10 per cent down to 4 per cent were the figures that were mentioned by one of the speakers.

As a percentage of all the clothing fibres that are used world wide, wool is now only 4 per cent as against 10 per cent maybe five or six years ago. That should be a great worry to us and it should be relevant to our consideration, I believe, of how to dispose of the stockpile. The stockpile is 4.8 million bales which is quite a lot of wool. It is more wool than has been sold per annum over the past few years. Also to be considered is what it costs the industry to keep maintaining that stockpile.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $450m a year.

—I acknowledge what Senator Boswell says. I am in a bit of a quandary about this aspect of Senator Tambling's amendment. Although I am attracted to voting for it because it at least gives us in the Senate, and more particularly the industry, a clear understanding of what is likely to occur in the next 12 months, I am not too sure that it is really the way to go if the two factors I have mentioned need to be given a fair degree of priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. One of the justifications for bringing forward this amendment was given as being an opportunity to bring confidence into the wool market. This proposition will further distort what will be a very distorted version of what is described as a free market, which is in no way a free market because of the distortions that are brought to bear upon it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine mentioned one of those distortions, and that is that there will be additional costs brought to the growers by the very Party which earlier tonight hoped to remove costs from growers. The cost of storage of that stockpile while frozen, as we were informed by Senator Boswell, is of the order of $450m a year, with no chance of earning any returns while it is frozen.

The other distortions are brought about by the very fact that maintaining the stockpile is as much a threat to potential market prices as if it were not frozen for one year. Just the fact that it is there and that buyers are able to anticipate that after one year it will begin to dribble onto the market brings a distortion which is more than psychological; in fact, it is a true distortion.

The other distortions that will exist in this potential so-called free market are brought about at the moment by the knowledge on the part of buyers that 700c will be returned to growers regardless of what the market does. That distorts the buyers' input and makes it not a free market.

By freezing the stockpile we reduce the capacity of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) to meet its task of marketing wool with flexibility and imagination. This relates to the imagination that is required to follow some of the suggestions that were made by Senator Harradine. But the option to follow those suggestions will be removed by freezing the stockpile.

The opportunity to take advantage of any unpredicted circumstance which arises during the next year is removed by this freezing. Nobody can predict what will occur. People this evening have tried to predict and suggest what-ifs, and quite rightly the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) was not prepared to answer questions on that basis. Certainly this is a great what-if, except that we are removing the option to meet some of the unpredictabilities. We are in this mess because of our inability to predict. If two years ago we had been able to predict what prices or the market would do, there would have been less chance of our now being in this mess. Our inability to predict caused this predicament. If we freeze the stockpile, we will reduce the capacity to meet unpredictable circumstances.

The absolute killer so far as I am concerned on this idea is that it comes from a group which earlier suggested that the AWC should sell some of its assets. They are now telling us to freeze the biggest asset possessed by the Corporation, and such a suggestion is ridiculous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard some interesting comments. We see the usual jelly backed Monopoly players in the Australian Democrats on this issue. They would have been quite prepared to have traded this amendment under many circumstances, but were not prepared to consider the matter on its merits. It was very important to look carefully at the stockpile for its inherent measures. As usual, the Democrats and their commitment to the bush go with where they see the best press release.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine raised the issue with regard to access to and use of the stockpile. While there would be a freezing of the stockpile, we felt that in order to meet contracts or special circumstances that would arise from the market there would need to be exceptions on that basis, and that could have been covered. What was more important was that we saw the long term objective was to achieve economic stability and certainty in the marketplace when it was known what the long term market prospects would be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the freezing of the stockpile. I believe that it is the right way to go. We will find 2.5 million bales of wool coming onto the market in the next three or four months. We already have in the stockpile 4.8 million bales or maybe five million bales at a cost of $4 billion. That is the rough equation. The other part of the equation is that there will not be enough supplementary payments and borrowings to cover the full 700c, as I think everyone acknowledges. If we unfreeze the stockpile or let it go, that will force down the market. It will force the wool price down to maybe 200c or less. That will then increase the tax on the reduced price of the wool. So if the wool falls now to 300c, the tax will be 41 per cent; if it goes lower, the tax must go higher.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in reply to Senator Harradine that in January we almost get out of gaol with the floor price. Sales picked up and went up to probably 60 per cent purchases by the trade, maybe a little higher, and then some wool was released from the stockpile. That fine balancing act got out of kilter and the market then went down again. I suppose it is a balancing act in itself whether one is prepared to cop the $450m in storage and interest rates, or whether one freezes the position. But we are really talking about a $4 billion asset, and one has to look at that in the perspective of $4 billion to $450m. On balance I would come down to a freezing of the stockpile because I think that it is the only way that the market will rise. The higher the market rises, the less tax the growers have to pay. On balance, I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to what the two previous speakers have said about the importance of freezing the stockpile and explain some of the rationale behind it. It is really all about supply and demand. Freezing the stockpile will give the industry time to adjust its production down much closer to demand. Once again I will quote one of the figures which we got from the Minister tonight-which I am grateful for-of the anticipated sale of just over five million bales in the next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Anticipated production will be in excess of that figure. We have already seen some 10 million sheep taken out through the flock reduction scheme, and there needs to be a period of time to allow further reductions in flock numbers to get production down so that the stockpile can then be put onto the market without distorting it too much. In terms of some of the points that Senator Harradine raised, I hope I have explained the rationale behind freezing the stockpile to allow production to come down.

The other point concerns the amount of wool we have to put out into the market now. I believe there will be sufficient wool in those five million bales to allow us to penetrate into those types of markets that some of us mentioned during the second reading debate. I think the rationale to allow the industry to settle down, to allow the buyers to settle down and to allow production to get back in line with demand is the fundamental reason behind freezing this stockpile and then having a proper management plan to release it into the market over the next three, four or five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Archer said earlier in this debate that there needs to be a lot of goodwill in the future for managing the situation. I agree with that. I must say, as well, that Senator Bell, in his contribution, treated the Committee to an objective analysis of the likely considerations were the stockpile to be frozen and came to an on-balance consideration of the outcomes. Certainly I adopt the analysis that he made on that point as an analysis that, I think, is right and reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Opposition wants to do in amending this Bill is to provide that for a period of 12 months the stockpile will be frozen except for such exceptions as allowed by regulation. After that period the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) will be able to sell only in a manner prescribed in subsequent legislation. The Government is already operating like this. On Tuesday the AWC announced, with the concurrence of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the stockpile management rules that will apply for the rest of the year. Perhaps I should just say what they are.

All sales from the stockpile in Australia will cease as from 25 February. Sales from the stockpile in Europe can continue until 25 March in small amounts for inventory adjustment purposes, but at no less than the 700c floor price. The only exceptions are for contracts entered into by the AWC before 25 February and for wool to meet the technical requirements of the International Wool Secretariat market development projects. These guidelines will be gazetted tomorrow along with the supplementary payments schedule guidelines.

The Minister has already said that the longer term stock management guidelines will be announced as part of a larger package of measures to manage the AWC's debt position, as part of the Government's response to the report of the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing. I can understand the Opposition's desire to nail down the stockpile management situation. However, what it is trying to do, with all due respect, is simplistic. The stockpile cannot be managed in isolation from the AWC's debt structure; neither can it be managed in isolation from promotion and marketing policies.

Managing the stockpile will be a difficult balancing act in itself. Many people accept that. Some want simple one-off solutions. The complex task of drawing up the long term guidelines will be done after proper investigation of the stockholdings and not on a knee jerk basis. Selling wool from the stockpile is an inherently commercial activity.

The longer term guidelines need some flexibility so that, within reason, the AWC can respond to the market quickly. If this amendment were to be passed, the ability to respond to market factors quickly would be removed-and in a commercial manner so that it cannot be speculated against.

I now turn to Senator Walter's question: how long will the stockpiles be held? It is a question she explicitly asked. It is a matter for further consideration in terms of debt exposure, Treasury and Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics input and, importantly, further consideration based on the findings of the Vines report.
