On that basis, with the goodwill that was spoken of earlier, this matter can be managed, but to oppose mechanistic solutions for short term purposes seems to me to fly in the face of rationality in much the same way as exposed by Senator Bell's contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has just told us that it is ridiculous for us to put forward an amendment to freeze the stockpile. He has read-as I had previously read into the Hansard-the Corporation's news release. He did not answer my question, which was: can the Minister tell us when that stockpile will be released? It says that it ceases on 25 February, and overseas stockpiles cease on 25 March. Can he give us any indication, so that the woolgrowers have something to plan on, as to when the stockpile will reopen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always thought Australia was the world power so far as wool was concerned.
—Not any more.

—I thought not. I thought that we had enormous muscle with regard to that. What worries me is the statistic that has been given that, in so far as clothing fibre is concerned, wool worldwide is now down to 4 per cent. That is the key. It might have been Senator Crane, Senator Archer or even Sen- ator Bell who mentioned it-I cannot recall who did-but it certainly struck me as something we have to work at. The question on this amendment is whether what Senator Tambling has said will do that best; that is to say, make it more attractive-there will be problems in any case in the wool industry-for people to opt for wool in the local domestic market and in the international market, or whether the Government's proposal is best.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me, just listening to what the Minister said about the guidelines which will be gazetted tomorrow, that they probably will not be far away from what Senator Tambling has been suggesting in his amendment in any event. There is an implied decision-not only an implied decision-that most of the stockpile will be frozen in any event by the regulations that will be gazetted tomorrow. Perhaps the Minister can confirm that or otherwise. I understand what Senator Bell has said about flexibility, but I still have regard to what has been said in support of Senator Tambling's amendment. We need to have some clear understanding as to what is likely to be the requirement so far as the stockpile is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —To put Senator Harradine's mind at rest concerning the figures of 4 per cent and 5 per cent, in the past few years the biggest problem not only for Australia's woolgrowers but for woolgrowers around the world is that wool as a fibre has lost one per cent of the world market. Whereas wool used to have a 5 per cent share of the world market, it has now dropped back to 4 per cent. That has made all the difference. Earlier Senator Harradine said that we had the biggest clout in the world in the wool market. We used to have the biggest clout. I said that in my second reading contribution yesterday. But we have gone away from that, for a couple of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, Australia gave up the ban on exporting genetic merino material; however, that is another argument. So the results of that are coming through. We also have the influences of Uruguay, China and other places. Honourable senators might not know that one other country grows more wool than Australia-it is either China or Russia-but it uses its wool internally, so it does not come onto world markets.

Senator Harradine is right. That is our problem. The mistake that the Australian Wool Corporation has made in three or four years has been that it did not concentrate on marketing wool as a fibre; it was marketed as high fashion material for women's clothing, or something similar, with very low micron wool being used. That is the whole point. If we are interested in the industry as a whole, we have to chase that one per cent market share. Then we will sell all the wool we want to. I believe that that is where we should concentrate our efforts.
Friday, 22 February

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — As to the question from Senator Walters, I have to stick to the same answer that I gave before. The Vines report comes down on 31 March. The Australian Wool Corporation accounts need to be looked at and reported back on. We expect the guidelines to be available in the time zone between the end of April and the beginning of May. I cannot, as Senator Walters invites me so deliciously to do, speculate as to what they will contain, because what they will contain needs to arise from a study of the situation and, in particular, from information obtained by the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, pages 3 and 4, proposed section 147, line 26 (page 3) to line 22 (page 4), omit the section.

The reason for my requested amendments is that they propose to omit from the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill proposed section 147. This section provides for what are called special powers of the Minister. If passed, this section will reduce the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) and its directors to puppets and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will be able to sack, at will, the directors of the Wool Corporation.

It has long been a standing issue in my Party that the growers must always have control of the marketing of their products. This Party was established on that basis. I do not care to change that direction at the moment. It can be argued that the section is unnecessary because there are already extensive powers of control of the Corporation provided to the Minister under the Wool Marketing Act 1987. Under the Act, the Minister already has extensive powers of control over the Corporation and its membership. These are set out at length in divisions 3 and 4 of the Act. I will not go into them at length. But I will mention some: directors of the Corporation are appointed by the Minister; they hold office under terms and conditions of his choosing; they are appointed for between two and three years; the Minister can terminate the appointment of one or more of the appointed directors; and the Minister has extensive power and control over the selection of membership of the Corporation. To increase these controls and provide special powers for the Minister, as is proposed by this Bill, would be to undermine the whole concept of the independent professional Australian Wool Corporation.

I do not want the Minister to be able to appoint someone who has no philosophy, no understanding and no sympathy for the wool industry. I have moved this amendment because the Bill takes away control from the Wool Corporation and puts it in the hands of a Minister. That is not correct and I do not believe the woolgrowers believe it is correct. They pay for the Corporation. They pay for it through their taxes and their levies.

TALK.START.PARA: —They pay for it through their nose.
—Go and talk to Mr Kerin about that; he was the one who caused it.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, if you want to be disorderly, be disorderly from your proper seat.

—It is very easy to kick someone when he is down. But no-one attacked the AWC in 1988 and 1989 when it was bringing $6 billion worth of income into this nation. Everybody wanted to jump on the bandwagon then. I am reminded that it is late. I am standing on a point of principle. I commend the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the earlier amendment that Senator Boswell moved, this is rather like an ambit claim. The earlier amendment was an ambit claim for the use of $500m of taxpayers' funds, obviously on behalf of Senator Boswell's pressure groups and interested parties. The amendment as circulated is in an incorrect protocol form. It is circulated in the name of Senator Boswell, Leader of the National Party in the Senate. This is unfortunate. I regret that it has happened in that manner. Senator Boswell has obviously given a personal direction to the Clerk in that regard. This is inconsistent with coalition policy. It is a personal stance and certainly not endorsed by the Party. There was no discussion in the National Party rooms of the Senate or of the Parliament about the issues canvassed in Senator Boswell's amendment. The details raised in the amendment were not even mentioned by Senator Boswell in his speech during the second reading debate on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We have carefully looked at the clause that Senator Boswell seeks to delete. We have looked at the powers that are necessary. We draw the comparison with the Wheat Marketing Act and other statutory authorities where the Minister does have and must have the power to exercise these sorts of controls. It is important to note that some of the members of the Australian Wool Corporation have been called upon to resign by speakers and many people. It is obvious that others are thinking about resigning. The fact that important interim measures are necessary, particularly in the time between now and 30 June, is important and should be properly addressed. The coalition does not support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to go into this in great depth but I do want to say that there was a meeting. I said I would move these amendments. I stand by that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not see anything ambit about this claim at all. In fact, the first mention of this was made by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. To pretend that that subject was not raised is really quite nasty. That is the only word to describe what has been done here. Ignoring the semantics of whose name is on what piece of paper and the petty jealousies that might arise, I will repeat what has been done to me earlier tonight in betraying a confidence. I think that Senator Tambling was posturing. The matter was discussed with me by Senator Tambling.

SPEECH.PARA: Discussions took place about which amendments would get up and which would be put up and by whom. If the coalition was unsure about who was going to do what, perhaps that is explained by the sorts of media releases put out in the name of Mr Bruce Lloyd, Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, shadow Minister for primary industry, dated 11 February 1990, in which Mr Lloyd said in part that the coalition would now study the Government's proposal and await the legislation to see how things were handled before formulating a response. It is the very delay of that response which has occasioned this conglomeration of opinions tonight.

We support the amendment because it was raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I raised it during my speech in the second reading debate. If other honourable senators were concerned about the questions raised by that Committee, they would have addressed the matter and decided their opinion much earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support Senator Boswell's amendment. The situation is that the Minister cannot dismiss the board but, as has been rightly said by Senator Tambling, board members have been called upon in speeches around the country to resign. One has to be prudent in framing legislation on a sensitive issue such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: If the board were to resign the procedures to reappoint the board by the normal route of consultation and involvement would take up to six weeks or more to occur. That is because they have to be exhaustive and extensive. One could picture a weird situation: if the board yielded to the calls of those who call upon it to resign, there would be a six-week vacuum in the Australian Wool Corporation. That is not in anyone's interest. Therefore, the Government does not support this amendment. It believes that in circumstances such as that the Minister should be able to have the power, and this Parliament should clothe him with the power, to be able to appoint a board to mind the store while the proper consultative procedures for an ongoing permanent board are exhausted and the appointments made. We do not support the amendment for those reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against this amendment. In doing so I point out a couple of things about people in the Senate and elsewhere who are involved in the woolgrowing industry, and I happen to be one of them. I have not heard one woolgrower senator stand up in this debate and speak for this amendment. That is very crucial.

SPEECH.PARA: I also refer to a point that a number of us mentioned during our speeches. I refer particularly to the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, who highlighted what was removed from the Act in 1987. In effect, that was the ministerial powers in terms of reporting, financial controls and a number of other aspects. It is now generally concluded by most experts that that is where the reserve price scheme went wrong. That discipline in financial control and management was taken away. The accountability was taken away.

I would suggest respectfully that Senator Boswell should think very carefully about the words that were used in the speech of the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair because I think they provide all the answers as to why this chamber should not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, I wish to address Senator Crane's concern about a letter from the Western Australian Farmers Federation (Inc.), signed by the Deputy Director, Mr P. W. Chidgzey, which reads, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Special Powers of the Minister
The Federation strongly objects to Section 147 which aims to give special powers to the Minister until 1 July 1992.
That is a woolgrower; that is his opinion; and that is why we are voting for Senator Boswell's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: — I apologise to the Committee but I must respond to that. I said that I had not heard one woolgrower senator stand up in this debate and speak for this amendment. I said that I had not had one farmer speak to me in terms of this amendment. I would respectfully point out that Mr Chidgzey, whom I know well, is not a farmer. He is not a woolgrower. He is an executive officer. I am not going to get involved in semantics. But I would suggest that Senator Bell get his facts right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I did not intend to speak again in this debate this evening. But in view of what has taken place in the chamber since the amendment was moved, I felt that I had to rise once again. I am sure that this amendment is the result of a letter from the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) that I presume was sent to all members of this chamber and the other chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I said in my speech during the second reading stage that the AWC wants to build into this legislation security of tenure for its position. In other words, it wants to eliminate any clause by which it could be removed. We reckon that we should change that sort of arrangement in respect of the waterfront. I am not going to stand here and defend a system under which a body can keep its position forever and a day and not be removed by way of legislation.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Boswell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment briefly on proposed section 148(2) (b). In his introductory remarks this evening during the committee stage, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) acknowledged that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, had reached an acceptable understanding with the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats and it was not necessary to proceed with the amendment that I had circulated earlier with regard to proposed section 148(2) (b).

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to note the comments of the Minister for Industrial Relations that the application of any regulations that will be put in place under this proposed section will apply only to the operation of supplementary payments, and also that any such changes would not be included in subsequent legislative packages to be brought in later this year. Senator Cook also acknowledged that this should not be seen to create in any way a precedent. I share the concern of many honourable senators on this side of the chamber-in particular, that of Senator Vanstone and Senator Macdonald-who alerted the Senate to issues that were raised under the Scrutiny of Bills report and the need for being very cautious with regard to the monitoring of excessive powers. But because of the fact that both Senator Cook and Mr Kerin have given firm and strong commitments in this regard, I will not proceed with the amendment circulated earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tambling has already said, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has given us some sort of guarantee that, if we do not put our amendment to the clause giving the Minister the authority to override the whole Act, he will introduce regulations and therefore we should be satisfied. The thing that concerns me is that this should be seen as a precedent. It really is of great concern that, written into a piece of legislation, it could be that a Minister has the power to amend any provision of the Act under this part. Whether he is to put it in guidelines or otherwise, it seems to me quite incredible that the Government should even contemplate that.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Cook, in the statement that he made to the Senate, has put in a particular provision saying that this should not be seen to create a precedent. I am pleased to see that in, and I ask the Minister the only remaining question that is of concern to me. What the Minister has promised is that Mr Kerin should adequately consult with the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the shadow Minister, on the use of that particular subsection. Could he tell me what `adequately' means? Is it a fact of saying to the shadow Minister, `This is what I am going to do.'? Or is it an agreement between him and the shadow Minister? It does not say `only after agreement'. It just says `adequately consult'. There is a very big difference between `adequately consult' and `only after agreement' with the shadow Minister. Could the Minister explain what `adequately consult' is? Seeing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, is in the chamber, I am sure it would not be a very difficult thing for him to ask. Come on, Mr Kerin. Do give him the indication--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters. Direct your remarks through the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to answer the question that has been put to me obviously, but first to acknowledge for the record the comments of Senator Tambling and to confirm again the undertaking given at the end of my second reading speech. That does include the words that he sought to add, and which we have accepted; but that it is not to set a precedent. I confirm that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters has raised the question of what the meaning of the word `adequately' is. I think the best way of answering that is to go to the letter that was sent by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the shadow Minister, on the subject of this assurance that I have read into the second reading debate. The relevant passage in the letter to Mr Bruce Lloyd from Mr Kerin is as follows:
My undertaking to consult on the use of the section was genuine. Consequently, should it be necessary to use the provision, I will give you adequate time to make a considered response.

It is on the understanding of that comment that the words were settled between the shadow Minister and the Minister as being sufficient to cover the circumstances. I think it does say one thing about the trust that operates between those two members of the House of Representatives, and I think meets the point of the Opposition, and should meet the point raised by Senator Walters. It should adequately dispose of this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill reported without amendment or requests.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the report from the Committee be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -Before we allow the passage of this Bill, I once more briefly implore the Opposition not to be bluffed by this Government's threat that wool sales will be disrupted; not to be bluffed by the fact that any rejection of this will require a further sitting of Parliament-after all, it is not even one o'clock on Friday morning and there are some 23 hours to go today. If we were serious about this, serious in our opposition to it, and if we were serious about the position that has been taken by the coalition, we would find the coalition supporting us in voting against the passage of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: If the coalition is serious about the statement made by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the shadow Minister, on behalf of the coalition, that this wool package is irresponsible and inadequate, if the coalition seriously agrees with the statement by its spokesperson on this that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has failed to provide any leadership on wool at a time when the industry desperately needs it and if the coalition supports that statement by its spokesperson, it will join us in not supporting the passage of this Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the hour, I shall not detain the Senate too long, but there are a number of matters that I wish to raise. I rise in this adjournment debate to put forward another aspect of the South Australian State Bank debacle. It gives me no joy to do so. I have always had an affinity with the State Bank of South Australia and a desire to see it grow tall in the banking arena around Australia. Now I feel let down, as do many other South Australians, for I, like them, have wanted to have a trust in that financial institution in South Australia. In fact, it was in 1962 as a teenager that I started my working career in its predecessor. In 1982, as a politician and as Leader of the Opposition-I supported the merger of the State Bank and the Savings Bank of South Australia which was to give us the bank as we know it today.

SPEECH.PARA: In late 1988 and early 1989, as Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, I found myself in a situation where it became clear that the Premier, John Bannon, needed to be questioned in Parliament about the more aggressive business dealings of the State Bank-business dealings which were showing every indication of being as unsuccessful as they had been unwise. As Opposition Leader I was faced with a bank advertising that it had its heart in South Australia, yet with evidence growing daily on my desk that at the same time it was losing an arm and a leg both interstate and overseas.

A number of people have approached me in the past two weeks since the bank's financial crisis has finally become public and suggested a feeling of `I told you so'. I do not, in fact. Rather, I feel an enormous sense of frustration that factors in South Australia-predominantly the combined arrogance and well-documented inaction of the Premier-allowed the very visible smoke signals of disaster in the State Bank two years ago to go quite unheeded. He was, I admit, aided in his inaction by a strong view in South Australia that the bank was a sacred cow; it was untouchable.

While both the bank and the Premier were supposed to be accountable to the people of South Australia, it seemed that neither was willing to be so. As we began to inquire into the bank, the Premier's minders worked hard on many Adelaide journalists. So, as we probed and prodded for answers into the bank's dealings with companies such as the failed Equiticorp, generally we found it was ourselves, the Opposition, not the Government, which was criticised and under fire from the media. The bank's corporate public relations machine also moved quickly into top gear and soon not only were the media questioning our role and our reasons for asking such questions, but so too was the business community.

Some two years later, in February 1991, I find it absolutely unacceptable to listen to a Premier saying that he did not know and he had not had any warnings. Of course he had had warnings-two whole years of them. There is none so blind as he who does not want to see; and he did not. But he really has nowhere to hide on this issue. Even if the royal commission finds that he did not know of the details or the extent of the bank's problems until the end of January this year, we told him two years ago that we had reason to believe that there were concerns which he and the bank should address.

As the owner of the bank it was his clear duty to follow through on these concerns on behalf of the taxpayers of South Australia. Even if he thought, as his minders told anyone who would listen, that it was all the Opposition's imagination and a scare campaign in an attempt to win government, he still had a duty to investigate questions put to him in Parliament. We received no answers, only ridicule and put-downs. Perhaps he was given the wrong information by the bank, but with names such as the controversial and failed Equiticorp and valid questions about other loans, just how much does it take to get John Bannon to see that smoke means fire?

Anyone who has read the South Australian Hansards for 1989 has seen the warnings-question after question on investment decisions. They were not just about Equiticorp but about the National Security Council, a massive exposure to the REMM Group, and some most unusual dealings with a group called Health and Lifecare. To those of us concerned by the bank's exposures and its massive growth of 25 per cent a year, it was incomprehensible that our concerns were not being translated into any action by either the bank or the Premier.

My Party's questioning, labelled opportunistic by the bank at every opportunity, led to an invitation to address senior management of the bank at its annual strategic planning conference in March 1989. I took the opportunity to tell those managers that I held the view that the State Bank should act like a private sector bank. I will quote some of the comments made at the March 1989 strategic planning seminar, attended by all senior managers-30 or 40 in all-and chaired by Tim Marcus Clarke at the State Bank. I said:

The bank should exercise due caution with lending risks and not expose itself to unreasonable risks. Care also needs to be taken to ensure the bank is not seen to be an arm of Government which can be twisted. Or that it is prone to decisions which fit a particular government's political philosophy. Or that it is willing to fund pet Government projects which private banks would not lend to. Or fund other projects which other banks will not because of the high risk nature of the development and where to invest is foolhardy. This is the road to a VEDC or a WA Inc. The State Bank must not only be, but be seen to be, above that sort of behaviour.
I also criticised its foray into Equiticorp, saying:

With Equiticorp the bank has gone not only offshore but into an entrepreneurial high risk area of lending to an organisation which it has been suggested did not have audited accounts. It assaults traditional notions of local support and commitment to the South Australian community. It does not seem to fit comfortably within the bank's charter as it is generally understood.
I don't believe the Bank has, or ever will have, a capital base sufficient to allow it to act on an international basis like our other major trading banks.
If the Bank believes it must go outside South Australia then it needs to more clearly explain itself to the South Australia public, the owners of the Bank.
I also talked in that address about the confidentiality provisions the Premier kept hiding behind, saying:

With Equiticorp it is my view that once that body went into receivership the onus of the State Bank's duty transferred to the people of South Australia who guarantee the Bank's operations-that this duty overrides the duty to a client in receivership.

Just as private banks are accountable to their shareholders the State Bank through the Government and the Parliament must be accountable to its owners-the people of South Australia. As it is, all they know is that the most the group will lose is $60 million for this is the amount of the current provisions for losses and you have reported that the provisions will be sufficient.

I also spoke of the bank's reporting of bad debts, which even in 1988 had raised questions about the extent to which doubtful debts were recoverable. The previous year the bank had written bad debts of more than $6.8m and reported recoveries of only $97,000, when usual private banking practice was to recover up to 50 per cent of bad debts. I asked whether the bank's reporting of bad debts also included any interest on loans which were not repaid; that is, when a loan defaulted as a result of not being able to keep up with interest payments we saw the situation where the interest payments were capitalised and, because of that, the loan was not then in default. That is a way of disguising the true extent of bad and doubtful debts and the appropriate provisions that ought to be made. These concerns were raised back in 1989 with the strategic planning group of the State Bank. All those concerns were visible to my Party and to my research staff at that time.

The Premier, with many financial and economic experts surrounding him in his own department and Treasury, continued to ignore the signals. My speech at that time was reported by the media in an article on page 1 of the Adelaide Advertiser. As is the way of Adelaide, I know full well that the Premier would also have received a full text of that speech from some journalist. John Bannon, Labor Premier of South Australia, is either guilty of a huge cover-up over the State Bank or, as is perhaps likely, he has shown himself to be inept in financial matters and irresponsible in carrying out his duties as the owner of the State Bank of South Australia. In the past two weeks he has hidden behind the State Bank Act, saying it stopped him interfering. It did-in the everyday running of the bank-but nowhere in that Act is there any section which stops him inquiring of bank management, seeking information from bank management or the board or even demanding answers on behalf of the taxpayers he represents.

Looking back, the speech I gave in March 1989 seems quite prophetic, but it also shows just how obvious were the cracks in the facade of the South Australian State Bank two years ago. However, few would listen and even fewer people would believe. Through it all the Premier and the Managing Director of the State Bank, Tim Marcus Clarke, were scathing. Mr Clarke surpassed himself after my speech to the management group when he wrote to me as follows:

I suspect you are regularly induced to have a go at State Bank by the other trading banks in town who we have certainly affected via our competitive edge and by political pressures on you to take an opportunistic approach in seizing upon anything which might prove useful in attacking the Government.
He went on to say:

I do ask that any attack on the current Labor Government in your vigorous pursuit of the Treasury benches you do insist on a more responsible approach to those matters likely to affect the extremely high regard that South Australians have for their Bank, and the complete confidence they have in its security-a reputation the Bank richly deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you sent him a copy back?
—I wrote back to him shortly after that letter. In addition to that, a senior bank official wrote to me, in far less mannerly terms, I might add.
—Not a banker, was he?

—Another State banker. The bank was out of control, a law unto itself, and the man who let it be that, and remain like that until it was too late, is none other than Premier John Bannon, the man who quite blatantly refused to see any evil or hear any evil as it relates to the State Bank. In the private sector he would have been replaced by now. The man in control of the State's finances cannot be seen to be indifferent or incompetent. For the past two years in dealing with the State Bank, John Bannon has been both.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Treasury: Staff Training

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount was spent by the department: (a) in the financial year 1988-89; and (b) in the financial year 1989-90, for the purpose of training actual and potential staff.
(2) What is the estimate for the amount to be spent on training staff and potential staff for the financial year 1990-91.
(3) For each of the years 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91, what was spent on, or what is the estimate for, salaries and payments in the nature of salaries paid by the department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What checks does the Department of Social Security make on Australian residents who receive the Australian pension (age or invalid), and who may receive pensions from overseas, to ensure that such latter sums are included as part of the Australian pension income test.

(2) Does the department write to the governments of other countries asking for details of pensions paid by these governments to Australian residents who are in receipt of Australian pensions but who the department suspects may also be qualified for pensions paid from overseas; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department target for review any ethnic groups residing in Australia who it may consider are likely to be in receipt of foreign pensions; if so, which particular ethnic groups.

(4) For 1989-90 how many pensioners, by country of origin and overall, were found to be in receipt of pensions from overseas which they had not declared for the purposes of the Australian pension income test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When the Department believes that a pensioner may be entitled to receive pension income from overseas because of the period of residence and/or work in another country or for other reasons, it will contact the pensioner and review the current payment of Australian pension. Overseas pension income is taken into account for the purposes of the Australian pension income test.
Additionally, through arrangements about to be introduced, overseas-born applicants for Australian pension payments will have this aspect checked before entitlement is confirmed.

In 1989-90, the Department wrote to 388,000 overseas-born pensioners, seeking information about pension income being received from other countries which had not already been disclosed. The letter also reminded them that they could be eligible for payments from overseas.

(2) The Department contacts overseas social security authorities about matters related to the payment of overseas pensions in Australia, in accordance with reciprocal agreement arrangements and for other reasons.
Pensioners can live and/or work in another country long enough for there to be an apparent entitlement to an overseas pension but none is recorded by the Department.
Further checks are being made about the entitlement of pensioners in this category who were part of the 1989-90 review.
In these circumstances the pensioner is requested to authorise the Department to contact the overseas social security organisation concerned and to make enquiries about the individual case.
This procedure is also being introduced for new applicants for Australian pension.

(4) The 1989-90 review of overseas-born pensioners referred to above resulted in 24,941 pensioners having rates of payment of Australian pension varied because previously undisclosed overseas pension income was taken into account. Details are as in the Table below:
RESULTS OF REVIEW OF OVERSEAS-BORN PENSIONERS 1989-90

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the book by Mr Fred Bennett, former Chief of Defence's Capital Procurement organisation, which is highly critical of the management of defence equipment projects, does the Minister agree with Mr Bennett's conclusions that Defence equipment procurement has suffered: ` . . . cost and schedule overruns, performance failures, and in some cases, abandonment of projects. (And that) Taxpayers have not received full value for money spent and military forces are less well equipped than they could have been.'

(2) Is Mr Bennett's statement that in the year to June 1987 ` . . . major weapons system project managers lodged submissions seeking increases in approved project costs that in total amounted to A$650 million' correct.

(3) Given Mr Bennett's view that cost overruns in equipment projects will continue `So long as existing costing methods, management systems, budgetary procedures and political attitudes will persist . . . ' (pages 80 and 81), what guarantees can the Minister give that current acquisition projects will be completed to specification, on time and within budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Major procurement processes, both overseas and in Australia, have provided and will continue to provide targets for criticism. In Australia the Defence project management system was the subject of scrutiny and comment by the Utz Review (1982) and the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts (JPCPA) Review (1984)-Report 243.

Since that time the creation of the Capital Procurement Organisation within Defence and the policies and operating procedures developed in support of its activities, together with subsequent Departmental actions have largely satisfied most of the recommendations in the JPCPA Report No.243. I recently provided related information to Senator Durack in answer to Question No.349 and it is pertinent to note that 56 of the 68 recommendations have been implemented with positive results. In 1988 and 1989 there were substantial reorganisations. These structural changes combined with the introduction of Program Management and Budgeting (PMB), extensive procurement reforms, and the devolvement of greater responsibility and accountability to project managers, has led to more efficient project management and cost control measures being exercised over the Defence major capital equipment program.

Mr Bennett's book on Defence equipment procurement contains references to the management of a number of major weapons systems projects in both government and the private sector, both in Australia and in several countries throughout the world (e.g. United States of America, United Kingdom, France, Germany, Sweden and Singapore). A substantial part of his book relates to overseas experiences in this area. It is acknowledged that Australian Defence project management has experienced similar difficulties in the management of its very large, complex and often unique weapons system projects which are at the leading edge of technology. However, I would draw on Mr Bennett's qualification at page 33 of his book which should be noted when assessing these difficulties in context, viz:

`Weapons system procurement differs from most areas of government administration in that projects have defined cost, schedule and performance targets. At first sight it may appear that efficiency might be measured by the extent to which those targets are achieved but, as the discussion will show, these targets tend to be idealistic aspirations rather than attainable goals and it is common for projects to be subject to disruptions that change the objectives or make them unattainable.'

The Government will continue its efforts to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Defence equipment acquisition process and implement measures for improved project management to ensure taxpayers are receiving value for money and that the forces are as well equipped as is possible from those Defence resources made available for this purpose.

(2) No. The data published by Mr Bennett appears to have been an estimate made prior to the end of the financial year. Actual increases in the costs of approved projects over the financial year 1986/87 for exchange and inflation effects were some $580m. In addition, there were real cost increases totalling some $704m related primarily to Defence-initiated changes in contract requirements including an increase in the number of Blackhawk helicopters at a project cost of $478m and a new phase of the Raven Radio project at a cost of $204m.

(3) Given the nature of Defence major procurement projects and the limitations of original cost, schedule and specification targets as a benchmark against which to measure project management performance, I am not prepared to give guarantees that those targets will always be met. While comparison of final and original target costs, schedules and product performance provide an indication of the quality of project management, for major projects there will often be good reason to vary specifications in the light of experience during the life of the project. The most important measures of performance are whether the equipment purchased is acceptable to the user and whether it represents value for money.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 6 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government have any plans to create a national rail system; if so, what is the timing for this and will the existing lines be used.
(2) Will passenger rail services be extended to more towns.
(3) What is the cost estimate for any planned upgrading of rail services on a nation-wide basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Federal Government's strategy to reform and revitalise rail focuses on the development of a national interstate rail freight organisation.

The proposal to establish a fully commercial National Rail Freight Corporation by 1 July 1991 received unanimous support from Heads of Government at the October 1991 Special Premiers' Conference. The Corporation will encompass all existing interstate rail freight operations and involve Commonwealth and State equity contributions.

A task force established by Australia's Transport Ministers is preparing detailed recommendations and proposals for consideration by Governments, and the matter will be addressed at the Special Premiers' Conference scheduled for May 1991.

The Federal Government strongly supports the concept of the National Rail Freight Corporation and as an indication of its commitment to the Corporation's establishment, I have approved the expenditure of $50 million in 1990/91 on upgrading infrastructure vital to its operations.
The NRFC will make use of existing lines.

(2) Operation of passenger rail services, except for Australian National services, is essentially a State responsibility. However, I recently established the Australian Rail Industry Advisory Council (ARIAC) to examine rail industry issues. Among other things it will look at the future of passenger services, including the possible establishment of a single rail passenger authority for interstate services.

(3) The National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force established by Australia's Transport Ministers is preparing detailed recommendations and proposals on such matters as infrastructure and investment for consideration by Governments. It is expected to report in the near future. However, any future upgrading of rail services would ultimately be a matter for the National Rail Freight Corporation's commercial judgement.
